articles.title: Remaining four ‘rebel’ Labour MPs have whip restored
articles.trailText: Neil Duncan-Jordan, Chris Hinchliff, Brian Leishman and Rachael Maskell are last of series of penalised backbenchers to return to the party
articles.summary: Four Labour MPs – Neil Duncan-Jordan, Chris Hinchliff, Brian Leishman and Rachael Maskell – had the whip restored after being suspended in July for repeatedly opposing government policies on welfare reform, winter fuel allowance cuts and the planning bill’s environmental impact. Following meetings with chief whip Jonathan Reynolds, they rejoined the parliamentary party; all but Maskell are from Labour’s 2024 intake. Their return follows earlier reinstatements of other rebels over benefit cap votes. Remaining independents include Zarah Sultana, Diane Abbott and others sidelined over ideological splits or misconduct inquiries.

articles.title: Boris Johnson trying to undermine BBC leadership, insiders fear after leak
articles.trailText: Director general under pressure after release of memo criticising reporting on Trump, trans rights and Gaza
articles.summary: After a leaked memo from ex-adviser Michael Prescott accused the BBC of skewed reporting on Donald Trump, trans rights and Gaza, Boris Johnson and allies—including board member Robbie Gibb—have intensified pressure on director general Tim Davie. Parliament’s culture, media and sport committee has demanded the BBC’s response by Monday as critics fret the leak is a bid to undermine the corporation ahead of charter renewal. Prescott, appointed via a panel including Gibb, will testify, while senior Tories call for resignations over alleged left-wing bias in Panorama and BBC Arabic.

articles.title: Nicola Sturgeon: I understand why people doubt my ignorance of alleged SNP embezzlement
articles.trailText: ‘Trust me, I had no idea’ about potential wrongdoing in Scottish National party, says former first minister
articles.summary: Ex-first minister Nicola Sturgeon insists she was unaware of alleged SNP embezzlement by ex-husband and former SNP CEO Peter Murrell. She says her relaxed post-resignation demeanour proves she had no suspicions. Murrell was arrested and charged; Sturgeon is no longer under investigation and has since separated and divorced. In a Politics Weekly UK podcast she warned of the UK union’s potential collapse amid resurging national parties and championed her blocked gender recognition reform as consistent with feminist and trans rights. She predicted a future ‘confederation’ of the British Isles or independent Scotland, Wales and Ireland.

articles.title: Kemi Badenoch to relaunch exclusive ‘advisory board’ for high-value donors
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Tory leader has plans to reinstate group that provided top donors with direct access to senior ministers
articles.summary: Kemi Badenoch plans to reinstate the Conservatives’ once-closed high-value donors’ advisory board under a new name, restoring exclusive access to her and shadow cabinet ministers. The original board, shut down in 2021 after a ‘cash for access’ scandal involving donors contributing over £250,000 a year and meeting Boris Johnson and Rishi Sunak, will allow top backers to lobby on tax cuts and spending restraint. With rival Reform UK courting wealthy ex-Tories and party coffers under strain post-election, Badenoch has raised over £500,000 since conference and £8.4m in 2025 so far.

articles.title: Nandy breached code over appointment of donor to lead football regulator
articles.trailText: Culture secretary ‘deeply regrets error’ after inquiry finds failures in declaring past donations by watchdog nominee
articles.summary: Culture secretary Lisa Nandy apologised to PM Keir Starmer after William Shawcross’s report found she failed to declare David Kogan’s past donations to her and Labour before nominating him to head the new Independent Football Regulator. The 18-page inquiry cited three governance code breaches, including omission of Kogan’s donations in interview discussions. Starmer accepted her inadvertent error, praised her integrity and willingness to learn lessons, while Kogan keeps his role. Shawcross recommended clearer conflict-of-interest guidance and reminded ministers to declare all relevant interests promptly.

articles.title: Lucy Powell says Labour must stand by promise not to raise key taxes
articles.trailText: New deputy leader also calls on government to lift two-child benefit cap urgently and in full
articles.summary: Labour deputy leader Lucy Powell urged her party to honour its manifesto pledge not to raise income tax, national insurance or VAT, warning that breaking it would erode trust. Positioning herself as an independent voice unbound by collective responsibility, she demanded a “budget of fairness” boosting household incomes and a full, urgent repeal of the two-child benefit cap to curb child poverty. Her BBC intervention ramps up pressure on Rachel Reeves’s budget choices and highlights internal tensions over funding public services versus upholding election promises.

articles.title: Why doesn’t Lammy just bring in a new policy of accidentally jailing people? | John Crace
articles.trailText: Justice secretary seemed to be the only person not being released, as he hid from questions about latest prison mishaps
articles.summary: John Crace skewers justice secretary David Lammy’s chaotic handling of repeated accidental prisoner releases—from an Algerian sex offender to the reformed con Billy Smith—while he’s effectively imprisoned by civil servants on 15-minute observation. Lammy dodges PMQs, blames a doppelgänger and Tory underfunding, and forgets crucial updates. The satirical piece even proposes a right-wing dream policy of “accidentally jailing” migrants, lampooning his PR blunders as emblematic of a collapsing prison system.

articles.title: Reform UK suspends another member of Kent county council
articles.trailText: Isabella Kemp’s departure means party has lost nine of 57 councillors elected in May, including four after video leak
articles.summary: Reform UK has suspended Kent county councillor Isabella Kemp, its ninth loss since May, amid fallout from a leaked video of leader Linden Kemkaran berating colleagues. Kemp, former adult social care chair and party data protection officer, intends to take unfair dismissal claims to a tribunal via Acas. Four councillors were earlier suspended after the leak, with two forming an Independent Reformers group. The turmoil forced cancellation of key committee meetings and cast doubt on promised savings, while prompting questions over a possible 5% council tax rise and drawing criticism from opposition and local leaders.

articles.title: Badenoch accused of ‘interfering’ in lobbying scandal linked to Cameron
articles.trailText: Lex Greensill alleges current Tory leader used business secretary position to protect former PM from scrutiny
articles.summary: Lex Greensill has accused Tory leader Kemi Badenoch of ‘interfering’ in a 2023 insolvency inquiry to protect David Cameron from scrutiny over his Greensill lobbying role. In a letter to new business secretary Peter Kyle, Greensill alleges Badenoch, as business secretary, restructured the Insolvency Service case to omit Cameron’s involvement ahead of his elevation to the Lords and appointment as foreign secretary. He argues this political intervention undermines the disqualification proceedings against him and calls for a full review amid ongoing UK, German and Swiss probes.

articles.title: Labour MPs revive ‘desperately needed’ soft left group to take on Reform
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Tribune hopes over 100 MPs join group led by Vicky Foxcroft and former cabinet minister Louise Haigh
articles.summary: Labour MPs led by Louise Haigh and Vicky Foxcroft have relaunched the Tribune group to organise the party’s soft left ahead of the budget, targeting over 100 supporters. Architects of last year’s welfare rebellion—including Justin Madders, Sarah Owen and Debbie Abrahams—and new intake MPs Yuan Yang and Beccy Cooper will steer the caucus. They aim to pressurise the government to abandon the two-child benefit cap, adopt a more muscular centre-left stance against Reform and the Greens, and revive Tribune’s 1960s progressive legacy after years of dormancy under Starmer.

articles.title: Lancashire’s Reform-run council plans to close care homes and day centres
articles.trailText: Questions about potential conflict of interest as council’s cabinet member for social care owns private care company
articles.summary: Reform UK–run Lancashire county council proposes closing five care homes and five day centres to save £4.16m a year, part of £103m cuts including £50m in adult social services over 2025–27. Residents such as 92-year-old Dorothy Devereux vow to resist, while Phil Price says the plan could “kill” his mother and will quit the party. Critics call it “selling off the family silver” and allege conflict of interest against social care cabinet member Graham Dalton, co-owner of private 1st for Care GB. A consultation runs until mid-December, with a final decision due in February.

articles.title: Reform’s public-sector pensions plan could cost billions extra, union warns
articles.trailText: Prospect says proposals to make payouts less generous would damage public finances rather than save money
articles.summary: Reform UK deputy leader Richard Tice proposes replacing defined benefit public-sector pensions for new entrants with defined contribution schemes to curb an unfunded £1.5–2.5 trn liability. Prospect union warns the switch would strip current contributions, cost taxpayers tens of billions long term, aggravate staffing shortages and create a fiscal “ticking timebomb.” Tice argues mirroring private-sector reforms is vital to prevent debt spiraling to 200% of GDP, while the OBR maintains existing pension costs are sustainable under its projections.

articles.title: London mayor sees parallels in Zohran Mamdani’s victory: ‘Hope won’
articles.trailText: Sadiq Khan, the city’s first Muslim mayor, says: ‘We are united by something far more fundamental, our belief in the power of politics to change people’s lives for the better’
articles.summary: Sadiq Khan, London’s first Muslim mayor, hailed Zohran Mamdani’s victory in New York—by almost 200,000 votes over Andrew Cuomo—as a win for hope over fear. From a Rio climate summit, Khan noted parallels in their ‘soft-left’ platforms: rent controls, high living wages (£14.80/hr vs $30/hr), fare freezes/free transit, and a 2% levy on incomes above $1 million. Both champions of Gaza recognition, they’ve endured right-wing slurs (Trump, Goldsmith, Cuomo) but insist multicultural, progressive cities reject dystopian fear-mongering, proving unity and optimism always triumph. Khan, re-elected for a historic third term, and Mamdani, son of Ugandan academic Mahmood Mamdani and filmmaker Mira Nair, embody diverse, progressive leadership.

articles.title: Miscounting to six costs Tory stand-in his gotcha against poppy-shock Lammy | John Crace
articles.trailText: Plucked from obscurity, James Cartlidge messed up his maths while his opposite number had forgotten his politics 101
articles.summary: At PMQs, Tory shadow defence secretary James Cartlidge, standing in for Keir Starmer–away at COP30–miscounted his six allotted questions while trying to nail Labour’s David Lammy over allegedly released asylum-seeker sex offenders. Cartlidge’s procedural fumbles and unfounded claims collapsed his ‘gotcha’, leaving Rishi Sunak distracted by a prostate cancer question and frontbenchers scrambling. Lammy, who also nearly sparked controversy by arriving poppy-less, salvaged his credibility when a veteran supplied one and defended Labour’s record on justice system failings. The episode spotlighted chaos in the Conservative deputy ranks and ongoing debate on prison release procedures.

articles.title: Letter: Prunella Scales obituary
articles.trailText: Neil Kinnock writes: Prunella Scales was a dedicated member of the Labour party
articles.summary: Neil Kinnock praises Prunella Scales as a brilliant comic and dramatic actor and committed political activist. As a leading Equity union member and lifelong Labour party supporter (like husband Tim West), she championed CND, the Anti-Apartheid Movement, the Anti-Nazi League and women in mining communities, alongside charity work. Known for her lauded portrayal of the Queen in Alan Bennett’s 1988 A Question of Attribution—achieved by studying newsreels—she embodied both artistry and civic engagement. Her personal motto—'Sometimes, dear, it’s useful to stand up and show that you are taking action and not acting'—underscored her belief in visible activism.

articles.title: Reeves wants to talk about the budget, but she’s taken a vow of white noise | John Crace
articles.trailText: Exclusive: It must be tough overseeing Schrödinger’s economy, fixing the foundations while also failing to fix them
articles.summary: At an 8.10 am Downing Street briefing, chancellor Rachel Reeves abandoned her traditional pre-budget silence for a 40-minute “interpretative dance” of coded messages and white noise, hinting at income tax rises without naming them. Claiming honesty while reneging on manifesto pledges against tax hikes, she portrayed the UK economy as simultaneously fixed and flawed—Schrödinger’s economy—downplaying OBR forecasts as backward-looking. Critics call it damage control ahead of 26 November. Meanwhile, Tory leadership contender Kemi Badenoch staged an inconsequential outdoor press-fest that few noticed.

articles.title: French taxi driver cleared of stealing from David Lammy after fare dispute
articles.trailText: Nassim Mimun, who left with Lammy’s and his wife’s bags after ‘tone escalated’, acquitted owing to lack of evidence
articles.summary: French court acquitted taxi driver Nassim Mimun, 40, of theft charges after allegedly taking cash and luggage belonging to UK deputy prime minister David Lammy and his wife at the end of a 600 km ride from Forlì, Italy, to Flaine in April. Mimun claimed Lammy refused to pay a €700 balance on a €1,550 booking and held their bags overnight, returning them to a police station the next day. Both parties filed complaints, but prosecutors said there was insufficient evidence to convict. Lammy, then foreign secretary, became justice secretary and deputy PM in September.

articles.title: Starmer was briefed on Mandelson’s Epstein links before appointing him, say civil servants
articles.trailText: PM had been given ‘summary of reputational risks’ but did not know about contents of emails before PMQs, MPs told
articles.summary: Senior civil servants told MPs that Keir Starmer received a Cabinet Office report on Peter Mandelson’s US ambassadorial candidacy, which flagged “prior relationship with Jeffrey Epstein” (including a 2009 stay at Epstein’s Manhattan flat and a 2002 meeting with Tony Blair), his past ministerial resignations and other reputational risks. The appointment proceeded before national security vetting was finalised. Starmer did not see Mandelson’s emails expressing support for Epstein before endorsing him at PMQs; their later publication prompted Mandelson’s removal. The government now mandates pre-appointment interviews and ministerial “fireside chats” for political ambassadorial posts.

articles.title: Nige is no longer laughing at himself as he ‘performs’ yet another big speech | John Crace
articles.trailText: Reform leader is trying to make it as a mainstream politician – which involves contradicting himself and gaslighting voters
articles.summary: At a showy City press conference set to ‘perform’ another economy speech, Reform UK’s Nigel Farage shed his self-mockery to pose as a mainstream politician. He recycled stale Brexit criticism while absolving himself of responsibility and gaslighting voters over tax cuts ‘aspirations.’ Attacking Labour and Tory MPs as inept, championing the wealthy over low-income families and pensioners, and scapegoating immigrants, Farage contradicted past pledges, flattered a young male audience and sidelined colleagues to cultivate credibility without substance.

articles.title: What would UK economic policy look like under Nigel Farage’s Reform?
articles.trailText: Leader’s speech offered most detailed explanation yet on party’s priorities on tax cuts, benefits, wages and pensions
articles.summary: In his most detailed outline to date, Nigel Farage framed Reform UK’s six economic priorities: he downgraded but retained the aspiration to raise the income-tax threshold to £20k, pledged only to reverse farm inheritance-tax hikes, and proposed tightening personal independence payments while lifting the two-child benefit cap solely for working UK nationals. He hinted at scrapping the triple lock and cutting public-sector pension fees, celebrated wealthy entrepreneurs as vital growth drivers, pledged new North Sea drilling to replace net-zero targets, and railed against diversity and compliance regimes as over-regulation.

articles.title: Nigel Farage backtracks on Reform UK’s promise to cut £90bn of taxes
articles.trailText: Party leader says proposal had been an ‘aspiration’ and accuses Tories and Labour of ‘wrecking the public finances’
articles.summary: Nigel Farage has partially reversed Reform UK’s pledge to cut £90bn of taxes, calling it an “aspiration” and insisting major cuts follow public spending control. He refused to guarantee the pensions triple lock and delayed significant tax reductions, offering only modest initial savings like higher thresholds and farm inheritance relief. Farage outlined deep welfare, net zero and asylum policy cuts, potential public sector pension reforms, and disputed PIP savings. He argued the youth minimum wage may be too high, attacked non-dom tax rules to retain high earners, lamented squandered post-Brexit deregulation, and declined to name a prospective chancellor, dubbing his economic team “a work in progress.”

articles.title: Nigel Farage to promise business deregulation in economic policy speech
articles.trailText: Reform UK leader to set out ‘pro-entrepreneurship’ agenda while rowing back on tax cuts pledge
articles.summary: Nigel Farage will unveil Reform UK’s most detailed economic policy yet, centring on sweeping business deregulation and pro-entrepreneurship measures in lieu of previously pledged £90bn tax cuts. Framing deregulation as a post-Brexit opportunity, he promises to rein in public spending to reduce borrowing costs before cutting taxes and to recruit industry experts into government. The speech seeks to bolster fiscal credibility and diversify Reform’s image beyond migration, though economists warn that his proposed spending cuts and £45bn net-zero rollback savings may be unachievable.

articles.title: Tory patience wears thin as Badenoch’s critics count down to May elections
articles.trailText: With the party adrift and Reform surging, Jenrick’s allies are sharpening their pitch for a post-election reset
articles.summary: At a VIP Tory event, debate swirled over Kemi Badenoch's potential ouster as Reform UK surges and local elections loom. Robert Jenrick—her runner-up in last year's leadership contest—leads calls for a post-May reset, eyeing the 36 MPs needed to trigger a confidence vote. Though Badenoch’s stamp-duty cut buys her breathing space, polls show her at –22 favourability, lagging Jenrick (–16). Ministers diverge on whether to replace her pre- or post-elections; contenders include Jenrick, James Cleverly, Mel Stride or lower-profile figures like Claire Coutinho. A pact with Reform remains divisive.

articles.title: Rachel Reeves considers 20% tax on assets of people deciding to leave UK
articles.trailText: Plans for ‘settling-up charge’ predicted to raise £2bn and would follow policy in place among most G7 countries
articles.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves is exploring a ‘settling-up charge’ requiring wealthy UK residents who emigrate to pay 20% tax on their retained business assets, aligning the UK with most G7 nations and potentially raising £2bn. Currently, non-UK residents pay 20% CGT on UK property over £6,000 but can avoid tax on other assets like shareholdings after departure. The proposed measure would tax unrealised gains on assets at exit, with options to defer payment. Treasury modelling is underway ahead of the budget, balancing risks of capital flight against fairness. A complementary plan could waive CGT on pre-arrival gains to attract investors.

articles.title: HMRC likely to have breached privacy laws in stopping child benefit – experts
articles.trailText: Watchdog contacts tax authority after families’ payments stopped based on flawed travel data
articles.summary: HMRC suspended child benefit for some 23,500 families under an anti-fraud crackdown using incomplete Home Office travel data, reinstating 1,979 payments so far after legal experts warned the flawed information breached UK data protection rules. The ICO has opened inquiries, urging that inter-departmental data sharing be necessary, accurate and proportionate. HMRC halted suspensions pending further checks, now cross-referencing travel records with PAYE data. Ministers face calls to explain failures and compensate affected households.

articles.title: Reform councillor defects to Tories after party’s policies left him ‘uncomfortable’
articles.trailText: Dartford representative James Buchan says ‘devastating’ immigration plans had created a lot of fear and anxiety
articles.summary: James Buchan, Reform UK councillor for Dartford’s Stone House ward in Kent, has defected to the Conservatives, citing discomfort with Nigel Farage’s anti-immigration agenda—particularly a plan to remove indefinite leave to remain for non-EU residents. Elected in a July by-election to serve local families, Buchan said fear-based rhetoric created anxiety and clashed with community service. A Reform source claims he should resign, while Tory council leader Jeremy Kite welcomed him. The move follows scrutiny of Farage over a racist MP defense and a bribery plea by his former Welsh leader.

articles.title: Ex-Tory member sues party over suspension for criticising Israel
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Bruce MacInnes, whose grandfather was archbishop of Jerusalem, told genocide remarks were antisemitic
articles.summary: Bruce MacInnes, a member since 2018 and grandson of Jerusalem’s former Anglican archbishop, is suing the Conservative party for £30,000 after a six-month suspension for labeling Israel’s actions in Gaza “genocide”. Party officials deemed his repeated references to the ICC’s plausible genocide finding antisemitic and say they emailed him, though he received no notices. MacInnes claims breach of contract and belief-based discrimination, highlighting opaque governance and suppression of pro-Palestinian views. Former foreign minister Sir Alan Duncan brands the suspension “McCarthyism”. MacInnes awaits a high-court date, having already incurred substantial legal fees.

articles.title: Bridget Phillipson ‘ready to take on unions’ over year 8 reading tests
articles.trailText: Education secretary says mandatory test needed to tackle ‘shocking outcomes’ for many working-class children
articles.summary: In a Guardian interview, education secretary Bridget Phillipson commits to compulsory Year 8 reading tests to address one-in-four children failing literacy, rising to one-in-three among disadvantaged pupils. She challenges teaching unions resisting “unnecessary” mandatory assessments, arguing they must justify poor outcomes for working-class kids. Following next week’s curriculum review, schools will also conduct informal writing and maths checks and must offer extracurricular enrichment across sports, arts, outdoor, civic and life-skills, partly to combat student detachment and radicalisation. Ofsted will inspect compliance. Phillipson also urges scrapping the two-child benefit cap to cut child poverty and insists Labour deliver tangible improvements ahead of the election.

articles.title: Keir Starmer keeps Trumps’ silver necklace gift – for a price
articles.trailText: Prime minister paid cabinet office to retain jewellery, but chose not to fork out for cufflinks and golf club
articles.summary: Keir Starmer paid to retain a personalized silver necklace gifted by Donald and Melania Trump during their September state visit, making it the only gift he kept. The Trumps’ personalized golf club, silver cufflinks and cowboy boots for Victoria Starmer were held by the Cabinet Office under the £140 retention rule, with Starmer covering the difference. Downing Street declined to disclose the necklace’s value. Starmer had presented Trump a ministerial red box embossed with the presidential seal and gave Melania a silk scarf by Ukrainian children. Gift exchanges between UK prime ministers and US presidents often spark controversy, recalling Gordon Brown’s ornamental pen holder to Obama, Qatar’s $400m Boeing 747 gift to Trump and past accusations that Trump gave fake jewellery.

articles.title: ‘Young Tories are fed up’: the students switching to Reform in big numbers
articles.trailText: A ‘nasty split’ is emerging on campus with one Conservative society opting to merge with their rightwing rivals
articles.summary: Student Conservative societies at Newcastle, York, Durham and beyond are merging or losing members to Reform UK amid dwindling Tory interest and HQ pushback; Newcastle’s merged society saw tenfold growth, while polls show Reform leads Conservatives 10% to 7% among 18-24s. Former Tory presidents like Henry Bateson, Xavier Hale and Jack Eccles drive new Reform branches, sparking feuds (“nasty split” at York) and exclusion from cross-party events. Reform’s campus surge doubles attendance, positioning student wings as a pipeline for future candidates.

articles.title: Zarah Sultana sets sights on replacing Labour and gaining power
articles.trailText: MP who left Labour in July to form leftwing grouping with Jeremy Corbyn, says party is not just one of protest
articles.summary: Zarah Sultana, MP who left Labour in July to co-found leftwing “Your Party” with Jeremy Corbyn, says her vision is to replace Labour over the next 10–40 years by winning state power and implementing socialist policies—nationalisation, council housing, secure jobs—through grassroots organising. The new group has faced leadership rows, funding shortfalls and a name dispute ahead of a conference to settle its permanent title. Tensions flared with Corbyn over a paid membership system, prompting defamation threats before reconciliation. Sultana also accused Nigel Farage and Reform UK of fascist tactics, warning against a “fascist government,” a claim Reform UK dismissed, telling her to “go back to school or buy a dictionary.”

articles.title: UK launches search for ‘town of culture’ among places ‘written out of national story’
articles.trailText: Lisa Nandy says government hopes to build on success of cities of culture programme, with £3.5m for winner
articles.summary: Culture secretary Lisa Nandy has launched a competition to crown the UK’s first “town of culture,” offering the winning community £3.5m to stage a cultural programme in summer 2028. Modelled on the successful cities of culture scheme that boosted Derry, Hull, Coventry and Bradford, the initiative aims to spotlight places “written out of the national story,” with towns under 75,000 population encouraged to apply. The government also opened bids for the 2029 UK City of Culture, promising a £10m award. Nandy, representing Wigan, argued this would give “access to excellence,” amplify local pride and ensure communities from Barnsley to Wigan can see their creative contributions reflected in Britain’s shared narrative.

articles.title: Lettings agency takes blame in Rachel Reeves licence row
articles.trailText: Agency says staff member offered to apply for licence to allow chancellor to rent out family home, but failed to do so
articles.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves admitted her south London rental fell foul of Southwark’s selective licensing rules after moving into 11 Downing Street. Initially No 10 said an apology sufficed, but Harvey & Wheeler—the lettings agent—has since taken responsibility, revealing a former staffer offered to apply for the licence then failed to do so. Emails between the agent and Reeves’s husband, senior civil servant Nicholas Joicey, corroborate this. Southwark council has no plans for enforcement. Prime Minister Keir Starmer, after consulting ethics adviser Laurie Magnus, ruled the breach inadvertent, but Conservatives press for a full investigation.

articles.title: Starmer feels the effects of setting high standards for his party in opposition
articles.trailText: Despite pledges to run a squeaky clean administration the prime minister and some in his cabinet have been caught out
articles.summary: After criticising Tory ministers over Partygate, UK PM Keir Starmer’s pledge to uphold “squeaky clean” ethics has stumbled as he and four senior colleagues faced rules breaches. Starmer drew fire for accepting freebies and Rachel Reeves admitted inadvertently renting out her home without a licence; Louise Haigh, Tulip Siddiq and Angela Rayner resigned after misconduct or underpayment. Downing Street swiftly cleared Reeves but scrutiny persists. These episodes underscore the difficulties of enforcing high probity standards in government and risk undermining Starmer’s reformist credibility.

articles.title: What has Rachel Reeves done wrong – and how serious are things for her?
articles.trailText: A few weeks before she delivers budget, timing of revelation chancellor failed to buy rental licence could not be worse
articles.summary: With under a month until the budget, Chancellor Rachel Reeves admitted breaking Southwark council rules by letting her Dulwich home without the £945 licence required under the 2004 Housing Act. An estate agent warned her husband to apply but failed to submit after resigning, prompting Reeves to take full responsibility—apologising to Prime Minister Keir Starmer and applying for the licence. Conservatives call for further scrutiny, accusing her of negligence, but No 10 says her prompt action negates the need for a formal probe. Critics view the timing as a distraction ahead of the budget and a test of Starmer’s ethical stance.

articles.title: How one bad oyster did for the Liberal party | Letter
articles.trailText: Letters: Responding to a Pass notes article, Michael Meadowcroft writes on how a bad bivalve changed political history in the early 20th century
articles.summary: Michael Meadowcroft highlights how in December 1914 Liberal chief whip Percy Illingworth, aged 45, died of typhoid after eating a contaminated oyster, depriving Asquith of a trusted organizer. Subsequent chiefs, notably Vivian Phillipps in the 1923 hung parliament, proved divisive: his fierce loyalty to Asquith and antipathy toward David Lloyd George deepened rifts. Phillipps’s inability to bridge factions during the 1924 Labour minority government accelerated the Liberal Party’s fragmentation and long-term decline.

articles.title: Lib Dem members criticise ‘trans-exclusionary’ rule change for party elections
articles.trailText: Rules on quotas to ensure fair representation of women changed on legal advice in light of supreme court ruling
articles.summary: Liberal Democrat members have criticised an abrupt rule change—introduced on legal advice after a supreme court ruling—that ties internal election quotas to sex at birth rather than lived gender. The party’s LGBT+ group labelled it “explicitly trans-exclusionary,” Lib Dem Women expressed “grave concerns,” and Young Liberals called it “unacceptable.” At least five trans or non-binary candidates face direct exclusion. Critics argue the move contradicts Lib Dem values, lacked consultation and risks undermining transgender inclusion despite promised LGBT+ quotas on larger committees.

articles.title: Kemi Badenoch smiles from the stump as she heads towards oblivion | John Crace
articles.trailText: The relaxed demeanour of the Tory leader suggests she is just relieved that things aren’t worse than they could be
articles.summary: Kemi Badenoch turned up smiling at a chilly outdoor stump event on London’s South Bank, where low turnout and lacklustre Mel Stride underscored the Tories’ dwindling relevance as Reform dominates the news agenda. Trailing in polls and clinging to official-opposition status, she seized on Rachel Reeves’s Dulwich licensing blunder to demand her resignation, then condemned looming income-tax rises. Wrapping up, Badenoch disowned Katie Lam’s deportation Bill from Chris Philp, deeming it dead in the water but promising alternative enforcement. Despite looming defeat and muted leadership unrest, she appeared unusually relaxed.

articles.title: Ministers to delegate some public appointments in attempt to cut delays
articles.trailText: Under shake-up affecting about 4,000 roles, officials will run more of hiring process but ministers can have final say
articles.summary: Ministers to delegate public appointments to senior officials under new Cabinet Office code covering about 4,000 roles in bodies like Ofcom, Environment Agency and BBC. Aims to cut excessive delays—currently only one in seven posts filled within three months—by letting officials run more of the process while ministers retain final selection and job specs. Candidates may stay on a reserve list for two years. The code introduces a ‘public service’ principle, mandates publication of PM and Crown appointments, and preserves ministerial override powers with commissioner consultation when departing from panel advice or appointing without competition.

articles.title: No 10 refuses to say if ethics adviser saw proof Reeves’s rental breach was ‘inadvertent’
articles.trailText: Pressure mounts on chancellor over failing to get a licence to rent out her south London home
articles.summary: Downing Street refused to say whether ministerial conduct adviser Laurie Magnus saw evidence supporting chancellor Rachel Reeves’s claim she “inadvertently” rented out her four-bedroom Southwark home without a required £945 licence, citing confidentiality. Prime minister Keir Starmer, relying on Magnus’s confidential advice, accepted her prompt application for the licence and apology as sufficient. Advertised at £3,200 a month since September 2024, Reeves noted the rental income but said her agency hadn’t informed her of the licensing requirement. Conservative leader Kemi Badenoch demanded Reeves be sacked if she broke the law, warning of political fallout ahead of next month’s budget.

articles.title: Tories will not deport legally settled people, Badenoch clarifies
articles.trailText: Katie Lam spoke ‘imprecisely’ in stating large number of people would ‘need to go home’, says Conservative leader
articles.summary: Kemi Badenoch told reporters the Conservatives will not deport legally settled residents or retrospectively strip indefinite leave to remain (ILR), clarifying shadow minister Katie Lam’s ‘imprecise’ assertion that thousands would ‘go home’ under a proposed draft bill tying ILR loss to benefit claims or income below £38,700. Only criminal convictions can revoke ILR. Exiting the European convention on human rights will allow denying benefits to non-EU migrants. Lam’s comments triggered Tory complaints, Lib Dem and Labour demands for policy clarity on benefits, including maternity pay.

articles.title: Boris Johnson tells Tories to stop ‘bashing green agenda’ or risk losing next election
articles.trailText: Former PM says he has not seen party ‘soaring in the polls as a result of saying what rubbish net zero is’
articles.summary: Boris Johnson has urged the Conservatives to stop ‘bashing the green agenda’ or risk losing the next election, joining Theresa May and John Major in warning that attacking net zero alienates mainstream voters. He criticised Kemi Badenoch’s plan to repeal the Climate Change Act, abandon 2050 net zero targets, scrap carbon budgets and disband the Climate Change Committee in favor of ‘cheap and reliable energy’. Johnson, who backed net zero and hosted COP26, says he saw no polling boost from attacking climate policy and remains committed to long-term CO2 reduction despite post-Ukraine energy challenges.

articles.title: Rachel Reeves admits breaking rules by renting out her house without a licence
articles.trailText: Chancellor is backed by prime minister after saying she ‘inadvertently’ failed to pay fee required by London council
articles.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves has admitted inadvertently renting her four-bedroom Southwark home for £3,200 a month without the required £945 selective licence after moving to Downing Street. Using a letting agency that failed to flag the council rule, she notified PM Keir Starmer and ethics authorities, applied for the licence immediately, and apologised. Starmer closed the case after his adviser’s review. Conservatives, led by Kemi Badenoch, and Lib Dems warned the oversight threatens confidence ahead of Reeves’s forthcoming budget, which may include further property tax rises; Reeves has declared rental income since September 2024.

articles.title: ‘The novelty will wear off’: Labour hopes publicity will be Farage’s downfall
articles.trailText: With no sign of Reform’s media strategy slowing down, Labour insiders fret over limiting Nigel Farage’s support
articles.summary: Labour insiders are increasingly anxious as Nigel Farage’s Reform UK maintains persistent poll leads by staging back-to-back press conferences during news lulls, dominating headlines with half-truths and uncosted or contested policy claims – from migrant benefit cuts to welfare and government overhauls. MPs admit they underestimated his summer momentum and struggle to counter his agenda or articulate a compelling alternative. Reform plans further big economic policy announcements next week, with Farage vowing pre-tax spending cuts and his deputy Richard Tice headlining at Bloomberg. While some in Labour believe Farage’s novelty will fade, strategists warn against complacency ahead of next May’s election.

articles.title: Farage reclaims centre stage as Reform’s Sarah Pochin keeps the world at bay
articles.trailText: Nige suffers through lacklustre PMQs to seize the spotlight with drive-by demand to get further away from Europe
articles.summary: Reform UK co-leader Sarah Pochin has been absent from three consecutive Commons appearances—allegedly overwhelmed by the sight of MPs of colour—leaving Nigel Farage to dominate Wednesday’s PMQs. He used his allotted 10-minute rule bill to propose exiting the European Convention on Human Rights, a largely performative gesture promptly defeated after Lib Dem leader Ed Davey exposed his misinformation and defended the Convention’s accountability role. Reform’s Russia connections resurfaced in debate, while PMQs otherwise featured predictable spat over tax and economic pledges.

articles.title: Racism, intent and the diversity in TV adverts | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Readers respond to the Reform UK MP Sarah Pochin’s remarks about ‘adverts full of black people, full of Asian people’
articles.summary: Letters reacting to Reform UK MP Sarah Pochin’s complaints that TV adverts feature “full of black people, full of Asian people.” Contributors note that dismissing racism as unintentional prejudice obscures systemic bias: Nigel Farage’s defense echoes Frank Hester’s violent remarks about Diane Abbott and Robert Jenrick’s “white face” quip. Writers argue everyday language reveals widespread racism, citing James Baldwin’s “innocence constitutes the crime.” They question Pochin’s fixation on demographic ratios, likening it to Ludovic Kennedy’s 2003 critique, and explain diverse casting as marketing logic, not “woke conspiracy.” The letters warn inclusion is contingent and challenge Farage to define racist expulsion criteria.

articles.title: Letter: Lord Taverne obituary
articles.trailText: Andrew Copson writes: Taverne showed how a humanist outlook can anchor an ethical and courageous public life
articles.summary: Dick Lord Taverne pioneered modern humanist public life, blending rigorous reason with ethical courage. As founder of the Institute for Fiscal Studies and co-founder of Sense About Science, he championed evidence-based policy, warned of cultural drift to dogma in his book The March of Unreason, and advocated secularism, humanist marriages, assisted dying, and non-religious rights in the House of Lords. His calm, unsentimental approach rooted tradition in reason, defining a legacy of openness, civilised discourse, and principled reform.

articles.title: Tightening Pip benefit eligibility could save £9bn a year, says Reform
articles.trailText: Lee Anderson says ‘gaming the system’ is too common and jokes about symptoms of anxiety and depression
articles.summary: Reform UK proposes tightening PIP (personal independence payment) rules to save up to £9bn annually by excluding claimants with milder mental health issues (eg anxiety), reinstating mandatory face-to-face assessments and clamping down on eligibility 'gaming'. MP Lee Anderson, who admits coaching clients on benefit forms during his Citizens Advice tenure, criticized remote assessments and alleged widespread system manipulation. Policy head Zia Yusuf slammed the absence of reassessments and lifelong labels on young people. The plan, requiring £100m for in-person tests and work support, mirrors delayed government efforts after Conservative rebellions.

articles.title: Boris Johnson approved China’s London super-embassy proposal in 2018
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Conservatives under Theresa May gave Beijing assurances that it could proceed with the proposal
articles.summary: Boris Johnson, then foreign secretary under Theresa May, wrote in May 2018 to China’s top diplomat Wang Yi approving Royal Mint Court in London as the site for China’s “largest overseas diplomatic investment,” a £255m “super-embassy.” He framed it as reciprocal to the UK’s planned embassy redevelopment in Beijing, citing high-level assurances brokered by Eddie Lister. Despite this consent, local planning permission was refused in 2022, the application lapsed, then was resubmitted under Labour. Keir Starmer has vowed to decide independently amid Chinese pressure and local backlash, while Conservatives now demand transparency on the approval process.

articles.title: Britain can defy gloomy economic forecasts, says Rachel Reeves
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Fiscal watchdog predicts productivity downgrade will leave chancellor with £20bn gap to fill in budget
articles.summary: Facing a £20bn fiscal shortfall after the OBR’s 0.3pp productivity downgrade, Chancellor Rachel Reeves rejects gloomy forecasts and vows to defy them in next month’s budget. She admits tough choices—possibly a targeted income tax rise, reversing the winter fuel cut and ending the two-child benefit cap—while ruling out a return to austerity. Citing faster wage growth than inflation, potential interest-rate cuts and planned reforms, Reeves criticises rivals for “talking Britain down,” stresses investment in public services and infrastructure, and highlights the IMF’s upgraded 1.3% growth forecast, second-highest in the G7.

articles.title: Your Party to launch legal action against three of its ‘rogue’ founders, sources say
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Leftwing party seeks to recover donations and data from company run by Andrew Feinstein, Jamie Driscoll and Beth Winter
articles.summary: Your Party, the leftwing movement led by Jeremy Corbyn and Zarah Sultana, is suing three of its founding directors—Andrew Feinstein, Jamie Driscoll and Beth Winter—via MoU Operations Ltd for refusing to transfer about £800,000 in membership donations and supporter data after a final deadline. The row, stemming from an unauthorized membership portal launch that generated over 20,000 sign-ups, jeopardises next month’s national conference by limiting delegates. Party insiders say legal action was a last resort; the founders deny wrongdoing. An ICO probe is under way.

articles.title: Should the Home Office be broken up into two units?
articles.trailText: The department is once again the subject of debate about whether it is beyond repair after immigration and prison problems
articles.summary: The Home Office, beset by dysfunction, scandals from Windrush to asylum hotel failures, and enduring poor morale among its 50,000 staff, faces renewed calls for split into crime/policing/security and borders/immigration units. New Home Secretary Shabana Mahmood and Perm Sec Antonia Romeo confront this debate as politicians from Karen Bradley to the Greens echo past demands, despite No 10’s view that reorganisation would be disruptive. Critics like Nick Timothy and the Institute for Government argue that culture, leadership and policy reforms, not structural overhaul, are essential. Mahmood now weighs a full-scale transformation against continued crisis management.

articles.title: Reform wheels out Danny Kruger, the ‘brains’ of Nigel Farage’s operation | John Crace
articles.trailText: A man with no experience of government is to prepare the party … to govern. What could possibly go wrong?
articles.summary: Reform UK has appointed Danny Kruger, an ex-Tory MP with minimal government experience, as Nigel Farage’s chief policy architect ahead of the next election. Despite only writing opposition speeches for David Cameron and briefly serving as Boris Johnson’s political secretary, Kruger outlined plans for a sovereign parliament with half of ministers hand-picked by Farage, a 30% civil service cull, scrapping international treaties and DEI programmes, and a secret anti-waste hotline. At a tightly controlled press conference, he dodged accountability for his Wiltshire constituency and defended Sarah Pochin against “accidental racism” claims. Critics warn his proposals expose Reform’s contradictions and its reliance on personality over substance.

articles.title: John Major tells Tories alliance with Reform would be ‘beyond stupid’
articles.trailText: Former PM says a pact would destroy the Conservatives for good and urges them not to desert centre ground
articles.summary: Former PM John Major told a Conservative party lunch that an alliance with Nigel Farage’s Reform UK would ‘for ever destroy’ the Tories, dismissing such a pact as ‘beyond stupid.’ He urged any defectors to leave now and called on the party to reclaim the centre ground, warning that populist nationalism erodes democracy. Major criticised leader Kemi Badenoch’s plans to scrap the net-zero target and cut overseas aid by £7bn, arguing that one-nation Conservatism is under threat. He called for reintegrating right-wing, centre and centre-left Tories to rebuild broad appeal, cautioning that without unity the party risks irrelevance amid a global swing towards authoritarianism.

articles.title: Letter: Sir Robert Worcester obituary
articles.trailText: Neil Kinnock writes: Characteristically, Bob was offering kindly reassurance. I was grateful.
articles.summary: Sir Robert Worcester, founder of the MORI polling firm and former Labour pollster supplanted by Philip Gould, remained a loyal friend to Neil Kinnock. After Labour’s defeat by John Major in 1992, yielding a slim 21-seat majority, Worcester phoned Kinnock to console him with a revealing statistic: the combined Tory margins in the 11 most marginal constituencies totaled just 1,240 votes. By framing 1,240 out of 31 million votes as a narrow loss, Worcester exemplified his hallmark kindness and analytical reassurance.

articles.title: Reform UK would let ministers ignore international law, Kruger says
articles.trailText: Party’s efficiency chief says he would cut civil service and close six government offices – most of which are already closing
articles.summary: Reform UK’s new efficiency tsar Danny Kruger proposes sweeping powers for ministers, including ignoring international law, rewriting the ministerial and civil service codes, and granting cabinet “hire and fire” control over civil servants. He plans a 30% cut in the civil service, closure of six government offices, political appointments from outside Parliament (notably in the Lords), and tougher anti-union rules to curb “malevolent” staff. Kruger likens his approach to Trump’s, while critics highlight organisational chaos within Reform and question the feasibility of its savings claims.

articles.title: Jeremy Corbyn to appear in north London panto
articles.trailText: Former Labour leader will make onscreen cameo as ‘Wizard of Oz-lington’ in drag production of Wicked Witches
articles.summary: Jeremy Corbyn, the ex-Labour leader turned independent MP for Islington North, will appear onscreen as the “Wizard of Oz-lington” in a drag pantomime of Wicked Witches at north London’s Pleasance theatre. This cameo marks the venue’s first panto in over 20 years and celebrates its 30th anniversary. Corbyn praised local theatre’s inclusive, festive spirit. The production—packed with camp cabaret, pop parody and soaring vocals—promises a gloriously sassy Christmas spectacular. Expelled from Labour in 2024, Corbyn has since co-founded a new leftwing party with ex-MP Zarah Sultana.

articles.title: Lammy tells Labour to learn from Caerphilly defeat as party seeks reset
articles.trailText: Deputy PM tells MPs party must pick clearer fights that show its values after byelection slump
articles.summary: Deputy PM David Lammy urged Labour to treat its 11% vote share in the Caerphilly byelection, where Plaid Cymru prevailed and Reform UK finished second, as a reset moment, warning centre-left parties in Canada, Norway and Australia have rebounded from similar midterm slumps. Speaking privately to MPs, he stressed picking fights that tangibly showcase Labour’s values and turning reform from slogan into something voters feel. Colleagues praised Wes Streeting’s candid assessment that the party hasn’t told a compelling story, while still backing Sir Keir Starmer’s recent moral attack on Reform UK as a potential reset ahead of May’s polls.

articles.title: Nige thinks Pochin’s comments were ugly and unpleasant. But he agrees with them | John Crace
articles.trailText: Reform is no place for racists, and every party has its bad apples. But the benchmark seems to be higher at Farage’s party
articles.summary: Reform MP Sarah Pochin sparked outrage on TalkTV by complaining she was driven “mad” by seeing “too many black and brown faces” in adverts, lamenting diversity and praising a white-only ‘traditional English’ aesthetic. Party leader Nigel Farage condemned her comments as “ugly and unpleasant” but refused to suspend the whip, arguing they weren’t intentionally racist and he can’t vet every member. At a separate press conference on grooming gangs, Farage dismissed the official inquiry as a cover-up, proposed an MP-led investigation of all 250,000 victims, and bizarrely urged leniency for Prince Andrew.

articles.title: Nigel Farage defends MP’s complaint about TV adverts as ‘ugly’ but not ‘deliberately’ racist
articles.trailText: Reform MP Sarah Pochin said seeing adverts of black or Asian people ‘drives me mad’
articles.summary: Reform UK leader Nigel Farage defended MP Sarah Pochin after she said adverts “full of black and Asian people” “drive her mad”, calling her wording “ugly” but insisting it was not deliberately racist and that he would have disciplined her if it were. Pochin’s remarks drew cross-party condemnation from Keir Starmer, Rishi Sunak, Wes Streeting and others. At the same press conference, Farage urged MPs to launch a parliamentary inquiry into decades-long grooming gang abuses, proposing a Commons subcommittee, potential Equality Act reforms and winning support from survivor Ellie-Ann Reynolds.

articles.title: How can Rachel Reeves reduce inflation?
articles.trailText: Five ways the chancellor could mitigate a UK inflation rate that is harming households – and Labour’s vote share
articles.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves plans in next month’s budget to curb the UK’s high inflation, which is eroding living standards and Labour’s poll-lead. She must also bridge an anticipated £20–30 bn budget shortfall without breaching her pledge to forgo hikes to income tax, national insurance or VAT. Key proposals include a zero-rate VAT on energy (saving households ~£83 pa and cutting CPI by ~0.2 pp); freezing fuel duty despite low oil prices; capping or pausing rail and bus fare hikes; and restraining public-sector pay settlements to avoid wage-price spirals.

articles.title: A costly lesson for Labour in Caerphilly | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Readers respond to Plaid Cymru’s victory in the recent Welsh byelection
articles.summary: Letters blame Labour’s Caerphilly defeat on a deeper malaise predating Starmer rather than youthful ‘looney left’ voters, arguing Corbyn-era populism was a symptom of Britain’s crisis. One writer notes Farage understood this and warns Labour’s decline will persist until it adapts. Others say anti-immigration concerns drove voters away from xenophobic parties, explaining Reform’s poor showing. Contributors call for a policy reset—ending back-room deals, boosting environmental and democratic oversight, protecting protest rights and uniting against the far-right and big tech—while one quips ‘Nigel Mirage.’

articles.title: Reform UK expels two Kent councillors accused of ‘undermining’ its interests
articles.trailText: Robert Ford, subject of an ‘unofficial complaint’, and Bill Barrett, suspended after leaked meeting, removed via email
articles.summary: Reform UK has expelled two Kent county councillors, Robert Ford (Maidstone Rural West) and Bill Barrett (Ashford), after suspensions sparked by an unofficial misconduct complaint from female council staff against Ford and Barrett’s vocal criticism of party hierarchy. Party HQ cited that both had undermined Reform’s interests and brought it into disrepute. Three colleagues—Oliver Bradshaw, Paul Thomas and Maxine Fothergill—remain suspended pending investigation. The expulsions cut Reform’s Kent contingent from 57 to 48 seats. A leaked August meeting revealed internal tensions and council disruptions, including a cancelled school transport committee.

articles.title: Reeves to lead trade mission to Saudi Arabia amid human rights concerns
articles.trailText: Ministers hope to secure a deal with the Gulf Cooperation Council that could add £1.6bn to the UK economy
articles.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves will lead UK business and government delegations to Saudi Arabia—her first Gulf visit in six years—to push a proposed trade pact with the Gulf Cooperation Council that ministers say could boost the UK economy by £1.6bn annually and add £600m in wages. Reeves plans meetings with Saudi royals, US officials and CEOs at the Future Investment Initiative and Fortune Global Forum. The deal, which may lift UK–GCC trade by 16% from its current £59bn level, faces pressure from rights campaigners and the TUC demanding legally binding human and labor rights protections.

articles.title: Labour must counter ‘growing sense of despair’, Streeting warns after Welsh defeat
articles.trailText: Health secretary urges party to take Caerphilly result to heart as Lucy Powell gets to work as deputy leader
articles.summary: Health secretary Wes Streeting warned Labour must counter a “growing sense of despair” after losing the Caerphilly Welsh Senedd byelection – a seat held for over a century – to Plaid Cymru and Reform amid midterm fatigue. He urged tangible proof of change, likening it to the 2021 Hartlepool setback, and called for a more compelling narrative on NHS improvements, childcare and cost of living. New deputy leader Lucy Powell — elected with 54% of votes but just 16.6% turnout — pledges to reconnect grassroots, amplify member voices and boost optimism ahead of next May’s local elections.

articles.title: Lord Taverne obituary
articles.trailText: Ousted Labour MP who had a famous byelection win against his old party in 1973 and later joined the SDP
articles.summary: Dick Taverne, British MP turned peer, died aged 97. Born in 1928 in Sumatra to Dutch parents and naturalised at 21, he won a scholarship to Balliol (first in classics) after Charterhouse. Elected Labour MP for Lincoln in 1962, he served in the Home Office and Treasury but was deselected in 1973 over his pro-European stance. Resigning, he won the Lincoln by-election as Democratic Labour, held it in Feb 1974, then lost in Oct. He co-founded the Institute for Fiscal Studies, joined the SDP in 1981, became a Lib Dem peer in 1996 and later founded Sense About Science. He married microbiologist Janice Hennessey and is survived by two daughters.

articles.title: Would a written constitution save Britain from the far right? | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Readers respond to George Monbiot’s article calling for a constitution to guard against the rise of Reform UK and autocracy
articles.summary: Readers broadly endorse George Monbiot’s call for a written UK constitution to block a far-right takeover but warn it isn’t a panacea. Peter Loschi cites the US: 75% of Trump’s actions were unconstitutional yet unchecked by compliant institutions, stressing civic culture over text. Ray Flood dismisses Reform UK as a protest vote and urges Labour to campaign on the NHS. Nathon Raine fears a citizens’ convention would be dominated by liberal activists, mirroring Farage’s entrenchment of his worldview. Robin Hambleton advocates enshrining local-authority protections in the devolution bill, citing Sweden’s success.

articles.title: Keir Starmer shares post-punk passion and revisits musical past
articles.trailText: Prime minister praises Scottish post-punk band and shares details about his family life in Radio 3 interview
articles.summary: On BBC Radio 3's Private Passions, PM Keir Starmer revisited his musical roots—from childhood violin scholarship and flautist days with future Fatboy Slim, to daily escapes in Beethoven, Tchaikovsky and Elgar. He praised Scottish post-punk band Orange Juice, recalling its soundtrack to student life in 1980s Leeds, and shared northern soul kitchen sessions with his daughter. Emotional reflections included tributes to his late mother, a ballet-loving Still’s disease victim, and his brother Nick’s recent death. Starmer warned against cuts to school music and pledged post-Brexit fixes to ease touring hurdles for UK artists.

articles.title: Reform MP’s remarks about TV adverts were ‘racist’, says Wes Streeting
articles.trailText: Health secretary hardens Labour line after Sarah Pochin said advertising ‘doesn’t reflect our society’
articles.summary: Wes Streeting, the Health Secretary, condemned Reform UK MP Sarah Pochin’s remark that adverts featuring Black and Asian people “drive her mad” and fail to represent “average white families” as racist, warning of a return to 1970s-80s style racism. Pochin apologized for what she called “poorly phrased” criticism of DEI-minded advertising but faced sustained backlash as Labour’s Anna Turley and Lib Dem leader Ed Davey denounced her, Labour urged Nigel Farage to intervene, Tory MP Chris Philp reluctantly admitted her comments were wrong, and Pochin later doubled down on X.

articles.title: ‘We have to book bigger rooms’: Green membership surge causes novel problems
articles.trailText: Party rides high with new leader Zack Polanski winning media plaudits and supporter numbers doubling to 140,000
articles.summary: Since Zack Polanski’s takeover as Green party leader in England and Wales seven weeks ago, membership has doubled from 70,000 to over 140,000—overtaking Lib Dems and Conservatives—and local branches report surges, with some jumping from 400 to 1,000 activists, forcing room upgrades. Polanski’s rapid media blitz—61 interviews in two days, a top-10 political podcast, and an 11 million-view social video—has boosted polling to 15% and energized a once fractious coalition. While skeptics warn his eco-populism may alienate rural supporters, activists report unified enthusiasm. The next election tests in May’s council and Senedd polls will reveal if this momentum translates into seats and a real threat to Labour.

articles.title: Companies that donated to Labour awarded £138m in contracts, study finds
articles.trailText: Report raises fresh concerns about the link between political donations and public spending
articles.summary: Thinktank Autonomy Institute finds companies donating to Labour received £138m in contracts in its first year, within two years of £580k in donations (July 2024–June 2025). Over the long term, 25 Labour-linked firms have won £796.4m since 2001. Across parties, 125 corporate donors gave £30.15m and secured £28.8bn in central government contracts, £2.5bn awarded within two years. Key examples: Baringa Partners donated £30k and won £35.2m; Grant Thornton gave £81.7k and received £6.5m. Four strategic suppliers—Fujitsu, KPMG, Microsoft and PwC—also donated then won contracts. Experts call for banning donors from procurement; government insists processes remain fair.

articles.title: Labour’s new deputy leader says party must pay more heed to its members
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Powell, who was sacked as Commons leader by Starmer in September, says government should stop trying to ‘out-Reform Reform’
articles.summary: Lucy Powell, Manchester Central MP, won Labour deputy leadership with 54% (87,407 votes) against Bridget Phillipson’s 46% (73,536) on just 16.6% turnout. Her victory follows Labour’s third-place, 11% showing in the Caerphilly by-election. Powell pledges to amplify grassroots voices, involve a broader membership in policy debates, and rebuild support ahead of May 2025 local polls. She urges clearer messaging on Labour successes—from workers’ rights to free school meals and NHS appointments—warns against mimicking Reform UK, and calls for a progressive alliance. Keir Starmer backed her leadership and vowed to unite the party against hardline Conservative immigration rhetoric.

articles.title: ‘History is repeating itself’: fight against far-right in London’s East End goes on
articles.trailText: Eighty-nine years after residents drove Oswald Mosley’s Blackshirts from Tower Hamlets, anti-far right coalition is still vital in borough
articles.summary: In Tower Hamlets, 89 years on from the 1936 Battle of Cable Street, residents and community groups continue to repel far-right incursions. This autumn police banned a UKIP “crusade” through the borough’s 40% Muslim population to avert disorder. Far-right figures like Tommy Robinson have targeted local Muslim councillors online, while charities and interfaith networks mobilise counter-protests. Mayor Lutfur Rahman’s progressive agenda—free school meals, council home investment—coexists with persistent child poverty. A recent bilingual festival on Brick Lane symbolised a resilient, diverse East End united against xenophobia.

articles.title: Factionalism, farce and chaos dog Reform UK in the garden of England
articles.trailText: All is not well in Kent for Nigel Farage’s party as the recent video of an incendiary meeting suggests
articles.summary: Reform UK’s Kent county council is riven by infighting after leader Linden Kemkaran’s leaked video, in which she told dissenters to “fucking suck it up,” triggered four suspensions, one defection to UKIP and loyalty oaths by 37 of 57 councillors; deputy leader Richard Tice denounced “treachery.” Farage has been at a cryptocurrency conference and the Caerphilly Senedd byelection. A school transport appeals committee was canceled for lack of quorum. Kemkaran belatedly declared her husband’s NHS role amid calls for her resignation. Facing a £2.5bn budget, potential 5% tax rise and Whitehall reforms, the authority risks chaos.

articles.title: Lucy Powell wins Labour deputy leadership election
articles.trailText: MP for Manchester Central had been seen as favourite ahead of rival Bridget Phillipson throughout contest
articles.summary: Lucy Powell has been elected Labour deputy leader with 87,407 votes (54%) to Bridget Phillipson’s 73,536 on a 16.6% turnout among members and affiliates, far below the 58.8% in 2020. The contest was triggered by Angela Rayner’s resignation. Seen as a test of Keir Starmer’s direction, Powell—formerly Commons leader—beat the Downing Street–backed education secretary. Both candidates supported scrapping the two-child benefit cap. In her victory speech, Powell called for listening to members, bold Labour values and reclaiming the “political megaphone” from Reform UK. Starmer welcomed her win, warning against dark Tory and Reform politics. Powell will not serve as deputy PM.

articles.title: Rishi Sunak only politician sent witness statement in China spy case
articles.trailText: Statement from security adviser, sent to then prime minister, did not describe China as enemy
articles.summary: Matthew Collins, deputy national security adviser, sent a December 2023 witness statement only to then-PM Rishi Sunak; it omitted calling China an enemy per Conservative policy. The case against Christopher Cash and Christopher Berry collapsed in September after the CPS concluded no evidence China posed a threat under the Official Secrets Act; both men deny wrongdoing. Letters to the national security committee from Collins and NSA Jonathan Powell say no ministers were involved after charges. Labour denies Starmer’s government intervened. DPP Stephen Parkinson says espionage threat threshold rose after a Russia spy trial; AG Richard Hermer had no role beyond a brief update.

articles.title: Local election wipeout would see off Starmer, MPs say after Caerphilly rout
articles.trailText: Crushing defeat in Welsh byelection triggers renewed outpouring of anger and concern within Labour
articles.summary: In Caerphilly’s Senedd by-election, Plaid Cymru’s Lindsay Whittle won with over 47% as Labour collapsed to 11% (−27% swing), relegating Reform UK to second. MPs warn that if next May’s local polls mirror this rout, Keir Starmer’s leadership is untenable, spotlighting Labour’s “incoherent” strategy, vulnerability to Reform on the right and Greens, Lib Dems, SNP or Plaid on the left. Calls grow for a clear vision and possible change at the top. Plaid hails the result as a mandate for new Welsh leadership; Reform views Wales as a two-horse race.

articles.title: When hearts were in the Home Office | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Alice Bacon | BBC Sounds | Reform councillors | Royal Lodge | Investigating Andrew
articles.summary: Letters cover Home Office’s decline: ex-minister Alice Bacon recalled moving out in late 1960s as “like shifting from a Rolls-Royce to a Mini.” Another reader fixes the irritating BBC Sounds jingle by using the 45-minute sleep timer to stop “In Our Time” (50 minutes long). Kent’s Reform councillors were bluntly told to “suck it up” amid suspected typos. Taxpayers face £558,000 to evict Prince Andrew from Royal Lodge or could crowdfund; calls grow for a police investigation. Readers are invited to send letters for publication.

articles.title: Caerphilly byelection a triumph of positivity over division, says Plaid Cymru leader
articles.trailText: Rhun ap Iorwerth says party’s win was more than just rejection of immigration-obsessed Reform or rudderless Labour
articles.summary: Plaid Cymru leader Rhun ap Iorwerth hailed the Caerphilly byelection victory, where candidate Lindsay Whittle secured 47% amid a collapse in Labour support (down 35 points to 11%), as a triumph of positive policy over Reform UK’s immigration-focused agenda. He argued voters prioritized healthcare, housing and childcare proposals—his party’s £30,000-per-child support plan—over populist blame. Ap Iorwerth cited tactical voting but stressed lasting shifts by lifelong Labour supporters, setting Plaid’s sights on building trust across Wales ahead of next May’s Senedd elections and offering a blueprint to counter Reform’s surge.

articles.title: ‘Reform didn’t have any idea about south Wales’: Plaid Cymru supporters celebrate byelection win
articles.trailText: Welsh nationalists secured a hefty 47% of votes in what had been framed as a close two-horse race against Reform
articles.summary: In Caerphilly’s Senedd by-election Plaid Cymru’s Lindsay Whittle won with 47%, trouncing Reform UK (36%) and collapsing Labour to 11%. Despite Nigel Farage’s campaign, Reform failed to connect on local issues, particularly immigration, which residents deem minimal. Supporters hailed Plaid’s Welsh-first stance in a traditional Labour seat, calling the result historic and signaling momentum ahead of next year’s Welsh parliament elections.

articles.title: Plaid Cymru ousts Labour in Caerphilly byelection
articles.trailText: Rhun ap Iorwerth’s party seizes Senedd seat, beating Reform UK into second place
articles.summary: Plaid Cymru seized the Caerphilly Senedd seat from Labour in a landmark byelection, winning 15,961 votes to Reform UK’s 12,113 and Labour’s collapsed 3,713. Leader Rhun ap Iorwerth hailed the result as proof of Welsh appetite for independence and “hope over division”, while Reform touted grassroots gains. Labour figures blamed divisive refugee rhetoric and face difficulty passing next year’s budget with just 29 of 60 seats. Pollster John Curtice sees Plaid poised to lead Wales, but warns Reform remains a force. The outcome transforms Wales into a two-horse race ahead of the 2026 Senedd elections.

articles.title: Plaid Cymru’s victory in Caerphilly points to a new kind of electorate
articles.trailText: The Welsh town’s byelection was a two-party race – but this time neither Labour nor the Conservatives were in it
articles.summary: Plaid Cymru overturned a century of Labour dominance in the Caerphilly Senedd byelection on 24 Oct, winning decisively with a 47.4% vote share against Reform UK’s 36%, as Labour and Conservatives combined secured just 13%. Despite Reform UK launching its 2024 manifesto nearby, voters appear to have tactically supported Plaid to block Reform. The upset underscores growing support for smaller parties, complicates Labour’s prospects under Wales’s new 2026 PR electoral system, and offers a model for anti-Reform tactics ahead of Westminster 2029.

articles.title: Caerphilly result is blow to Labour and Reform – and shows parties who cannot adapt will be crushed
articles.trailText: Plaid Cymru’s byelection victory signals a seismic shift in Welsh politics that will rattle Westminster
articles.summary: Plaid Cymru’s Lindsay Whittle seized the Caerphilly Senedd seat with a 4,000-vote majority in a byelection that saw Labour’s share collapse from 46% in 2021 to 11%, tumbling to third place. Reform UK, tipped as favourite, was beaten thanks to tactical voting and Whittle’s local standing, while the Tories managed just 2%. The result signals a seismic shift in Welsh politics ahead of May’s elections, poses a fresh threat to Keir Starmer, and shows that parties must adapt or risk being crushed.

articles.title: Starmer lays out vision for much-criticised digital ID scheme
articles.trailText: Prime minister says the identification would never be needed to access hospitals amid fears over civil liberties
articles.summary: PM Keir Starmer defended his digital ID scheme amid public backlash, insisting it won’t be needed for hospital access and is optional except to prove the right to work and curb illegal employment. He said IDs would cut “faff,” boost fraud protection and simplify banking, mortgages and public services. Despite over 2.9m petition signatures and net support falling to –14%, opponents—including Labour advisers and Lib Dems—label it intrusive, costly and prone to surveillance. The government plans to offer IDs to all UK citizens and legal residents.

articles.title: Up pops Katie Lam to outdo Robert Jenrick on the nastiness scale | John Crace
articles.trailText: It’s hard to keep up with everyone the Tory MP tipped as a future party leader hates
articles.summary: John Crace skewers rising Tory MP Katie Lam’s zealous anti-immigrant crusade: a former Goldman Sachs analyst and ex-Boris aide now junior whip, Lam champions mass deportations of legal residents she deems ‘culturally incoherent’, from low-paid NHS staff to families with ILR. Crace lampoons her consistency-defying Brexiter zeal, amateur musical writing (a dystopian Sound of Music) and her one-nation rivals, notably Robert Jenrick, now upstaged on the nastiness scale. Underpinning Philp’s draft bill, Lam’s rhetoric promises ICE-style raids, splitting families and targeting anyone seen as ‘foreign’ despite legal status.

articles.title: Conservatives complain to whips about fellow MP’s comments on legally settled people
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Criticism of Katie Lam comes amid widespread confusion in the party over its policy on indefinite leave to remain
articles.summary: Conservative MPs have complained to party whips after junior shadow minister Katie Lam told the Sunday Times that many legally settled migrants should ‘go home’ to keep the UK ‘culturally coherent’. Colleagues warned her language risked bigotry, sparked alarm over unclear indefinite leave to remain (ILR) plans and internal confusion about proposals to strip ILR from benefit claimants or low earners. Labour leader Keir Starmer condemned Lam and Tory policy, while senior ministers including James Cleverly and Kemi Badenoch grappled with mixed messages over oversight and retrospective ILR revocation.

articles.title: Frontrunner suffers blow in race to be UK ambassador to US over criticisms of Trump
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Whitehall officials raise fears about Mark Sedwill’s newspaper article warning of president’s ‘blundering’ behaviour
articles.summary: Mark Sedwill’s bid to succeed Peter Mandelson as UK ambassador in Washington has stalled after Whitehall officials flagged his 2021 Daily Mail article praising Joe Biden and sharply criticising Donald Trump’s ‘blundering’ Brexit advice and his role in the January 6 Capitol attack. Though US diplomats have raised no objections, British aides fear the piece could provoke a volatile White House. Sedwill, a crossbench peer and former national security adviser, has not ruled out applying. Other candidates include Varun Chandra, Clive Alderton, Christian Turner, Antonia Romeo and Ed Llewellyn.

articles.title: Reform’s only Black branch chair quits over ‘harmful’ migration debate
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Neville Watson leaves amid concerns about weaponisation of religion and erosion of community relations
articles.summary: Neville Watson, Reform UK’s only Black branch chair and former Enfield leader, has quit the right-wing populist party, condemning the harmful tone of Britain’s migration debate, rising Islamophobia and the weaponisation of Christian nationalism among some members. The son of Windrush-generation parents and a social enterprise professional, Watson had helped recruit diverse communities but grew alarmed by sympathy for far-right activist Tommy Robinson and anti-migrant rhetoric. Citing his evangelical faith and belief in managed migration, he has joined the Christian People’s Alliance, warning that politics is losing compassion.

articles.title: Jess Phillips has ‘full backing’ of PM over grooming gangs inquiry, says minister
articles.trailText: Children’s minister, Josh MacAlister, insists Phillips will remain safeguarding minister as four abuse survivors call for her resignation
articles.summary: Children’s minister Josh MacAlister insisted on Thursday that safeguarding minister Jess Phillips retains PM and home secretary’s full backing, after four abuse survivors on the grooming-gangs inquiry advisory panel demanded her resignation as a condition of participation. Survivors accuse ministers of sidelining victim testimony and broadening the inquiry’s scope to deflect questions about the ethnicity of predominantly Pakistani perpetrators. Both proposed chairs, Annie Hudson and ex-police officer Jim Gamble, have withdrawn amid a “toxic environment.” Labour leader Keir Starmer has appointed Louise Casey to support the inquiry and reaffirm its laser-focused remit.

articles.title: Shabana Mahmood says damning report shows Home Office ‘not fit for purpose’
articles.trailText: Home secretary vows overhaul after previously secret 2023 review lists series of perceived shortcomings
articles.summary: Shabana Mahmood, appointed Home Secretary in September 2025, vows to overhaul the Home Office after the Times forced release of a secret 2023 report by ex-adviser Nick Timothy. It documents a culture of defeatism on immigration, defensive legal teams, conflicting systems and hours wasted on identity-politics listening circles. Other departments distrust the Home Office after the Windrush scandal. The review cites failings leading to the Manston asylum centre crisis—18,000 unlawfully detained in overcrowded conditions and disease outbreaks—plus missed mental-health checks before an asylum seeker’s death on the Bibby Stockholm. Mahmood calls the department "not fit for purpose."

articles.title: Police take no further action against men arrested for Trump Windsor projections
articles.trailText: Investigation ends after Led By Donkeys stunt highlighting the US president’s relationship with Jeffrey Epstein
articles.summary: Thames Valley police announced no further action against four men arrested after political campaign group Led By Donkeys projected images of Donald Trump, convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, victims’ photos and an alleged Trump letter onto Windsor Castle during the US president’s second state visit on 16 September. Initially held on suspicion of malicious communications and public nuisance, the men were released without charge. Led By Donkeys branded the arrests ‘political policing’ and urged authorities to probe Prince Andrew. The White House denies the letter’s authenticity.

articles.title: Keir Starmer prepares to miss key green target in effort to keep energy bills down
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Promise to remove almost all fossil fuels from UK’s electricity supply by 2030 may be quietly abandoned over cost
articles.summary: Ministers plan to abandon the 2030 zero-fossil-fuel electricity target to curb rising bills, sources say. Energy Secretary Ed Miliband may commission far fewer renewables than the record 8 GW experts deem necessary, preferring cheaper gas-fired capacity. Downing Street fears cost-of-living pressures empowering Reform UK. Though Keir Starmer resists publicly dropping the pledge, insiders expect it will quietly be missed. Analysts warn this undermines investor confidence, while Greenpeace and experts argue forsaking the target jeopardises climate leadership and long-term bill reductions.

articles.title: Attacks on UK cabinet secretary ‘stink of political cowardice’, union leader says
articles.trailText: Civil service union head decries anonymous criticism as insiders continue to bemoan Chris Wormald’s appointment
articles.summary: FDA general secretary Dave Penman has denounced anonymous attacks on Chris Wormald, Keir Starmer’s December appointment as cabinet secretary, as ‘political cowardice’ that deters talent and damages government credibility. Insiders in No 10 and the civil service privately criticize Wormald as ‘insipid’ and doubt his delivery, with reports suggesting he may be replaced by January. Despite Downing Street affirming Starmer’s support, senior ministers quietly fault Wormald’s low-energy style and argue stronger candidates like Olly Robbins were overlooked.
