articles.title: Rayner’s return gives a lift to Labour’s gloomy backbenchers
articles.trailText: Former deputy PM’s resignation statement offered a moment to reflect on what the party had lost – and might have again
articles.summary: Angela Rayner’s first Commons appearance since her September resignation drew packed Labour benches, offering MPs a morale boost amid party gloom after a narrow election. Her measured resignation statement emphasised socialist values, pride in her record on housing, workers’ rights and the Hillsborough law, and acknowledged her HMRC tax‐form error without full apology. Rayner’s authentic, emotive style contrasted with Keir Starmer’s technocratic reticence, reigniting backbench hope and underlining Labour’s tight three-and-a-half-year deadline to revitalise policies for working people. At PMQs, Kemi Badenoch’s angry challenge over the grooming gangs inquiry faltered against Starmer’s legalistic assurances and promises for Louise Casey, as Nigel Farage looked on from the gallery.

articles.title: Deporting legally settled people is ‘broadly in line’ with Tory policy, says Badenoch’s office
articles.trailText: Conservative leader’s spokesperson sets out plan to strip the right of indefinite leave to remain from people claiming benefits
articles.summary: Kemi Badenoch’s office endorsed proposals to retrospectively strip indefinite leave to remain (ILR) from legally settled migrants who claim benefits, fall below £38,700 income for six months, or aren’t ‘net contributors’, while exempting state pensioners. The spokesperson said this aligns with Katie Lam’s call to deport large numbers to maintain ‘cultural coherence’, though details on statutory maternity pay, shared parental leave, or ties to UK spouses remain unclear. Labour’s Anna Turley condemned the plan as ‘grotesque’, warning it would tear families apart. Tories insist policy will be carefully drafted to avoid unfairness.

articles.title: Chancellor hoping shift in tone on Brexit will ring true for key groups of voters
articles.trailText: Rachel Reeves’ criticism of Brexit impact on economy is aimed at leave voters who have changed their minds and younger voters, says analysts
articles.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves has blamed Brexit for the UK’s weak economy ahead of a challenging budget, aiming to sway former leave voters who now regret the decision, enfranchised younger electors and remainers aware of Brexit’s economic costs. Despite criticism by Brexit supporters accusing her of scapegoating, polls show rising dissatisfaction with Brexit’s fallout. Political analysts argue this shift in tone may help Labour retain voters flirting with the Lib Dems or Greens, but risks alienating leave backers and pro-EU advocates expecting a reversal. YouGov polls indicate a majority view Brexit as a failure.

articles.title: Caerphilly byelection could signal ‘fundamental realignment’ of Welsh politics
articles.trailText: If Labour loses the Senedd seat, it will be a huge blow for party that has dominated politics in Wales for a century
articles.summary: Labour faces a potential third-place finish in the Caerphilly Senedd by-election following Hefin David’s death, with Reform UK leading on immigration (42%) and Plaid Cymru close behind (38%). Plaid’s Lindsay Whittle capitalises on disenchanted Labour support while Labour’s Richard Tunnicliffe focuses on local services. A loss would force fragile budget deals in the Senedd and underline Welsh Labour’s internal civil war. Experts warn this could end a century-long Labour hegemony and reshape UK politics ahead of 2026 elections.

articles.title: Scotland demands £24.5m from Westminster for Trump and Vance visits
articles.trailText: Treasury says trips were private while Scottish ministers point out US president met Keir Starmer and it had to stump up for extra policing
articles.summary: Scotland’s government demands Westminster reimburse £24.5m spent policing Donald Trump’s five-day July visit to Turnberry and Menie (c.£21m) and JD Vance’s four-day August Ayrshire trip (£3m), arguing these high-profile meetings—Trump’s talks with Keir Starmer and Ursula von der Leyen—were official work visits, not private holidays. Finance secretary Shona Robison’s letter to Treasury chief James Murray cites the largest policing operation since Queen Elizabeth II’s death and precedent from Trump’s 2018 trip. The UK government insists visits were private under devolved funding rules.

articles.title: Lucy Powell urged ministers to rethink legal action against Labour donor’s firm
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Intervention by deputy leadership contender could have saved company based in her Manchester constituency millions
articles.summary: Lucy Powell, Labour’s deputy leadership frontrunner and MP for Manchester Central, intervened with then-housing secretary Angela Rayner to urge negotiation instead of legal action against Urban Splash—a property firm founded by Labour donor Tom Bloxham. In letters between December 2024 and August 2025, Powell warned that forcing Urban Splash to repay £49 m in post-Grenfell remediation costs would bankrupt the company and waste taxpayer funds. She insists all representations were made transparently in her capacity as a constituency MP. Bloxham, who donated to Labour, accused officials of a “vindictive” campaign; ministers say they remain committed to holding developers accountable.

articles.title: Why is there a national inquiry into grooming gangs and how is it going?
articles.trailText: Survivors of grooming gangs said a previous inquiry did not go far enough but there are tensions over new one
articles.summary: Following disclosures of street-based grooming rings—mainly involving Asian and Pakistani-origin men who preyed on vulnerable girls in the 1990s and 2000s—Labour leader Keir Starmer announced in June a national inquiry after survivors criticized the 2015–22 Jay report for ignoring cultural drivers. Despite Louise Casey’s audit calling for a new probe, recruitment has stalled: three survivors quit the liaison panel, chair candidate Annie Hudson withdrew, and debates rage over remit scope. Former deputy constable Jim Gamble is now considered. Some MPs demand safeguarding minister Jess Phillips resign, but she insists the inquiry will stay laser-focused on grooming gangs.

articles.title: How Rachel Reeves could balance Britain’s books and lower inequality | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Caitlin Boswell lays out measures that would make taxation fairer and improve lives. Plus letters from Rachel Sharp , Dr Tim Owen and Paul McGilchrist
articles.summary: Caitlin Boswell (Tax Justice UK) urges chancellor Rachel Reeves to fund public services and reduce inequality by equalising capital gains and income tax rates, applying national insurance to investment income, ending oil, gas and private equity tax breaks, and beefing up HMRC. She estimates CGT and NI reforms plus closing loopholes could raise £30bn to invest and rebuild trust in politics. Additionally, a 2% wealth tax on assets over £10m could yield £20bn annually for childcare and high streets. Letters from Rachel Sharp recall post-war high rates, Tim Owen critiques “broad shoulders” rhetoric, and Paul McGilchrist demands honest tax metaphors.

articles.title: Will no one think about poor Boris? Former PM smirks and sighs through Covid inquiry | John Crace
articles.trailText: Grilled over policies regarding children and young people, Johnson remains the wrong man in the wrong place at the wrong time
articles.summary: At the Covid Inquiry’s children and young people module, ex-PM Boris Johnson appeared unshaven, smirking and bored, deflecting scrutiny over lack of pandemic school‐closure planning. He insisted a three‐page memo sufficed, blamed education secretary Gavin Williamson for misremembering, and cast his missteps—from faulty exam algorithms to the ‘Eat Out to Help Out’ scheme—as unlucky real‐time calls. Johnson described his decisions as unavoidable, dismissed children’s sacrifices, and portrayed recovery efforts as tokenistic, remaining evasive and reluctant to accept responsibility for government failings.

articles.title: Reeves says economic damage caused by Brexit forcing her to take action in budget
articles.trailText: Chancellor, who is expected to announce tax rises and spending cuts, says effect of leaving bloc worse than predicted
articles.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves says unexpected economic damage from Brexit and past austerity has worsened growth prospects, forcing tax rises and spending cuts in her 26 November budget. Braced for a sharp OBR downgrade, she will protect capital investment and infrastructure, slash planning red tape and rebuild EU ties to lower business costs. Reeves is pressing all departments to help tame 4% inflation, warns against a market backlash like 2022’s mini-budget and plans a £2 billion LLP national insurance rise to plug a £40 billion finances gap while maintaining a fiscal buffer for shocks.

articles.title: Rachel Reeves set to launch ‘blitz on business bureaucracy’ to save firms £6bn
articles.trailText: Chancellor to tell business leaders at government’s first regional investment summit she plans to ‘cut pointless admin’
articles.summary: At Birmingham’s first regional investment summit, Chancellor Rachel Reeves unveiled a ‘blitz on business bureaucracy’, pledging to cut redundant admin measures—such as scrapping small-firm directors’ report filings—to save companies £6bn annually by Parliament’s end. Part of Labour’s push to reboot productivity, the reforms target 100,000 microbreweries, cafes and other SMEs. Facing pressure over a tax-raising budget on 26 November, Reeves signalled new levies would fall on those with ‘broadest shoulders’ alongside spending cuts. The package also includes millions in regional projects and £10bn of private sector commitments.

articles.title: China spy case gives MPs the opportunity to discuss their favourite topic: themselves | John Crace
articles.trailText: Seemingly what elevates this case to a matter of national security is that two Tory MPs were allegedly spied on
articles.summary: John Crace skewers MPs’ reflexive self-importance over the collapse of a Chinese spy trial that saw two Tory parliamentarians alleged to have been spied on for trivial leaks. He lampoons successive urgent questions as Tories frantically accuse Keir Starmer of influencing the CPS—first for leaning on the DPP then for failing to intervene—and mocks Chris Philp’s conspiracy fantasies. He notes exasperated security minister Dan Jarvis defending the government’s China stance, and the day ends with a rancorous debate over banning Maccabi Tel Aviv fans on alleged antisemitism grounds.

articles.title: Tory MP criticised after demanding legally settled families be deported
articles.trailText: Katie Lam said move would make UK ‘culturally coherent’ and that a large number of people ‘need to go home’
articles.summary: Conservative MP Katie Lam, a Home Office shadow minister and former Boris Johnson adviser, has been condemned after telling the Sunday Times that large numbers of legally settled families should have their right to stay revoked to keep the UK ‘mostly culturally coherent’. Lib Dem leader Ed Davey, in a letter to Tory leader Kemi Badenoch, labelled the proposal ‘deeply concerning and unpatriotic’, demanding the party clarify its immigration stance, including what constitutes a ‘culturally coherent’ population. Reform UK wants to scrap ILR in favor of five-year high-earner visas; Labour would restrict ILR to those with 10 years’ residence and proven community contributions.

articles.title: Reform suspends four Kent councillors after Guardian publishes leaked video of fierce infighting
articles.trailText: Members of Reform’s showcase county council will be investigated after ‘evidence that they brought the party into disrepute’
articles.summary: Reform UK has suspended Kent county councillors Paul Thomas, Oliver Bradshaw, Bill Barrett and Maxine Fothergill pending an inquiry after a Guardian-published leaked video exposed bitter infighting and leader Linden Kemkaran telling dissenters to “suck it up.” The whip-loss cuts Reform’s seats from 57 to 50 and forced cancellation of a school transport committee. Lib Dem, Labour and Tory MPs decry the chaos, failed “Doge” cost-cutting plan and potential council-tax hikes. A no-confidence motion against Kemkaran is being readied as the party hunts the leaker.

articles.title: Labour should return to its social-democrat principles | Letter
articles.trailText: Letters: The party must reconnect with its ideology of solidarity and compassion, and not be a bleak copy of Reform UK, says Dr Wouter Servaas
articles.summary: Dr Wouter Servaas warns that the UK Labour party, by emulating Reform UK and Conservatives on Brexit, protest bans, and rolling back green investments, risks losing its social-democratic identity. He points to the 2023 Dutch alliance between GroenLinks and PvdA – a centre-left merger focused on housing, cost-of-living relief, and green economy investment – as a model. Labour must revive solidarity and compassion or cede voters to the Greens, who aim to fill the ideological void. Servaas challenges Keir Starmer to reaffirm Labour’s left-wing heart.

articles.title: Keir Starmer will attend Cop30 in Brazil, No 10 confirms
articles.trailText: After speculation and conflicting pressures, prime minister will attend climate summit next month
articles.summary: Prime Minister Keir Starmer will travel to Belém, Brazil, for next month’s UN climate summit, Cop30—the biggest since Paris 2015—Downing Street has confirmed after weeks of speculation. Despite some aides urging him to skip amid concerns over rising energy bills and Reform UK opposition, Starmer says net zero offers a 21st-century economic boost to industrial heartlands, good jobs and lower bills. Labour has reversed an onshore wind ban and launched a clean-energy investment body, while Greens and MPs have pressed for his presence to bolster UK climate leadership.

articles.title: Labour deputy leadership contest may only cause more trouble for Starmer
articles.trailText: Victory for Lucy Powell or Bridget Phillipson, the rivals at the centre of the race, could be reckoning for the party
articles.summary: Labour’s deputy leadership contest sees former Commons leader Lucy Powell and education secretary Bridget Phillipson vying to succeed Angela Rayner, exposing rifts in Keir Starmer’s party. Powell leads in polls and champions unity, opposition to the two-child benefit cap, and a tougher line on Nigel Farage, but is distrusted by some in No 10 after welfare-vote leaks. Phillipson, backed by major unions and focused on child poverty and workers’ rights, warns a Powell win risks deeper factional division and low member engagement could undermine post-vote cohesion.

articles.title: Reform UK reviews if it underpaid VAT on tickets and merchandise
articles.trailText: Nigel Farage’s party reported to have exceeded £90,000 threshold due to ticket sales for Birmingham conference
articles.summary: Reform UK, Nigel Farage’s party and current poll leader, has launched a review into whether it underpaid VAT on ticket and merchandise revenues after exceeding HMRC’s £90k threshold, following a Times probe. Filings show £438k+ from merchandise/events last year, mainly boosted by its Birmingham conference. Reform didn’t charge VAT until April, citing political-party exemptions, then added VAT post-inquiry. The party, engaging specialist VAT advisers, says it will settle any liabilities with HMRC promptly. No evidence of deliberate evasion.

articles.title: Keir Starmer pressed not to slash UK contribution to global aid fund
articles.trailText: Polling finds majority consider £1bn funding for Aids, TB and malaria vaccines a UK success story
articles.summary: Prime Minister Keir Starmer faces growing calls to keep the UK’s £1 billion annual contribution to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, TB and malaria, after polling shows 62% of Britons want funding maintained or increased. With rumours of a 20% cut following a 40% aid‐budget reduction, and the UK co‐chairing the fund’s $18 billion replenishment summit in November alongside the G20 in South Africa, a decision is expected before the budget. Since 2002 the Fund has saved 70 million lives; maintaining £1 billion could save 1.7 million more, while Germany’s €1 billion pledge heightens pressure and aid chiefs warn any cut risks hundreds of thousands of lives.

articles.title: Reform council leader says she has launched hunt for ‘cowards’ behind leaked video
articles.trailText: Linden Kemkaran told fellow Kent councillors those who disagreed with decisions would have to ‘suck it up’
articles.summary: In a leaked video of an August internal meeting, Reform UK’s Kent council leader Linden Kemkaran denounces those who shared the recording as “cowards,” launches a head-office probe and vows to expel leakers. The footage exposes infighting—Kemkaran swears at dissenters, threatens to mute critics and warns that failure to balance the £2.5 bn budget and dodge a full 5% council tax rise will sink Reform’s election prospects. She also clashes over gender slurs and local government reform plans as divisions surface.

articles.title: Environment groups are anything but ‘mute’ on the planning bill | Letters
articles.trailText: Letter: Craig Bennett , Hilary McGrady , Dr James Robinson and Richard Benwell say they have never stopped campaigning on the planning and infrastructure bill’s flaws
articles.summary: Senior figures from The Wildlife Trusts, National Trust, RSPB and Wildlife and Countryside Link reject George Monbiot’s claim that NGOs have stayed silent on the planning and infrastructure bill. They detail hundreds of briefings, evidence submissions and public calls exposing harmful Part 3 proposals, plus a grassroots campaign generating over 100,000 emails, letters and postcards to MPs. Their coordinated push secured a package of government amendments—praised by the Office for Environmental Protection—and they vow to continue challenging threats to nature, including any future planning legislation.

articles.title: Support for Reform UK increasing among British Indians, poll shows
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Survey finds 13% of British Indians back Nigel Farage’s party compared with only 4% at last election
articles.summary: Poll by the 1928 Institute finds British Indian support for Reform UK jumped from 4% at last election to 13%, though still below the national average. Surveying over 2,000 voters, it shows Labour backing fell from 48% to 35%, Conservatives from 21% to 18%, and Greens up from 8% to 13%. The shift, driven by social conservatism, Hindu nationalism and changing priorities—economy now second after education, crime third—suggests traditional voting patterns in this 3% swing-voter community are eroding and parties must engage more directly.

articles.title: Tory MP reports ‘AI-generated deepfake’ video announcing his defection to Reform UK
articles.trailText: Mid Norfolk MP George Freeman calls spread of AI-generated misinformation a ‘dangerous development’
articles.summary: Mid Norfolk Conservative MP George Freeman reported an AI-generated deepfake video claiming he defected to Nigel Farage’s Reform UK, denouncing it on Facebook as a 'dangerous' misuse of his image and voice. The clip, widely circulated online, falsely showed him declaring that 'time for half measures is over' and accusing the Tory party of losing its way. Freeman, who has held ministerial roles since being elected in 2010, insisted he had no intention of switching parties, has alerted police, and warned against sharing such political disinformation, highlighting its threat to democracy.

articles.title: ‘Suck it up’: leaked video exposes bitter infighting at Reform UK’s flagship Kent council
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Footage reveals Kent leader berating councillors amid rows over budgets and bullying claims
articles.summary: Leaked footage of a late-August Kent county council meeting shows Reform UK leader Linden Kemkaran berating councillors—telling dissenters to “fucking suck it up,” threatening to mute speakers—and warning that failure to balance the £2.5 billion budget, including avoiding a full 5 per cent council tax hike, would cost Reform the next general election. The recording exposes deep infighting, backbiting and eight recent bullying complaints as members clash over budget, local government reform (LGR) plans and mentoring schemes. With party defections, suspensions and opposition MPs labelling the council “chaotic,” Reform defends tens of millions in savings and its governance record.

articles.title: ‘Super Dom’ Cummings cunningly waits five years to reveal national security lapses | John Crace
articles.trailText: Only a genius like Boris Johnson’s former right-hand man would have had the wisdom to keep stumm until now
articles.summary: Dominic Cummings, former chief aide to Boris Johnson, reveals via a Times interview and Robert Peston podcast that since early 2020 British intelligence networks ran on Chinese-owned Global Switch, potentially exposing top-secret communications. He criticises Johnson’s apathy—epitomised by late-night cheese sandwiches—and accuses successive leaders, including Liz Truss, Rishi Sunak and Keir Starmer, of failing to act. Observers note the irony given Cummings’s own history of real-time leaks and question why he waited five years to expose these lapses in national security.

articles.title: Revealed: UK Foreign Office staff pushed for Israel trip despite suspension of trade talks
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Peer met Israeli officials and business leaders on visit that had no support from ministers
articles.summary: Internal documents reveal the UK Foreign Office urged then-foreign secretary David Lammy to endorse trade envoy Lord Ian Austin’s late-May visit to Israel, days after Lammy suspended free-trade talks and rebuked Jerusalem. Bureaucratic dysfunction saw the unapproved mission proceed, with Austin meeting senior Israeli trade officials and Rafael arms executives behind Iron Dome and Spike missiles. Emails show officials urged the trip to calm Israeli business, contradicting ministerial directives and sparking concerns over UK-Israel defence ties.

articles.title: Chancellor says she ‘can’t leave welfare untouched’ this parliament as budget looms
articles.trailText: Rachel Reeves understood to be eyeing cuts to Motability scheme as she tries to plug hole in country’s finances
articles.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves warns she “can’t leave welfare untouched” ahead of her 26 November budget, with the Treasury mulling up to £1 bn of tax breaks for the Motability car scheme. Options include removing VAT and insurance exemptions or excluding luxury brands such as BMW and Mercedes, potentially raising £1.2 bn. She’s also pressing ahead with cuts to the health component of universal credit from April 2026. Disability charities and Labour MPs warn of extra burdens on claimants. Reeves must fill a £10–20 bn OBR downgrade with spending cuts and tax rises while shoring up fiscal rules.

articles.title: Your Party sets out constitution plans including new year leadership contest
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Proposals will bring ‘democratic revolution’ and transform ‘post-Labour left’ into formal political force, say organisers
articles.summary: Your Party, led by Jeremy Corbyn and Zarah Sultana, has unveiled draft constitutional proposals to formalise Britain’s ‘post-Labour left’ as a party. Key measures include a leadership or co-leadership election by one-member-one-vote by March 2026, a 21-member central executive committee (16 elected members, two MPs, chair term capped at 21 months), digital democracy edits, sortition-chosen delegates at a Liverpool founding conference on 29–30 November, recall clauses for officers, and strict democratic candidate selection rules. If approved, the blueprint transforms a loose alliance into a structured organisation accountable to ordinary members. Corbyn and Sultana face no guarantee of roles.

articles.title: Mark Sedwill is frontrunner to become new UK ambassador to US, sources say
articles.trailText: Former cabinet secretary seen as favourite despite running risk of angering No 10 with China spy trial comments
articles.summary: Former cabinet secretary Mark Sedwill is the leading candidate to succeed Peter Mandelson as UK ambassador to the US, senior government figures say. Downing Street is seeking a career civil servant after Mandelson’s exit over Epstein links, and insiders believe Sedwill—despite not applying and having sparked Whitehall controversy with his comments on a collapsed China spy trial—would bring the 'edge' needed in Trump’s Washington. Other contenders include trade adviser Varun Chandra, Clive Alderton, Christian Turner, and ex-UN envoy Barbara Woodward, though political figures like George Osborne and David Miliband are deemed unlikely.

articles.title: Nearly 2,000 Foreign Office jobs ‘at risk’, says PCS union
articles.trailText: Reduction in higher-level roles linked to government decision to cut foreign aid budget, says union
articles.summary: PCS, the biggest government workers union, warns 1,885 delegated-grade posts at the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office face redundancy, alongside senior civil servant notices. It links cuts to recent foreign aid budget reductions and criticizes the FCDO for skipping the mandated redundancy mitigation review and voluntary redundancy window. The union pledges to resist up to 30% job losses, arguing expertise will be lost. FCDO says the headcount reduction is part of a five-year reform to create a leaner, more agile, tech-enabled department.

articles.title: Three neo-Nazis jailed for plotting terror attacks on UK mosques and synagogues
articles.trailText: Group of ‘like-minded extremists’ styled themselves after the SS and amassed arsenal of more than 200 weapons
articles.summary: Three UK-based neo-Nazis—Christopher Ringrose (35), Marco Pitzettu (26) and Brogan Stewart (25)—were jailed for 8–11 years for plotting terror attacks on mosques, Islamic centres and synagogues in England. The trio formed an online cell called “Einsatz 14”, idolised the SS, amassed over 200 weapons (including machetes, crossbows, body armour, a stun gun and a partly 3D-printed firearm) and mapped abductions, torture and escape routes. An undercover officer infiltrated the group; a jury found their threats real. Stewart received 11 years, Ringrose 10 and Pitzettu 8.

articles.title: Ministers plan high-level visits to China despite espionage trial outcry
articles.trailText: National security adviser, education secretary and science minister to visit before end of year as part of policy to reset relations
articles.summary: Despite fallout from the collapsed espionage trial of two men accused of spying for Beijing, UK ministers plan high-level visits to China before year-end as part of a strategic reset. National security adviser Jonathan Powell is slated for November talks in Beijing, with Keir Starmer’s anticipated trip next year. Education secretary Bridget Phillipson and science minister Patrick Vallance will also travel. The decision comes amid criticism over dropped CPS charges, allegations of political interference and security concerns, yet the government stresses robust, long-term engagement across political, educational and scientific sectors.

articles.title: China spying case: dream job turns into nightmare for DPP Stephen Parkinson
articles.trailText: Having long desired to lead the CPS, Parkinson now finds himself at the heart of a political row over the collapsed case
articles.summary: Director of Public Prosecutions Stephen Parkinson, once eyeing the CPS top post since his pupillage, faces scrutiny after dropping a China spying trial for lack of a government statement deeming China a current UK national security threat. His explanation is challenged by senior lawyers and politicians, raising doubts about his tenure under PM Keir Starmer. A former barrister and the first solicitor DPP since the 1960s, Parkinson built his career in Blair’s administration and at Kingsley Napley. Known for independence and criticism of Starmer’s CPS record, Parkinson’s five-year term now resembles a political minefield.

articles.title: Farage urged to explain anti-abortion links to meeting with Trump officials
articles.trailText: Lib Dems accuse Reform leader of wanting to water down women’s rights after reports of help from advocacy group
articles.summary: Nigel Farage faced calls from the Liberal Democrats to clarify why the US anti-abortion group Alliance Defending Freedom (ADF) brokered his March meeting in London with Trump administration diplomats, reportedly discussing abortion rights, free speech and online safety laws. Lib Dem deputy leader Daisy Cooper accused him of colluding with Trump officials to weaken UK women’s rights and urged the government to demand answers. Farage denied ADF’s involvement, insisting abortion is “No 468” on Reform UK’s agenda and highlighting 22-week viability inconsistencies. ADF and the US embassy also refuted claims of partisan interference, while US VP JD Vance criticised UK abortion buffer zone prosecutions.

articles.title: Why MPs prefer conspiracy theory over cock-up in China spy case row | John Crace
articles.trailText: The facts had changed so MPs simply amended their conspiracy theories to fit the new evidence
articles.summary: John Crace dissects MPs’ persistent turn to conspiracy in the China spy case after Keir Starmer’s late-night release of DNSA Matthew Collins’s witness statements. Tory and opposition figures first accused the PM of coercion, then, when evidence disproved interference, pivoted to charge him with treachery through inaction. Junior minister Chris Ward, making his Commons debut, could only assert non-interference and defer to the CPS on dropped charges. Across party lines MPs demanded fabricated or extra evidence, ignoring procedural shortcomings. Crace highlights Westminster’s preference for sensational narrative shifts over acknowledging a bureaucratic cock-up, underlining politics as performance rather than fact-based oversight.

articles.title: Labour begins charm offensive to win over MPs sceptical of digital ID plans
articles.trailText: Party tries to reassure its MPs about proposed scheme and gather ideas on how it could improve public services
articles.summary: Ministers, led by Ian Murray, hosted roundtables with 50 Labour MPs to win support for a federated public-sector digital ID system. Initially for right-to-work checks before the next election, plans envisage expanding to health and benefits data to streamline services and tackle fraud. Ministers insist it will be built in-house; MPs pressed for cost estimates—BritCard’s £150m estimate deemed laughably low—and raised security concerns. While red wall MPs back it, critics warn of data leaks. Campaign by Amy Richards aims to rebuild trust and inform consultation.

articles.title: Rachel Reeves says those with broadest shoulders should pay fair share of tax
articles.trailText: Chancellor adds she wants to ‘get the balance right’ and not deter wealthy people from making the UK their home
articles.summary: Speaking at the IMF in Washington DC, Chancellor Rachel Reeves said those with “broadest shoulders” must pay their fair share of tax as she prepares her 26 November budget. She signalled targeted tax hikes and spending cuts to rein in Britain’s above-target inflation—focusing on administered prices like prescription fees and school VAT—while avoiding measures that deter wealthy residents. Reeves ruled out a new wealth tax, citing last year’s non-dom, private-jet and school-fee VAT changes, and floated trimming OBR forecast checks. She’s also negotiating pharma investment for favourable drug pricing and US tariff relief.

articles.title: Labour ministers met fossil fuel lobbyists 500 times in first year of power, analysis shows
articles.trailText: Lobbyists attended 48% more meetings than Tories, as Labour accused of giving them ‘backstage pass’
articles.summary: Government ministers met fossil fuel lobbyists over 500 times in Labour’s first year—twice daily on average—48% more than under the Tories in 2023. DESNZ ministers held 274 such meetings, Ed Miliband met lobbyists in a third of his 91 gatherings, and BP, Shell and Equinor attended 100 combined. Critics from Fossil Free Parliament and the Green party warn of undue influence on energy transition and bills tax. Fossil fuel lobbyists even attended nearly every meeting on the North Sea energy profits levy. Government says talks covered clean energy investment and job protection.

articles.title: Reform UK accused of sowing division in Wales in rowdy TV byelection debate
articles.trailText: Party leading latest opinion poll comes under fire for ‘weaponising’ immigration as candidates in Caerphilly clash
articles.summary: In Caerphilly’s Senedd byelection, Reform UK surged to 42% in a Survation poll, outpacing Plaid Cymru (38%), Labour (12%) and Tories (4%). During a rowdy BBC Wales debate, Reform’s Llŷr Powell was accused of “weaponising” immigration rhetoric, prompting an audience member—whose family includes UK-born immigrants—to say she felt unwelcome. Powell defended his stance by dismissing the 2.9% foreign-born census figure as outdated due to a “Boris wave,” and urged tighter migration control. Labour’s Richard Tunnicliffe said Reform sought to sow division, while Plaid’s Lindsay Whittle defended Wales’s sanctuary policy, warning of fears among Ukrainian refugees. With Labour’s century-long Caerphilly hold at risk, a political realignment looms.

articles.title: Drag acts, detractors and true-blue diehards: my weird weekend at a Margaret Thatcher festival
articles.trailText: For some, she was a hero. For others, quite the opposite. On 13 October, the prime minister who looms large over British politics would have turned 100 – and a gathering in Grantham celebrated her days in power
articles.summary: At a Grantham festival marking what would have been Margaret Thatcher’s 100th birthday, locals gathered around a contentious bronze statue and a riotous drag show, Margaret Thatcher: Queen of Soho, in which performer Matt Tedford reimagines the former PM as a disco diva on the eve of the 1987 Section 28 vote. The centenary programme featured talks by figures like Edwina Currie, walking tours, memorabilia exhibitions and provocations that drew both diehard Tory supporters and progressive audiences. Organisers trumpeted the publicity from upsetting both left and right. The weekend highlighted the ongoing reassessment of Thatcher’s small-state legacy amid rising far-right nationalism and generational disconnect over her economic and social impact.

articles.title: Proposed UK cuts to global aid fund could lead to 300,000 preventable deaths, say charities
articles.trailText: Exclusive: 20% reduction in contribution to Aids, TB and malaria funding expected to be announced next month
articles.summary: UK ministers plan to cut their contribution to the Global Fund to Fight Aids, Tuberculosis and Malaria by 20%—from £1 bn to £800 m—ahead of next month’s G20 summit in South Africa. Charities warn this could reverse progress made after a previous 30% UK cut and US aid reductions, potentially causing over 300,000 preventable deaths and millions of infections. Aid groups including Malaria No More UK, StopAids and One say the move undermines UK leadership, soft power and global health security. The Foreign Office says no final pledge has been made.

articles.title: Ministry of Justice ‘has failed to file spending receipts of nearly £11bn’
articles.trailText: Analyst firm Tussell says department is more than two years behind on publishing receipts, weakening scrutiny around public money
articles.summary: Tussell reports the Ministry of Justice, overseeing a £13bn prisons, probation and courts budget, has a 26-month delay publishing supplier receipts, totalling £10.8bn—far beyond the two-month industry norm. This makes the MoJ the worst in transparency; by contrast DESNZ lags 13 months (£3.7bn) and DSIT 10 months (£880m). Unlock Democracy warns such gaps weaken scrutiny. The MoJ maintains all spending is in annual accounts and cites security checks. After a 1.8% real-terms increase, day-to-day budgets reach £13.2bn by 2028-29 and capital £2.3bn, funding 14,000 prison places by 2031.

articles.title: No 10 moves to end China spy row – but threat of further fallout lingers
articles.trailText: Questions remain over trial collapse even as publication of key evidence scuppers Tory’s main line of attack
articles.summary: After the Crown Prosecution Service unexpectedly dropped the trial of two British nationals accused of spying for China, Downing Street published three witness statements from deputy national security adviser Matthew Collins. Dating from December 2023 to August 2024, they depict China as an 'epoch-defining challenge' yet signal Labour’s 'three Cs' stance—cooperation, competition and challenge on security. Tories accuse the government of secretly sabotaging the prosecution by refusing to call China an 'enemy', but ministers argue key evidence was compiled under the Conservatives. DPP Stephen Parkinson cited a 5% evidential shortfall under the Official Secrets Act. With both sides disputing motives and political direction, legal and domestic fallout may deepen.

articles.title: Questions for CPS after No 10 publishes key witness statements in China spy row
articles.trailText: Keir Starmer releases documents submitted by deputy national security adviser to Crown Prosecution Service
articles.summary: After prosecutors dropped charges against ex-researcher Christopher Cash and teacher Christopher Berry due to insufficient evidence confirming Beijing’s threat to UK security, Labour leader Keir Starmer released three witness statements by deputy national security adviser Matthew Collins. The August statement warns of “large-scale espionage operations” by China harming UK economic prosperity, democratic integrity and resilience, citing state-linked hacking of the Electoral Commission and MPs’ emails. Conservatives allege political interference and limited disclosure; Starmer asserts failure stems from outdated pre-1911 legislation that Conservatives never updated. Cash denies wrongdoing; Beijing dismisses accusations as a “self-staged anti-China political farce”.

articles.title: Rachel Reeves says higher taxes on wealthy ‘part of the story’ for November budget
articles.trailText: Chancellor hints at rises and calls out past ‘scaremongering’ over VAT on private schools and changes to non-doms
articles.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves told the IMF in Washington that her 26 November budget will include higher taxes on top earners, shrugging off “scaremongering” over non-doms, private-equity levies and VAT on private school fees, which she says delivered robust revenue last year. She ruled out blanket wealth taxes but is weighing options—higher capital-gains rates, national-insurance on rental income and legal/consultancy partners, new council-tax bands or ISA reforms—to fund growth, reassure bond markets and avoid a return to austerity despite an OBR downgrade.

articles.title: Jonathan Powell: the trusted aide Starmer is shielding from China spy row
articles.trailText: National security adviser has become most influential foreign policy figure in government
articles.summary: Since Starmer appointed him NSA less than a year ago, Jonathan Powell, ex-Blair chief of staff, has emerged as Labour’s uber-influential foreign policy architect. He’s led Ukraine and Gaza ceasefire plans, managed US and China ties, brokered Chagos handover, and navigated the British duo’s China spy trial collapse. Defended by Downing Street amid calls for parliamentary scrutiny, he operates as a politicised special adviser with vast external networks, now sharing duties with Barbara Woodward to ease his heavy global travel and workload. He’s considered Starmer’s sole trusted foreign policy confidant and is shielded from backlash over the collapsed espionage trial.

articles.title: Kemi brings a shovel to a gunfight, and Starmer lets her dig her own hole | John Crace
articles.trailText: After a humiliating performance earlier this week, the Tory leader continues to declare war on logic, evidence and self-awareness
articles.summary: Kemi Badenoch compounded her humiliation after opposing a Gaza ceasefire by launching a baseless assault on Keir Starmer over the collapsed China spying case at PMQs. Displaying Dunning-Kruger levels of self-belief, she ignored Starmer’s prepared evidence, including three witness statements, and repeated conspiracy-tinged allegations despite having no legal footing. Starmer skilfully pointed to past Tory ministers’ own cautions about China, blamed his predecessors’ failures and promised transparency. Out-maneuvered and fact-checked, Badenoch emerged looking stubborn but under-prepared, her attack fizzling amid complex intelligence and legal questions.

articles.title: Nature groups rebuke Reeves for ‘cynical’ 11th-hour planning bill changes
articles.trailText: Chancellor accused of removing environmental protections to win short-term growth and save her budget
articles.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves faces backlash after she tabled last-minute amendments to the planning bill that strip environmental safeguards and empower ministers to overrule local councils resisting developments on grounds like water shortages. Major charities—the RSPB, Wildlife Trusts and Wildlife & Countryside Link—label the move ‘cynical’, accusing Reeves of prioritising short-term growth and OBR forecasts ahead of her November budget. Opponents warn fast-tracking AI datacentres and housing projects will threaten biodiversity, undermine local democracy and deliver ‘legislative chaos’ rather than genuine reform.

articles.title: Pressure on Downing Street to release evidence in collapsed China spy case
articles.trailText: Crown Prosecution Service denies it blocked publication of material and says decision rests with the government
articles.summary: Downing Street faces demands to publish the key witness statement that led to the collapse of the China espionage trial of ex-researcher Christopher Cash and teacher Christopher Berry. The CPS says it did not block release of Matthew Collins’s evidence, arguing its disclosure is a government decision. Sources claim Cabinet Secretary Chris Wormald sought to suppress the statement, which prosecutors found insufficient to prove a national security threat. Lib Dems accuse ministers of a cover-up. PM Starmer defends Collins, while critics warn of opaqueness over handling China policy. Starmer faces scrutiny at PMQs as opposition highlights the delay.

articles.title: Digital ID: Danes and Estonians find it ‘pretty uncontroversial’
articles.trailText: Citizens have enrolled with little opposition, albeit with some concerns over security and privacy, as UK plans system
articles.summary: Denmark’s MitID, rolled out since 2001 and updated in 2022, now enrolls 97% of citizens aged 15+ for banking, e-signatures, healthcare bookings and digital post; just 5% opt out. Broad public trust and elderly volunteer training have driven adoption, though concerns linger over surveillance, online threats, system resilience and hybrid-warfare risks. Estonia’s digital ID, introduced in 2002, combines a physical card or mobile PKI-based auth for voting, taxes and banking under laws ensuring data ownership, audit logs and strong encryption. Limited political pushback to date, but accumulating digital footprints, e-voting integrity and future quantum risks spark emerging debate. UK aims for an app-only scheme by 2029.

articles.title: Keir Starmer back on familiar ground after walk-on part in the Trump show in Egypt | John Crace
articles.trailText: PM tells Commons that ceasefire between Israel and Hamas only first tentative step to peace in the Middle East
articles.summary: Keir Starmer was a non-speaking extra at Trump’s Egypt ceasefire launch – the US president’s personal peace spectacle – then returned to Westminster with a cautiously pragmatic Commons address, telling MPs the Israel-Hamas truce is only a necessary first step towards a durable settlement. He praised the UK’s behind-the-scenes support via Palestinian state recognition and Good Friday accords expertise, while warning against Trump’s transactional agenda. Tory frontbencher Kemi Badenoch launched a partisan attack, omitting Palestinian concerns and misreading negotiations, drawing implicit criticism from her own backbenchers urging cross-party unity for lasting Middle East peace.

articles.title: Farage, not Marxism, risks ‘poisoning our kids’ | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Dr Jan Udris says the Reform leader represents the antithesis of fairness, harmony and emancipation, while Terry Ward thinks he is confusing Karl Marx with Groucho Marx. Plus a letter from Huw Bradbury
articles.summary: Three letters in the Guardian rebut Nigel Farage’s claim that teachers are ‘poisoning’ children with Marxist race theory. Dr Jan Udris (Hemel Hempstead) argues Marxism—democratic redistribution, equality and emancipation, illustrated via John Lennon’s Imagine—stands opposed to Farage’s ethnonationalist capitalism. Former Essex NUT president Terry Ward quips he’s confusing Karl with Groucho Marx, while Huw Bradbury, head of history at Barnard Castle School, defends a diversity-rich, evidence-driven curriculum fostering critical thinking and shared heritage. All three respond to Farage’s October 9 speech at a private US Christian college accusing teachers of casting black pupils as victims and white pupils as oppressors.

articles.title: National grooming gangs inquiry stalls over remit wrangles and lack of chair
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Source says senior legal figures appear reluctant to head investigation launched by Keir Starmer in June
articles.summary: Keir Starmer’s national grooming gangs inquiry, launched in June after pressure from survivors, a Dame Louise Casey audit and Elon Musk, remains stalled four months on amid disputes over its remit and the failure to recruit a chair. A stakeholder panel, including abuse-ring survivors, is deadlocked over whether to widen scope beyond street-based gangs to broader sexual exploitation or regional cases, fearing a sprawling inquiry like the seven-year IICSA. Senior judges and lawyers have declined to lead the politically sensitive probe—especially given scrutiny over past IICSA chairs and unimplemented recommendations.

articles.title: Vote for a party’s policies and actions, not its name or history | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Readers respond to Polly Hudson’s article about feeling that she has no choice but to vote Labour
articles.summary: Three readers challenge Polly Hudson’s instinct to vote Labour out of familial loyalty, urging voters to judge parties on current policies and actions rather than name or heritage. Nadia Kevlin warns that blind party devotion echoes authoritarianism and that Labour’s stances on welfare caps and Gaza conflict may betray her father’s principles. Tom Houston cites Picasso on innovation over tradition, noting party shifts. Ashley Hyne shares his mother’s break with Labour to serve constituents independently. All stress democratic accountability and personal conscience in electoral choices.

articles.title: Former lord speaker faces suspension for ‘improper influence’ over speeding offence
articles.trailText: Frances D’Souza wrote to Met commissioner in apparent attempt to evade sanction for exceeding 20mph speed limit
articles.summary: Former lord speaker Frances D’Souza is facing an eight-week suspension from the House of Lords after she wrote on Lords-headed paper to Met commissioner Mark Rowley seeking to influence a live police probe into speeding in a 20mph zone. D’Souza argued hardship from a driving ban given her rural location and questioned radar accuracy. The Met declined a criminal inquiry, referring her letter to the Lords conduct committee, which deemed it an abuse of privilege. D’Souza has appealed, calling the sanction excessive, and was also summoned for the underlying offence.

articles.title: Academic axed from Labour conference panel for criticising energy policy
articles.trailText: Sustainability expert was told panellists discussing North Sea oil and gas were meant to ‘agree entirely’ with each other
articles.summary: Professor Matthew Agarwala, the University of Sussex’s Bennett professor of sustainable finance, was pulled from Labour and Conservative conference fringe panels after organisers Total Politics and sponsor Offshore Energies UK (OEUK) objected to his analysis that North Sea oil and gas do not cut UK energy bills and that net zero wasn’t driving high prices. Agarwala says he was told panelists must “agree entirely” and that events serve lobbying over debate. He criticised the “pay-to-play red-light district” nature of sponsored sessions. OEUK extended an offer for a future public debate. Total Politics declined to comment.

articles.title: Rachel Reeves to confirm changes to ‘outdated’ planning system
articles.trailText: Changes intended to reduce ‘burdensome bureaucracy’ and make it easier to build windfarms, reservoirs and housing
articles.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves will on 14 October confirm amendments to the government’s planning and infrastructure bill aimed at cutting red tape, restoring investor confidence and bolstering growth forecasts. Key changes include curtailing Natural England’s role in minor applications, allowing turbines within range of Scotland’s Eskdalemuir seismic array and giving ministers power to override council refusals on major developments. The bill returns to the Lords on 20 October, potentially unlocking an extra £3bn in OBR growth headroom before the budget.

articles.title: Labour MPs call on Rachel Reeves to scrap council tax
articles.trailText: Exclusive: 13 mainly northern MPs say a new system should better account for higher house prices in south-east
articles.summary: Thirteen mainly northern Labour MPs have written to chancellor Rachel Reeves urging her to abolish the outdated council tax—based on 1991 property valuations—and replace it with a system reflecting 35 years of housing inflation, especially in London and the south-east. Facing a potential £20–30bn budget gap but committed to no income, VAT or NI rises, Reeves is under pressure to pursue bold property-tax reforms. The IFS also recommends scrapping stamp duty and overhauling council tax. Signatories span Blue Labour social conservatives and the socialist left.

articles.title: Muddle over semantics or pressure from China? Collapsed spying case remains baffling
articles.trailText: Labour says Tory government at time failed to classify China as a threat, but plenty of evidence suggests the contrary
articles.summary: Dan Jarvis's claim that no Conservative government had officially deemed China a national security threat contradicts policy reviews and public statements from 2021–23 that labeled Beijing the biggest state-based threat to UK security. The prosecution of two Britons accused under the Official Secrets Act collapsed after deputy security adviser Matthew Collins omitted to call China a “current threat” in three witness statements, prompting the CPS to drop charges. Critics suspect either a semantic mishap or political interference and urge release of Collins's evidence, redacted if needed.

articles.title: Farage criticises ‘disgraceful’ rhetoric after alleged attack on Reform council leader
articles.trailText: George Finch, 19, says he was called a ‘racist’ and ‘fascist’ during incident in Warwickshire on Friday
articles.summary: Nigel Farage has condemned “disgraceful” rhetoric from Labour and Green leaders after Reform UK’s youngest council leader, 19-year-old George Finch of Warwickshire, was allegedly called “racist” and “fascist” and pushed in Nuneaton. Finch said the attacker was “wound up” by the parties’ language; Reform’s Zia Yusuf echoed this on X. Farage accused Prime Minister Starmer of inciting violence by branding Reform as unpatriotic. Labour and Green spokespeople denounced harassment, the Greens decried politicisation, and Warwickshire police opened an assault investigation.

articles.title: Government made ‘every effort’ to support China spying trial, says minister
articles.trailText: Dan Jarvis accuses Tories of suggesting case was deliberately abandoned ‘without a shred of evidence’
articles.summary: Security minister Dan Jarvis told MPs the government made “every effort” to support the trial of ex-researcher Christopher Cash and Christopher Berry on China spying charges, supplying three witness statements via deputy NSA Matthew Collins. He blamed antiquated legislation for the CPS’s decision last month to drop the case, rejecting Tory allegations that Jonathan Powell or ministers concealed evidence to appease Beijing. Conservatives and Lib Dems have demanded Collins–CPS correspondence, while ministers insist China poses real security threats amid new MI5 warnings.

articles.title: Why Britain’s climate and defence strategies need to be better integrated | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: Lt Gen (retd) Richard Nugee highlights the vital link between climate resilience and national security
articles.summary: Letter from Lt Gen Richard Nugee calls for merging Britain’s climate resilience and defence strategies, warning that treating them separately undermines national security. He cites Europe’s summer wildfires overwhelming health systems and militaries, global climate-driven conflict and displacement, and the EU’s energy dependence on Russian pipelines. He points to the navy’s pre-WWI shift from coal to oil as a model for today’s dual-use tech investments. With NATO’s 5% GDP spending pledge, the UK should fund dual-use innovations—like hybrid electric vehicles and sustainable aviation fuels—to cut emissions and boost military performance.

articles.title: Swinney says Scottish government will sponsor visas for foreign care workers
articles.trailText: First minister tells SNP conference older people should not ‘pay the price for Westminster’s prejudice’ over immigration
articles.summary: First Minister John Swinney pledged at the SNP conference in Aberdeen to allocate £500,000 of Scottish funds to sponsor visas for hundreds of overseas care workers after the UK government cut immigration routes for care roles. He argued Scotland’s elderly ‘should not pay the price for Westminster’s prejudice’ and highlighted low council tax, child poverty and free services as SNP achievements. Swinney linked the move to a broader push for independence, EU re-entry and renewable energy, aiming for an SNP majority (65 seats) at next Holyrood election to demand a referendum despite Labour’s refusal and electoral hurdles.

articles.title: Families of David Amess and Jo Cox voice concern at rise in violent political rhetoric
articles.trailText: Relatives of murdered MPs say Charlie Kirk killing is a wake-up call for UK and that violence is becoming more likely
articles.summary: Families of slain MPs David Amess and Jo Cox warn Britain faces a surge in violent political language, citing recent antisemitic, Islamophobic attacks and explicit social-media calls to shoot figures like Keir Starmer. They highlight suspension of a Reform UK councillor, threats filmed at a far-right London rally where Elon Musk warned “violence is coming,” and unprosecuted assassination calls. Nigel Farage also accuses Labour of incitement. Campaigners and legal experts urge consistent policing and prosecution to deter politically motivated threats and prevent further normalisation of violence.

articles.title: Reform UK abandoning manifesto pledge of £90bn in tax cuts, deputy leader admits
articles.trailText: Richard Tice says party will concentrate on cutting civil service and scrapping net zero once in government
articles.summary: Reform UK’s deputy leader Richard Tice admitted the party cannot deliver its £90bn manifesto tax-cut pledge, recasting measures like lifting the income tax allowance to £20,000 and cutting corporation tax to 15% as long-term aspirations. He said Reform will focus first on public spending reductions—slimming the civil service, scrapping net zero policies and easing regulations—before considering performance-linked tax cuts. Nigel Farage is set to unveil a revised economic blueprint prioritising upfront savings. Labour, the Conservatives and the IFS have dismissed Reform’s figures as unfunded and unrealistic, warning such cuts would imperil key services.

articles.title: UK charities say toxic immigration rhetoric leading to threats against staff
articles.trailText: Voluntary organisations forced to introduce extensive security measures to protect staff and property
articles.summary: Charities across the UK report surging racial abuse, intimidation and violent threats against staff and beneficiaries amid increasingly toxic political and online rhetoric on immigration and race. Refugee, asylum, Muslim, Jewish, ethnic-minority and other voluntary organisations say far-right activists have targeted offices and homeless accommodations – daubing racist graffiti, attempting break-ins, and issuing rape and murder threats. Many are installing safe rooms, tracking devices, security guards and redacting staff details from websites. More than 150 NGOs, including Age UK and Citizens Advice, have urged PM Keir Starmer to curb divisive rhetoric, protect civil society and uphold inclusion, equality and anti-racism in the face of extremist intimidation.

articles.title: Post-ministerial jobs watchdog closes as part of UK government ethics shake-up
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Acoba’s functions split between two regulators and new Ethics and Integrity Commission to oversee others
articles.summary: The UK government has abolished the Advisory Committee on Business Appointments (Acoba), splitting its duties: Sir Laurie Magnus will oversee post-ministerial job clearances, while the Civil Service Commission handles ex-civil servants and special advisers. Simultaneously, a new Ethics and Integrity Commission—led by Doug Chalmers and inheriting the Committee on Standards in Public Life’s remit—will coordinate oversight across bodies like the parliamentary standards commissioner and Electoral Commission. From Monday, ministers breaching the code may lose severance (usually 25% of salary, c.£17,000), with those serving under six months forfeiting payment and anyone taking another ministerial post within three months deferring salary for that period. Starmer promises these reforms, tied to forthcoming Hillsborough law duties, will restore public trust.

articles.title: Jonathan Powell had no role in dropping of China spy case, senior minister says
articles.trailText: Bridget Phillipson says national security adviser was not involved in discussions before CPS abandoned its prosecution
articles.summary: Senior cabinet minister Bridget Phillipson said national security adviser Jonathan Powell played no part in the CPS’s decision to drop espionage charges against parliamentary researcher Christopher Cash and China-based researcher Christopher Berry. Reports had linked the case’s collapse to Powell’s refusal to label Beijing an “enemy,” a designation legally required under the Official Secrets Act after case law from a Bulgarian spy trial and a June strategy calling China a “geostrategic challenge.” Phillipson stressed Powell was uninvolved in evidence or substance, Keir Starmer still backs him, and both the DPP and Tory MPs are demanding explanations.

articles.title: Green party reaches 100,000 members for first time after Polanski becomes leader
articles.trailText: Green party in England and Wales has had near-50% rise in membership since since Zack Polanski took over last month
articles.summary: The Green party in England and Wales surpassed 100,000 members for the first time after a near-50% surge since Zack Polanski became leader last month, overtaking the Liberal Democrats (83,500) and closing on the Conservatives (around 120,000). Officials say sustained momentum could make them the UK’s second-largest party by membership, though most polls still place them at about 11–15%. Polanski’s high-profile media push has alarmed Labour ahead of local elections, as he vows to replace them by championing fair taxes, climate action and political renewal.

articles.title: Looking for signs of life in centre-right politics in Britain | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Responding to articles about the Conservative party conference, David Redshaw suspects there may be life in Thatcherism yet. Plus letters from Des Senior, William Wallace, Les Bright , Katy Jennison and Peter Brooker
articles.summary: Five letters respond to debates over the Tory conference and centre-right politics: David Redshaw (Saltdean) argues Thatcherism replaced one-nation Conservatism and endures; Des Senior (Aylesbeare) lambasts Kemi Badenoch’s stamp-duty cut as fiscally irresponsible; William Wallace (Lib Dem peer) justifies civil service growth post-Brexit; Les Bright (Exeter) and Peter Brooker (West Wickham) lament the purge of pragmatic MPs by Boris Johnson; Katy Jennison (Witney) questions why Labour isn’t filling the centre-right void.

articles.title: Lucy Powell calls on Labour not to ‘write off’ May local elections
articles.trailText: Deputy leadership favourite says budget can revive party��s appeal, while Bridget Phillipson pitches to channel grassroots views to cabinet
articles.summary: Deputy leadership hopeful Lucy Powell warns Labour against conceding next May’s English, Scottish and Welsh elections, urging the November budget to reverse mid-term losses by lifting the two-child benefit cap, rebalancing tax burdens and resetting the party’s agenda to retain councils threatened by Reform UK. Sacked in Starmer’s reshuffle, Powell promises tough truths from outside the cabinet. Rival candidate Bridget Phillipson pledges a formal quarterly system to feed grassroots views from members and unions into cabinet policymaking. Electronic voting runs until 23 October, with the result declared on 25 October.

articles.title: Tories and Reform battle to be heirs to Thatcher’s legacy on her centenary
articles.trailText: Gala dinner to remember Conservatives’ most successful leader puts spotlight on who will carry forward her ideas
articles.summary: At a sold-out gala in London’s Guildhall marking Thatcher’s centenary, Conservatives—Boris Johnson, Thatcher’s son Mark—and Reform UK’s deputy Richard Tice clashed over her small-state legacy. Major donor Mohamed Amersi, now backing Reform, hailed Farage as a modern Thatcherian, while absent hopeful Kemi Badenoch pitched herself as Thatcher’s successor at a separate Tory fundraiser. Senior Tories and CPS director Robert Colvile lament no clear heir amid private donor dinners, Carlton Club gatherings and 80s-themed events vying for her mantle. Tickets ranged from £195 to £3,000, reflecting the event’s donor-driven scale.

articles.title: SNP backs Swinney’s ‘clear’ strategy for new independence referendum
articles.trailText: Members overwhelmingly endorse leadership motion that majority at next Holyrood election is only route to second vote
articles.summary: At its Aberdeen conference, SNP members overwhelmingly endorsed leader John Swinney’s motion that next May’s Holyrood election be fought on a “clear platform of national independence,” with winning at least 65 seats as the only uncontested path to a second referendum. Delegates rejected a fundamentalist de facto referendum amendment backed by over 40 branches. The party, trailing confusion that cost Westminster seats in 2024, now leads polls ahead of Labour and Reform UK but faces the high bar of securing a majority under Holyrood’s proportional system, while the UK government remains unlikely to sanction another vote.

articles.title: Tony Blair met Jeffrey Epstein in No 10 on advice of Peter Mandelson, documents reveal
articles.trailText: National Archives papers show how then MP pushed for 2002 meeting between PM and ‘young and vibrant’ financier
articles.summary: Newly released National Archives papers reveal that on 14 May 2002, PM Tony Blair met financier Jeffrey Epstein at No 10 after Peter Mandelson—then a backbench Labour MP—recommended him to Blair’s chief of staff, Jonathan Powell. Mandelson described Epstein as “safe,” “young and vibrant” and highlighted his links to Bill Clinton and Prince Andrew. A briefing from senior civil servant Matthew Rycroft noted Epstein’s role advising the super-rich. Blair’s spokesperson says the under-30-minute meeting predated Epstein’s crimes. Powell, now Keir Starmer’s national security adviser, had simply forwarded Mandelson’s request.

articles.title: Widow of man conned out of pension savings to lose half the compensation to tax
articles.trailText: Robert Dewar’s widow, Susan, is a leading campaigner over multimillion-pound Norton Motorcycles fraud
articles.summary: Susan Dewar, widow of Robert Dewar—who lost his retirement savings in the 2012–13 Norton Motorcycles ‘pension liberation’ fraud—will now relinquish almost £50,000 of her £114,000 compensation to tax. An obscure HMRC rule strips tax-free status from death-benefit lump sums paid more than two years after a scheme learns of a member’s death. Robert’s award via the Fraud Compensation Fund arrived in 2024, five years after his death, triggering the charge. Daughter Sally Holmes criticises systemic delays, while ex-owner Stuart Garner received a suspended sentence for misusing investors’ funds.

articles.title: Tony Blair and Nick Clegg hosted dinner giving tech bosses access to UK minister
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Six tech leaders dined with investment minister, documents reveal, underlining growing influence of ex-PM’s consultancy
articles.summary: Documents reveal that in January Tony Blair, leading his Tony Blair Institute consultancy, and Nick Clegg convened six tech executives—including heads from Insight Partners, Wayve, Graphcore and Faculty AI—for a private ‘salon dinner’ with investment minister Poppy Gustafsson to debate the UK’s evolving AI policy. Critics warn the event, bankrolled by donors like Larry Ellison, underscores opaque access to government and potential donor-driven agenda setting. Separately, TBI obtained a confidential AI action-plan summary from ministers days before its public release, fuelling transparency concerns.

articles.title: Boris Johnson breached rules designed to stop abuse of contacts made in public office, watchdog finds
articles.trailText: Johnson found to have breached rules after refusing to answer specific questions about allegations published by the Guardian
articles.summary: Boris Johnson has been found by the Advisory Committee on Business Appointments (Acoba) to have breached post-office lobbying rules after refusing to answer detailed queries on leaked Guardian documents showing him using contacts from No 10 to pitch a billion-dollar UAE venture and a Saudi consultancy. He denied substantive allegations as based on hacked material. Acoba chair Isabel Doverty reported his non-cooperation as a breach. With Acoba set to close on Oct 13, no further sanctions are expected.

articles.title: Labour’s softening stance towards China reinforced by dropped spy case
articles.trailText: In an attempt to reset the relationship the government is refusing to describe China as a national security threat despite evidence to the contrary
articles.summary: Labour under Keir Starmer has shifted from a hardline stance on China—once pledging to label Uyghur repression a genocide—to a trade-focused rapprochement echoing Cameron’s “golden era.” Critics highlight the dropped spy prosecution of two Britons after the CPS failed to secure a government statement branding China a national security threat. Starmer’s adviser Jonathan Powell, architect of the reset, subsumed the promised China audit into a national security strategy. Despite repeated Chinese cyber and industrial espionage, Labour removed genocide language, excluded China from its Foreign Influence Registration enhanced tier, and prioritizes investment over human rights.

articles.title: Richard Tice accepted stay at French Riviera home of Tory donor
articles.trailText: Reform deputy leader’s trip, worth £1,4000, to Lubov Chernukhin’s property was for ‘discussing gas power in UK’
articles.summary: Reform UK deputy leader Richard Tice accepted a stay worth £1,400 at the French Riviera property of Tory donor Lubov Chernukhin, wife of ex-Russian finance minister, to ‘discuss gas power in the UK’, MPs’ filings reveal. Tice, energy spokesperson and net zero critic, defended the August trip amid concerns over power shortages. Chernukhin, a British citizen who has donated over £2m to the Conservatives and co-founded Satellite Energy Systems, denies Putin ties. Labour criticised ‘foreign influence’; Tice argued Britain needs foreign investment for new gas plants.

articles.title: Zarah Sultana compares Jeremy Corbyn reunion to Gallagher brothers
articles.trailText: MP says pair have reconciled after bitter dispute as they appear together at Manchester leftwing festival
articles.summary: At Manchester’s The World Transformed festival, MP Zarah Sultana announced she and former Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn have reconciled and can co-lead their nascent leftwing outfit, unofficially dubbed Your Party, comparing their reunion to Gallagher brothers. The pair had clashed over Sultana’s paid membership system—Corbyn called it a "false membership system" and involved the ICO—prompting her to accuse him of running a "sexist boys' club" before rescinding legal threats. Corbyn later apologised in a video to 750,000 subscribers. The duo plans to work with the Greens and local independents. Sultana also denounced Nigel Farage’s Reform as a billionaire-backed distraction.

articles.title: Man who entered UK on small boat found guilty of threatening to kill Nigel Farage
articles.trailText: Fayaz Khan, 26, made the threat in a TikTok video that Reform UK leader told the court was ‘pretty chilling’
articles.summary: Afghan national Fayaz Khan, 26, who crossed the Channel in a small boat, was found guilty at Southwark Crown Court of threatening to kill Reform UK leader Nigel Farage in an October TikTok video. Jurors heard Khan, known for viral videos about his journey to the UK, brandished gun gestures, “pop pop pop” sounds and pointed to an AK-47 face tattoo, warning Farage to “delete the video” or be shot. Farage described the threat as “pretty chilling.” Khan, who livestreamed his Channel crossing and insisted the noises were a comedic shtick, faces sentencing for threats and illegal entry.

articles.title: Farage insists ex-Reform UK Wales leader convicted of bribery is ‘bad apple’
articles.trailText: Farage said he was shocked by Nathan Gill’s admissions relating to pro-Russia statements
articles.summary: Nigel Farage, campaigning in Caerphilly for Reform UK’s Senedd by-election candidate, described ex-Wales leader Nathan Gill as a “bad apple” after Gill pleaded guilty to eight counts of taking pro-Russian bribes in 2018–19. Farage said he was shocked, having known Gill as an honest, devout Christian, and insisted most parties encounter rogue figures. He defended Reform UK’s delay in appointing a new Welsh leader amid ongoing candidate selections. Local supporters Rob and Susan Pascoe praised Farage’s “honest” approach and lamented Labour’s absence, citing migration and a desire for change after years of Labour dominance.

articles.title: The £1m man: why did Boris Johnson take his donor to Ukraine?
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Leaked files offer a glimpse of the ex-prime minister’s relationship with Christopher Harborne
articles.summary: Leaked ‘Boris Files’ show ex-PM Boris Johnson flew his £1 m donor, Christopher Harborne—a discreet tech and defence investor and QinetiQ shareholder—to Kyiv in September 2023 for the Yalta European Strategy forum. Harborne was registered as an “adviser” to Johnson’s office, attended closed sessions with Zelenskiy and military-tech briefings. The visit spotlights potential conflicts between Johnson’s public Ukraine advocacy and private fundraising arrangements after leaving Downing Street.

articles.title: Starmer accused of pushing out some of last progressive allies in No 10 shake-up
articles.trailText: Exclusive: PM reorganising key parts of government to give chief secretary Darren Jones more Whitehall control
articles.summary: PM Keir Starmer’s latest No 10 reshuffle places chief secretary Darren Jones at the centre of government machinery by merging delivery and policy units into three pillars—economy, public services, communities and security—while sidelining longtime progressive advisers. Carys Roberts and Muneera Lula, viewed as two of the unit’s most left-wing experts, have resigned amid the arrival of more centrist recruits from the Tony Blair Institute and former May adviser Toby Lloyd. Critics warn this erodes diversity—particularly female and equalities posts—and signals a technocratic pivot as Labour battles poor poll ratings and policy incoherence.

articles.title: Foreign Office chief to visit China after collapse of high-profile espionage case
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Oliver Robbins to visit China next week on ‘long-planned’ government business after collapse of trial of two men over spying charges
articles.summary: Oliver Robbins, the UK’s top FCDO civil servant, will travel to China next week on a long-planned visit, even as ministers face scrutiny over the collapse of an espionage trial against two men accused of spying for Beijing. The prosecution was dropped after prosecutors failed to secure a government witness statement classifying China as a national security threat, a requirement under the Official Secrets Act. Downing Street denies ministerial interference. The trip, following recent visits by other senior UK officials, precedes key decisions on a proposed Chinese super-embassy and ahead of planned visits by Keir Starmer.

articles.title: Senior SNP figures believe Holyrood majority ���within reach’ at May’s election
articles.trailText: As party gathers for conference, re-engaging independence supporters seen as way forward after trust in Scottish government hits record low
articles.summary: Senior SNP strategists believe winning a 65-seat majority at May’s Holyrood election is ‘within reach’, citing Tory collapse and Labour’s unpopularity. Their strategy targets the ‘battleground cohort’ of ‘soft yes’ independence supporters who drifted away, aiming to re-engage them on a clear pro-independence platform. They credit John Swinney’s pro-immigration/progressive tax pitch and a fractured opposition: recent polling shows SNP 37%, Labour 17%, Reform 16%, Tories and Lib Dems 12%, Greens 5%, independence at 50%. Internal debate over calling next election a de facto referendum persists amid low government trust, NHS dissatisfaction, leadership churn and membership falling from 126,000 to 56,000.

articles.title: Rishi Sunak takes advisory roles with Microsoft and AI firm Anthropic
articles.trailText: Former UK prime minister told post-ministerial jobs watchdog roles would not involve lobbying or UK policy influence
articles.summary: Former UK PM Rishi Sunak has been appointed senior adviser at Microsoft and AI startup Anthropic, adding to roles at Goldman Sachs and US investment firms. Acoba approved roles with restrictions barring lobbying or UK policy influence due to conflict-of-interest concerns after his PM-era AI and digital deals. Sunak will provide strategic perspectives on macroeconomic and geopolitical trends, donating fees to his Richmond Project charity. Anthropic’s CEO says Sunak’s AI safety leadership and summit convening offer valuable insight.

articles.title: Phillipson presses Starmer and Reeves to abolish two-child benefit cap in full
articles.trailText: Exclusive: education secretary tells the Guardian scrapping limit entirely in November’s budget most cost-effective way to tackle child poverty
articles.summary: Education secretary Bridget Phillipson, co-chair of Labour’s child poverty taskforce, is pressing PM Keir Starmer and chancellor Rachel Reeves to abolish the two-child benefit cap entirely in the November budget, calling it the clearest, most cost-effective way to lift disadvantaged children out of poverty. Reeves is exploring a partial tapering to three or four children, but officials say the taskforce’s evidence will force full removal despite an eventual £3.6bn price tag. Phillipson, running for deputy leader, seeks a member mandate to drive this reform alongside expanded free school meals for 100,000 children.

articles.title: Nigel Farage accuses teachers of ‘poisoning our kids’ on race issues
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Reform UK leader’s remarks at event for private US college criticised as ‘grossly irresponsible’ by NEU leader
articles.summary: Nigel Farage, speaking at Hillsdale College in Michigan, accused UK teachers of “poisoning our kids” with critical race theory, claiming the “Marxist left” controls schools and predicting strikes soon after a Reform UK election win. NEU general secretary Daniel Kebede branded his remarks “nonsense” and “grossly irresponsible,” noting strikes hinge on pay and conditions. Farage signaled a years-long curriculum overhaul and pledged to extend Hillsdale’s free online courses to UK students despite Reform UK’s lack of a detailed education policy.

articles.title: Starmer enters parallel universe as red carpet rolled out in India amid trade deal
articles.trailText: UK PM greeted by thousands of posters of his face in Mumbai after clinching deal, despite torrid month back home
articles.summary: On his first year’s standout win, PM Keir Starmer landed in Mumbai to applause: 5,700 posters, street closures and musicians welcomed him as he marked the long-awaited UK-India free trade agreement. Having urged PM Narendra Modi to advance stalled talks, Starmer lit a Diwali lamp alongside Modi, who hailed him as a “friend.” He led a record 120-strong UK business delegation to secure sectoral deals, yet CEOs pressed for clarity on the looming UK budget amid sluggish growth and rising taxes. The FTA’s impact—modeled to boost UK GDP by just 0.13% by 2040—awaits parliamentary ratification as Starmer returns to low polls and restive ministers.

articles.title: Starmer praises Trump’s Gaza ceasefire deal – but avoids Nobel prize backing
articles.trailText: Breakthrough in Gaza possible thanks to US president’s leadership, says prime minister during India trade visit
articles.summary: On a trade mission to India, Keir Starmer hailed President Trump’s leadership as crucial for the Gaza ceasefire deal, urging its full implementation and immediate humanitarian aid relief, but stopped short of endorsing Trump for a Nobel Peace Prize. He highlighted the UK’s behind-the-scenes role and pressed for durable peace before Nobel backing. In Mumbai he also finalised a UK-India free-trade pact, a £350m missile defence sale, fintech and university investments, and explored India’s digital ID model. Starmer raised human-rights concerns with Narendra Modi, including Russian oil imports and Sikh activist Jagtar Singh Johal’s detention, and signalled broader UK-China outreach.
