articles.title: Plaid Cymru leader predicts two-horse race with Reform in Welsh elections
articles.trailText: Rhun ap Iorwerth says 2026 Senedd vote will pitch vision against division but will not be a poll on independence
articles.summary: Plaid Cymru leader Rhun ap Iorwerth forecasts next year’s Senedd contest as a ‘two-horse race’ between his party’s progressive vision and Reform UK’s divisive populism, citing YouGov polls showing Plaid at 30%, Reform 29% and Labour trailing at 14%. He argues a Plaid government would be free from London influence, rejects coalitions with Reform, and will court other parties in a mature way. He insists the election won’t hinge on independence even as he promotes a future redesigned UK of four nations and celebrates Welsh culture as central to nation-building.

articles.title: Keir Starmer to look at India’s digital ID system during visit to Mumbai
articles.trailText: Prime minister hopes to learn from success of scheme rolled out to most of country’s 1.4bn citizens
articles.summary: On his two-day trip to Mumbai, Keir Starmer met Infosys chair Nandan Nilekani to examine India’s Aadhaar digital ID system, rolled out to 1.4 bn citizens and handling 80 m daily transactions, credited with saving £11 bn but criticised for excluding minorities and data-privacy gaps. He plans a UK-built, non-biometric scheme—mandatory for employment to curb illegal working and voluntary for school applications, mortgages and driving licences—backed by a public consultation. Starmer will also meet Narendra Modi and pursue deals set to create about 7,000 UK jobs.

articles.title: Badenoch sets out her vision to redefine Tory party – but few are listening
articles.trailText: Rivals lurk in the aisles at sparsely attended conference at which the party leader ignores the threat from Reform
articles.summary: Badenoch arrived at a low-turnout Manchester conference where, amid 16% polling and a surging Reform UK threat, few recall her first year as leader. Rivals like Robert Jenrick and a 14-MP WhatsApp coup countdown until the November 2 leadership challenge loom. She opened with contrition, shifting emphasis from migration to the economy—viewed as the Tories’ strongest card against Reform. Despite 64% of members backing a pact with Farage, Badenoch refuses. Allies say her “tone of humility” has bought time before May’s local elections, though critics warn the party risks drifting into irrelevance.

articles.title: The irony of Robert Jenrick’s ‘white face’ remarks about Handsworth | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Shuranjeet Singh points out that it was the Tories who threw his neighbourhood into neglect, while Edward Lindon fears the MP is sowing the seeds for tomorrow’s bumper crop of racial hatred and misery. Plus letters from Warwick Hillman , Janet Walmsley and Darryl Telles
articles.summary: Opposition letters critique Robert Jenrick’s assertion that Handsworth is ‘like a slum’ and his lament over “not seeing another white face,” arguing it betrays irony given Tory disinvestment. Shuranjeet Singh stresses the area’s decades-long cultural resilience, local faith and voluntary groups, and invites Jenrick back to sample Soho Road’s vibrant eateries. Edward Lindon warns that Jenrick’s racialized rhetoric sows seeds of future hatred. Other writers underscore Handsworth’s integration successes (e.g. Baron Bill Morris), contrast his silence on predominantly white locales, and question his selective concern.

articles.title: Pat Bradley obituary
articles.trailText: Chief electoral officer for Northen Ireland who never voted, to ensure no one questioned his independence
articles.summary: Pat Bradley, who died aged 90, served as Northern Ireland’s chief electoral officer from 1980 to 2000, overseeing 25 elections. A scrupulous administrator, he championed voter ID in the mid-1980s to curb fraud and proposed the D’Hondt system for power-sharing posts. During the 1998 Good Friday Agreement referendum he defied DUP demands, stayed awake 40 hours to guard unopened ballot boxes and ensure transparency. He survived bombs and threats, advised new democracies worldwide, never voted to preserve impartiality, and was honoured OBE in 1986 and CBE in 1999.

articles.title: Badenoch enjoys her first, and probably last, Tory conference leader’s speech | John Crace
articles.trailText: The audience cheered and clapped to convince themselves the whole thing hadn’t been a waste of time
articles.summary: Kemi Badenoch delivered her debut—and likely farewell—Tory conference leader’s speech to an audience desperate to justify a moribund gathering. Despite standing ovations, her address was ramshackle: partisan barbs at Labour, nostalgic boasts of a “stronger economy” and secure borders, mindless quips and big-ticket pledges—from slashing 100,000 university places to abolishing stamp duty—none underpinned by credible funding. Half her membership wants her out, yet she offered no contrition for 14 years of austerity, migration and stagnation. Crace paints a Potemkin performance, a collective delusion masking a party in crisis.

articles.title: Iain Coleman obituary
articles.trailText: Labour MP fired by compassion for those left behind by society who fought for free social care provision at home
articles.summary: Iain Coleman, former Hammersmith and Fulham MP (1997–2005) and council leader (1991–96), championed a pioneering free home social care scheme—ironically later benefiting from it after a string of strokes (20 total) that led to early-onset dementia. Born in Hammersmith in 1958, a care worker in Kent and later local government officer, Coleman—a skilled Labour strategist—fought for homeless people and working-class families, highlighting his borough’s stark poverty in Parliament. He served again as a councillor (2010–14), married to politician Sally Powell, and is survived by her, son Jack, brother Neale and sister Helen.

articles.title: Tories would scrap stamp duty on primary residences, Kemi Badenoch tells conference
articles.trailText: Leader announces tax cut plan for England and Northern Ireland in speech aimed at boosting fiscal credibility
articles.summary: Kemi Badenoch told the Conservative conference she would abolish stamp duty on primary-home purchases over £125,000 in England and Northern Ireland, costing £9 billion a year, while retaining it on second properties and non-UK buyers. Framed as unlocking fairer homeownership for all ages, the pledge is funded by a separate £50 billion spending-cuts package by 2029 and a proposed “golden economic rule” to devote at least half of savings to deficit reduction. Critics call the cuts vague; economists argue scrapping stamp duty could spur housing market activity. The promise capped a policy-packed conference that also vowed to leave the European Convention on Human Rights, repeal the Climate Change Act and slash welfare.

articles.title: Starmer says Jenrick is ‘hard to take seriously’ after Birmingham comments
articles.trailText: PM says Jenrick is ‘still running his leadership campaign’ after he complained about ‘not seeing another white face’
articles.summary: Prime Minister Keir Starmer dismissed Shadow Justice Secretary Robert Jenrick’s backlash over his remark about ‘not seeing another white face’ in Birmingham’s Handsworth as part of a covert Tory leadership bid and deemed him ‘hard to take seriously.’ Jenrick described Handsworth as akin to a slum and criticised its integration levels, prompting condemnation from former West Midlands mayor Andy Street and first distancing by senior Tory Mel Stride. While Conservative chair Kemi Badenoch defended Jenrick’s right to ‘factual observations,’ Jenrick stood by his comments, rejecting suggestions they fuel far-right rhetoric.

articles.title: Starmer insists India trade deal will not affect UK visas as he heads to Mumbai
articles.trailText: British PM likely to face questions over closeness of Narendra Modi to Vladimir Putin during two-day India visit
articles.summary: On the eve of a two-day Mumbai visit with 120+ business, cultural and university leaders, UK PM Keir Starmer reaffirmed that the spring UK-India free-trade agreement—set to boost bilateral trade by £25.5bn annually and raise UK exports by nearly 60%—includes no further visa liberalisation for workers or students. Starmer, meeting PM Modi amid questions over Modi’s ties with Putin, emphasised business-to-business investment, expanded overseas education offerings and cooperation on Ukraine and cracking down on Russia’s shadow oil fleet, while seeking top global talent for the UK economy.

articles.title: A British Ice and more stop and search: Badenoch’s Tories set out new policies
articles.trailText: Shadow ministers have announced far-reaching and often radical proposals – here is a roundup of some of them
articles.summary: At its Manchester conference Kemi Badenoch’s shadow cabinet unveiled radical policies: quitting the ECHR, repealing the Human Rights Act and Climate Change Act, and creating a UK “Ice” force to enforce strict immigration controls, including banning irregular migrants from asylum, ending legal aid and housing for non-citizens. Shadow chancellor Mel Stride pledged £47bn spending cuts via welfare restrictions, civil service cull and ending net zero commitments. Home secretary Chris Philp plans 10,000 more police and tripled stop-and-search powers, while justice secretary Robert Jenrick would abolish the Sentencing Council and empower sacking “activist” judges. Caps on low-value degrees would reallocate £3bn to apprenticeships.

articles.title: Lucy Powell tells Labour it can’t sugarcoat how badly things are going
articles.trailText: Frontrunner for deputy leadership addresses rally as opponent Bridget Phillipson pledges ‘second Labour term our children deserve’
articles.summary: In the Labour deputy leadership race, frontrunner Lucy Powell—polling at 57% versus Bridget Phillipson’s 26%—pledges to stop sugarcoating the party’s struggles, challenge Downing Street’s ‘groupthink’ and rebuild a broad progressive coalition full-time. Speaking in east London, she urged authenticity, a stronger narrative and regaining the political megaphone from Reform UK and the Greens. Phillipson, backed by Unison, GMB and seen as No 10’s choice, highlights her poverty-to-cabinet story, prioritising child poverty, free school meals and a new deal for working people. Ballots run 8–23 Oct, result 25 Oct.

articles.title: ‘Incendiary, inaccurate, careless’: Handsworth locals reject Jenrick’s race claims
articles.trailText: Businesspeople and residents say senior Tory’s ‘no white faces’ claim is divisive and plain wrong – and the Birmingham neighbourhood is thriving
articles.summary: Shadow justice secretary Robert Jenrick claimed Handsworth was “one of the worst integrated places” and “as close as I’ve come to a slum,” saying he “didn’t see another white face.” Local business leaders and residents, including pawnbroker director David Volante and bakery owner Maria, called his comments “inaccurate,” “incendiary” and “ill-informed,” citing hands-on experience and council data (25% Pakistani, 23% Indian, 10% Bangladeshi, 16% Black African/Caribbean, 10% mixed, 9% white). They warn such rhetoric could hurt trade; residents note bustling Soho Road with “countless white faces” and growing international investment. Jenrick defended the need for an “honest” debate on parallel communities.

articles.title: Honest Bob gets the party started – the Reform party. It’s tough being a Tory | John Crace
articles.trailText: Robert Jenrick gives Conservative conference delegates permission to be the worst possible versions of themselves
articles.summary: At the 2025 Conservative conference in Manchester, shadow justice secretary Robert Jenrick—dubbed “Honest Bob”—stole the spotlight with a tongue-in-cheek leadership audition pitched at Reform Party supporters. In a deliberately light, amusement-driven speech, he mixed anti-immigrant barbs, contempt for the judiciary’s supposed liberal bias, calls to reintroduce the death penalty and implicit encouragement to embrace overtly right-wing policies. By mocking “wokerati,” praising authoritarianism with a “shiny, happy face” and positioning himself as the authentic voice of frustrated Tories, Jenrick effectively undermined Kemi Badenoch’s platform and laid out a roadmap for a seamless Tory-to-Reform transition.

articles.title: Letter: Lord Howarth of Newport obituary
articles.trailText: Stephen Bates writes: I tracked down Alan Howarth for a debate on capital punishment
articles.summary: Stephen Bates recalls tracking down Alan Howarth in 1983 to balance a BBC Midlands Today studio debate on capital punishment against newly elected MP Peter Bruinvels, who proudly offered to serve as hangman. After the broadcast, Bruinvels giddily described his macabre ambition in their taxi back to Parliament, prompting Howarth—ever the quick-witted parliamentarian—to quip that if he faced the gallows he’d prefer Bruinvels as executioner for his cheerfulness. Bates suggests such fastidious integrity set Howarth apart in party politics.

articles.title: Robert Jenrick accused of fuelling ‘toxic nationalism’ with Birmingham claims
articles.trailText: Shadow justice secretary stands by comments made in March amid criticism including from a Tory colleague
articles.summary: Shadow justice secretary Robert Jenrick ignited a fierce backlash after claiming he saw “not another white face” in Birmingham’s Handsworth, calling it “one of the worst integrated places” in Britain. His remarks—originally made while filming a GB News segment on litter—were condemned by deputy PM David Lammy, Tory shadow chancellor Mel Stride, the Bishop of Birmingham and local leaders as racist and divisive, with Green leader Zack Polanski decrying them as ‘toxic nationalism.’ Jenrick refuses to retract, framing his comments as a necessary debate on integration, while Kemi Badenoch defends the factual observation but questions its framing.

articles.title: Labour accuses Robert Jenrick of ‘personal attack’ on attorney general
articles.trailText: Party source says shadow justice secretary’s comments are attempt to disguise his own poor grip of the law
articles.summary: At the Tory conference in Manchester, shadow justice secretary Robert Jenrick attacked attorney general Lord Hermer as a “mafia lawyer” and “useful idiot” for Britain’s enemies, accusing him of bad legal advice on Shamima Begum, 7/7 suspects and Chagos Islands deals. Jenrick vowed to sack judges linked to migrant charities as “activists.” Labour says his insults mask his own legal missteps, including risking a murder trial collapse. Hermer defended lawyers’ duty to represent all clients; former judge Lord Sumption warned politicising the judiciary mimics a US-style court crisis. Jenrick also celebrated British identity.

articles.title: GB News’s US expansion feared to be new way for Trumpian views to reach UK audience
articles.trailText: White House backing was on full display as GB News launched The Late Show Live
articles.summary: GB News executives led by Nigel Farage secured a White House meeting with Donald Trump to back the US launch of its nightly program The Late Show Live. Hosts Bev Turner and Ben Leo gained briefing room access amid Trump PR, with Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt praising shared MAGA values. Supported by media mogul Paul Marshall, GB News seeks to bolster its UK influence as viewership edges slightly above BBC News channel but remains niche. Critics warn the expansion amplifies US rightwing talking points in Britain, raising questions about impartiality enforcement by Ofcom and political concerns over partisan coverage.

articles.title: Badenoch defends Jenrick’s ‘no white faces’ comments about Birmingham
articles.trailText: Tory leader says ‘nothing wrong with making observations’, after Jenrick said Handsworth was ‘as close as I’ve come to a slum in this country’
articles.summary: Kemi Badenoch defended Robert Jenrick’s Handsworth comments—‘I didn’t see another white face’—calling them a ‘factual observation’ about integration, not racism. Former West Midlands mayor Andy Street and Labour’s Richard Parker accused Jenrick of mischaracterising a well-integrated, multiethnic community and questioned his suitability as an MP. Jenrick cited government reports on ‘parallel lives’ and doubled down, while Badenoch urged a focus on social cohesion over appearances ahead of her Conservative conference speech, igniting culture-war debates on race and integration.

articles.title: Keir Starmer calls student protests on 7 October anniversary ‘un-British’
articles.trailText: Prime minister urges students not to protest on the second anniversary of Hamas’s 7 October attacks on Israel
articles.summary: UK prime minister Keir Starmer urged students not to hold protests on the second anniversary of Hamas’s 7 October 2023 attacks on Israel, calling them “un-British” and disrespectful to victims. He described the assault—killing around 1,200 people, taking 251 hostages, and prompting an Israeli offensive with heavy Palestinian casualties—as the worst anti-Jewish atrocity since the Holocaust. Education secretary Bridget Phillipson backed his plea to pause and reflect. Pro-Palestine demonstrations over the weekend led to arrests, and home secretary Shabana Mahmood pledged stronger Public Order Act powers to curb repeated rallies.

articles.title: Robert Jenrick complained of ‘not seeing another white face’ in Birmingham neighbourhood
articles.trailText: Shadow justice secretary criticised for suggesting he could tell how integrated Handsworth was based on short visit
articles.summary: Shadow justice secretary Robert Jenrick sparked controversy after visiting Handsworth, Birmingham, to film a GB News litter report and claiming in a 90-minute span he saw “not another white face,” branding it one of the country’s worst-integrated areas and likening it to a slum. Local MPs Khalid Mahmood and Ayoub Khan denounced his remarks as divisive and factually baseless, citing Handsworth’s diverse makeup (25% Pakistani, 23% Indian, 16% Black) and pointing to austerity, bin strikes and council neglect. Jenrick defended his stance, invoking government reports on ‘parallel lives’ and warnings about community integration.

articles.title: Has Kemi Badenoch sounded the death knell for one nation Conservatism?
articles.trailText: The Tory leader’s shift to the right has left its centrist wing wondering if its tradition still has a future
articles.summary: At the 2025 Tory conference in Manchester, leader Kemi Badenoch’s pledges to withdraw from the European convention on human rights and scrap the UK’s net zero target underscore a rightward shift that many see as sidelining traditional One Nation Conservatism. The One Nation caucus was quietly dissolved after Badenoch urged MPs to disband internal factions, though some maintain the tradition via a private dining club. While centrists like Damian Green and Andrew Mitchell accept tougher asylum policies, they hope a future leadership contest will restore fiscal prudence and a broader, moderate platform.

articles.title: Tories set a low bar after misspelling Britain on conference chocolate
articles.trailText: Misprinted wrappers pulled from Manchester goodie bags after derision on social media
articles.summary: At the Tory party conference in Manchester, a blue-wrapped chocolate bar in goodie bags bore the slogan "When Labour negotiates, Britian loses," signed by Kemi Badenoch. Organisers blamed a "printing error" and removed the wrapper after social media mockery. The gaffe landed amid Badenoch's bid to revive the Conservatives' dire poll ratings as she hit conference stages twice this week. Goodie bags also contained Labour's "fake CV" jibe at Rachel Reeves and a mock Reform UK manifesto. The slip-up echoes earlier misspellings: Scottish Labour's "Scotish" leaflets and Reform MP Lee Anderson as "Lee Andersin."

articles.title: Humiliation upon humiliation for the Melster in front of half-full Tory crowd | John Crace
articles.trailText: At conference where the stench of decay is overpowering, the shadow chancellor’s speech was an act of desperation
articles.summary: John Crace lambastes the half-empty Conservative party conference as a ghost town, where shadow chancellor Mel Stride delivers an irrelevant, poorly attended speech full of hollow promises—from maintaining the two-child benefit cap to sweeping benefit cuts—while struggling to engage a disinterested audience. Claire Coutinho’s subsequent energy pitch flops with a malfunctioning slideshow and radical proposals to scrap the Climate Change Act. A dreary fringe debate on the Online Safety Act, won by Toby Young, underscores the party’s existential malaise and lack of coherent strategy.

articles.title: Jonathan Powell to face MPs over role in collapse of espionage trial
articles.trailText: National security adviser to answer questions over abandonment of a major Chinese spying case against two Britons
articles.summary: Jonathan Powell, Keir Starmer’s national security adviser, will for the first time appear before the joint committee on the national security strategy to face MPs’ questions over the Crown Prosecution Service’s sudden collapse of the espionage trial against ex-parliamentary aide Christopher Cash and Christopher Berry. Chaired by Matt Western and including MPs such as Emily Thornberry and Sarah Champion alongside peers Mark Sedwill and Kate Fall, the committee will probe whether Powell’s assertion that the UK’s 2025 strategy reframed China as a “geo-strategic challenge” — not an “enemy” — undermined the evidential threshold under the Official Secrets Act. Downing Street denies any government interference. Separately, the intelligence and security committee will also review the case.

articles.title: Rachel Reeves still has plenty of options on taxation| Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Bernie Evans on ways the chancellor could pay for a cut in child poverty, Dr Alan Baker on Labour’s defining mission, Donald Third on conference expulsions and James Douet on the phrase ‘tax raid’
articles.summary: In a series of Guardian letters on Oct 6, readers challenge Chancellor Rachel Reeves to fund child-poverty cuts by raising gambling taxes, closing loopholes, equalizing capital gains and income tax rates—as even Thatcher’s government concluded—citing IFS evidence that low CGT fails to boost investment. They urge ‘historic-high’ levies on banks and landlords and council-tax reform. Others argue Labour’s defining mission should be reducing inequality rather than vague economic growth. Additional letters condemn conference expulsions of Owen Jones and Rivkah Brown as censorship and criticize labeling tax rises a ‘raid’, defending taxation as funding public services.

articles.title: Reform UK likely to raise council tax in Kent despite promise to cut costs
articles.trailText: Kent becomes latest local authority controlled by Nigel Farage’s party to signal intention to raise council tax
articles.summary: Reform UK-run Kent county council, under adult social care cabinet member Diane Morton, admits it will impose a 5% council tax rise—the maximum allowed—despite pledges to cut costs via an Elon Musk-inspired “Doge” efficiency unit. Facing a £50m shortfall on its £2.5bn budget, half earmarked for social care and SEN, the council has cut £66m debt and scrapped net-zero plans but still needs more revenue. Efforts by Zia Yusuf’s “UK Doge” team to scrutinize spending have hit data-access hurdles. Other Reform-led councils in Northamptonshire, Durham and Staffordshire flag similar tax hikes, prompting critics to warn of short-term cuts and legal challenges.

articles.title: Tories say people denied benefits in UK can return to home countries
articles.trailText: Mel Stride outlines plans to slash £47bn a year from public spending, including £23bn welfare cut
articles.summary: Shadow chancellor Mel Stride outlined Tory plans to cut £47 bn from public spending, including £23 bn in welfare by barring non-citizens—even those with indefinite leave to remain—from benefits and offering them the option to return home. Exceptions cover pensions and settled EU nationals. Work and Pensions shadow Helen Whately promised a crackdown on alleged “lifestyle” sickness claims. Further savings include £8 bn from cutting 130,000 civil service posts and £7 bn by reducing overseas aid to 0.1% of GDP, with Stride framing the measures as fiscal responsibility and upholding UK citizenship value.

articles.title: MPs’ pay watchdog to give public more of a say on how politicians are funded
articles.trailText: Ipsa’s Karen Walker says that even after recent ‘big change’ to system there is still room for potential improvement
articles.summary: New IPSA chief Karen Walker plans to give citizens a greater voice in setting MPs’ funding, after overhauling a rigid, rule-based expenses system into a flexible, principles-driven model stressing value for money, parliamentary purpose, accountability and integrity. A 23-member citizens’ forum backed fair pay—£93,904 salary plus up to £250,000 in costs—but urged benchmarking against public-sector roles, linking pay partly to household incomes and reflecting constituency needs. IPSA is now consulting on forum recommendations to boost transparency and tailored budgets.

articles.title: Badenoch says Tories open to quitting more treaties to increase deportations
articles.trailText: Party leader uses conference speech to outline proposal for UK to exit ECHR as part of wider bonfire of protections
articles.summary: Kemi Badenoch opened the Conservative conference in Manchester by proposing quitting the European Convention on Human Rights—and potentially the UN 1951 Refugee Convention—and ending legal aid and appeal rights for immigration and asylum cases. She pledged to deport unauthorized arrivals within a week to their home or third countries via a new “removals force” modelled on US ICE aiming for 150,000 expulsions a year. Shadow home secretary Chris Philp said foreign nationals promoting racial hatred or extremism would also face automatic deportation. These hard-right measures, to feature in the next Tory manifesto, pose complications for the Good Friday Agreement in Northern Ireland.

articles.title: Kemi Badenoch says she is ‘doing politics differently’ – you can’t argue with that
articles.trailText: Conservative leader has achieved the seemingly impossible: she has taken the Tories even further backwards
articles.summary: Conservative leader Kemi Badenoch’s debut conference speeches and media appearances exposed a party in freefall. On Laura Kuenssberg’s Sunday show she bristled at questions about deporting 150,000 migrants or leaving the European Court of Human Rights, dismissing practical concerns and bungling basic geography. At the party conference empty halls, Thatcher memorabilia and an AI Winston Churchill underscored a ghost-town atmosphere. Badenoch’s tone-deaf, incoherent addresses revealed no acknowledgement of past failures or coherent strategy. Yet she insists she’s “doing politics differently,” as the Tories’ fortunes slump further.

articles.title: Ministers to announce significant changes to UK’s planning system
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Differences over changes to environmental and legal provisions to prompt economic growth hint at chaos at heart of government
articles.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves plans pre-budget reforms to the UK planning system to unlock £3bn of growth by easing housebuilding and infrastructure approvals. Ministers clash over scope: some favour technical tweaks to existing legislation, others push a fresh planning bill granting automatic approvals and curbing judicial reviews. Reeves is exploring Lords amendments—limiting legal challenges, streamlining post-approval tweaks—and a separate nature bill to replace EU species lists. Downing Street, Treasury and environment teams are divided on ambition and democratic mandate, while developers and campaigners warn that ad-hoc measures risk chaos and environmental rollback.

articles.title: Tories to pledge to create immigration taskforce modelled on Trump’s Ice
articles.trailText: Proposed ‘removals force’ will be tasked with deporting 150,000 people a year in bid to tackle illegal immigration
articles.summary: Conservative leader Kemi Badenoch will unveil a “removals force” modelled on US ICE, backed by £1.6bn and sweeping powers—including surprise facial-recognition checks—to deport 150,000 people a year and conduct immigration checks during police stops. As part of a broader borders plan, asylum eligibility would be limited to those directly threatened by foreign governments, tribunals abolished, appeals and legal aid restricted, and the UK withdrawn from the European Convention on Human Rights.

articles.title: Watchdog cleared ex-Tory minister to work for offshoot of firm linked to China surveillance
articles.trailText: Acoba advised Richard Fuller he could take up post with Investcorp Securities, a subsidiary of private equity firm backing Sense Time
articles.summary: ACoBA approved ex-Tory MP Richard Fuller’s 2023 advisory board role at Investcorp Securities, the UK arm of Investcorp International, despite the parent’s stakes in Chinese AI group SenseTime—sanctioned by the US in 2021 over alleged Uyghur ethnic-profiling. Fuller, former Treasury economic secretary, earns £25k plus salary and served as interim Conservative chair in 2024. ACoBA acknowledged risks of undue influence but allowed his appointment with a two-year restriction on using privileged information or lobbying. Critics say the watchdog ignored broader ties to China Everbright and SenseTime, and is being disbanded amid reforms to post-ministerial appointment oversight.

articles.title: Next Tory leader? Rise of Katie Lam reflects rightward shift on migration
articles.trailText: Shadow Home Office minister who tweets in language of hard-right populism is talked of as future of conservatism
articles.summary: Shadow Home Office minister Katie Lam, 34, quickly emerges as a top contender to succeed Kemi Badenoch, embodying the Tory shift on migration. A state-school student turned Cambridge classicist, Goldman Sachs banker and Boris Johnson aide, Lam now channels hard-right populism on X, obsessively tweeting about asylum-seeker crime and grooming gangs. Allies frame her stance as Brexit-driven sovereignty, critics as a Damascene turn. Respected for her intellect and ambition, she faces sceptics over experience, links to the “old regime” and blue-wall voters alarmed by her Nigel-Farage-style rhetoric.

articles.title: Greens ‘on track’ to supplant Labour as favourite party in London, says Zack Polanski
articles.trailText: Exclusive: poll asked voters to rank parties on how favourably they felt about them, with strong support in capital and among younger voters
articles.summary: A YouGov poll commissioned for the Greens’ Bournemouth conference reveals they top party favourability in London (27%) and among 18–24s (36%), and hold 17% first preferences nationwide, second only to Reform UK’s 27%. Nearly a quarter of 2024 Labour voters now rate the Greens highest. Leader Zack Polanski cites council gains — three new councillors in Barking & Dagenham and a Brighton landslide — to argue the party is on track to supplant Labour. He warns a ‘managed decline’ under Keir Starmer risks ceding votes to Reform in suburban boroughs even as Greens target central London seats.

articles.title: Family firm of Reform UK council leader threatened with compulsory strike off
articles.trailText: Mansfield Carpets (Contracts) Limited faced Companies House action over four consecutive years of delayed filings
articles.summary: Mansfield Carpets (Contracts) Limited, owned by Gail Barton—wife of Reform UK Nottinghamshire council leader Mick Barton—faces a fourth consecutive compulsory strike-off threat from Companies House for late filings of its 2021–24 accounts and confirmation statements, offences rarely pursued. The two-month-late 2024 accounts follow a £497 county court judgment. Mick Barton, who resigned from a similarly named company this year, oversees operations informally. His media ban on the Nottingham Post, labelled “Trumpian” by Reach, prompted threatened legal action; the council has since lifted the embargo. Neither Mick nor Gail Barton commented.

articles.title: ‘Like going to the in-laws’: Conservative conference to be steeped in apathy
articles.trailText: As Kemi Badenoch faces a make-or-break gathering her biggest challenge will be to make herself appear relevant
articles.summary: Kemi Badenoch arrives at this weekend's Conservative conference in Manchester facing apathy not revolt. Delegates plan day trips, membership renewals sag and backbenchers joke attendance feels like visiting in-laws. MPs privately note a ticking clock on her leadership amid structural woes rather than personal failings, and few expect a serious challenge before local elections. After a policy-light year she'll unveil plans—likely pledging to leave the European human rights convention to curb immigration—while battling low polls (17-18%), Reform UK's momentum and Danny Kruger's defection. Her task: appearing relevant despite entropy in the party.

articles.title: Conservatives would take UK out of ECHR, Badenoch confirms
articles.trailText: Leader says move is is necessary ‘to protect our borders, our veterans and our citizens’
articles.summary: Kemi Badenoch has pledged that a Conservative government under her leadership would withdraw the UK from the European Convention on Human Rights, asserting the move is needed to secure borders, veterans and citizens and to remove legal barriers to deporting foreign criminals. Following a review by shadow attorney general David Wolfson, she argued that renegotiation or derogation are infeasible and that withdrawal is compatible with the Good Friday agreement and Windsor framework. Critics warn it could harm the UK’s international reputation and human rights protections. She contrasted her approach with Reform UK, criticizing Nigel Farage’s 'slapdash' proposals and stressing careful legal planning.

articles.title: Lord Howarth of Newport obituary
articles.trailText: Conservative MP and minister who crossed to the Labour benches and served in the government of Tony Blair
articles.summary: Alan Howarth, Lord Howarth of Newport (1944–2025), was a thoughtful One Nation Tory-turned-Labour MP who in 1995 became the first MP to cross directly from Conservatives to Labour. He served as schools minister (1988-90), higher education minister (1990-92), employment and disabled people minister (1997-98) and arts minister (1998-2001) under Thatcher, Major and Blair. Elected for Stratford-on-Avon (1983-95) and Newport East (1997-2005), he was known for principle over party, his advocacy for the arts and concern over democracy’s challenges. Elevated to the Lords in 2005, his memoir Begun, Continued appears posthumously.

articles.title: We are heartbroken after synagogue attack, says senior UK Jewish politician
articles.trailText: Attorney general Richard Hermer says more must be done to protect Jewish community and tackle antisemitism
articles.summary: Attorney general Richard Hermer, one of Britain’s most senior Jewish politicians, said he and the Jewish community are “heartbroken, frightened and angry” after a terror attack on a Manchester synagogue. In Jewish News, he warned of a rising tide of antisemitism and urged police protection for synagogues and schools, plus all political leaders to call out hate. He stressed the need for security measures to be accompanied by community healing. Prime Minister Keir Starmer echoed his message, promising a more visible police presence and a compassionate Britain where Jews can live and worship without fear.

articles.title: Tory chair accepted £2k hospitality from developer of HMOs for asylum seekers
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Kevin Hollinrake’s conference costs paid for by firm helping landlords convert homes for lucrative market
articles.summary: Conservative party chair Kevin Hollinrake, formerly shadow housing secretary, declared £2,000 hospitality from Living Redefined, a developer converting homes into HMOs for asylum seekers, covering flights, hotel and dinner at the MIPIM conference in Cannes. The firm claims to supply 84 properties (352 beds) to the Home Office but denies formal contracts. Critics highlight tensions between his party’s migration pledges and his acceptance of developer hospitality, amid wider debates on private outsourcing of asylum accommodation and community impact.

articles.title: Starmer will hand Britain over to Farage, says Green party leader Zack Polanski
articles.trailText: Leader tells party’s conference he is ready to take the fight to Labour and speak out in support of immigration
articles.summary: At a Bournemouth conference, new Green Party leader Zack Polanski accused Labour under Keir Starmer of ‘managed decline’ and aping Reform UK’s migration policies, warning this hands Britain to Nigel Farage. Polanski, who changed his name back to reflect his Jewish-Eastern European roots, strongly defended migration, condemned the Manchester synagogue attack and pledged to welcome migrants and refugees. He highlighted his diverse leadership team and record membership surge, promising bold policies to cut bills, curb living costs, protect the NHS and challenge disaffected Labour voters.

articles.title: Hartlepool strips Peter Mandelson of civic honour
articles.trailText: Councillors withdraw Freedom of Hartlepool award over former ambassador’s links to Jeffrey Epstein
articles.summary: Hartlepool borough councillors unanimously revoked the Freedom of Hartlepool from Lord Peter Mandelson—MP for the town (1992–2004) and former “Prince of Darkness” spin doctor—after revelations of his close friendship with convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, including supportive messages during Epstein’s 2008 prison term and a 2009 Manhattan stay. Council said the ties violated the honour’s values and risked public confidence. Sacked as UK ambassador to Washington for non-disclosure, stripped of roles in Hull and at Manchester Met, and with the Foreign Office admitting no in-depth vetting, calls mount for ministerial hearings, Keir Starmer disavowal and possible Lords expulsion.

articles.title: Rachel Reeves could raise £45bn in taxes and keep promises, report says
articles.trailText: Chancellor has ways to cover UK deficit without breaching spirit of Labour manifesto, Morgan Stanley claims
articles.summary: Morgan Stanley economists say Chancellor Rachel Reeves could raise up to £45bn in taxes to plug an expected £30bn fiscal shortfall without breaching Labour’s manifesto. They identify around £25bn of non-inflationary measures—freezing income tax thresholds, gambling levies, bank and council taxes and pension reforms—that comply with pledges, plus optional manifesto-breaking 1%-of-GDP hikes to calm gilt markets. The OBR’s imminent forecasts will shape the 26 November budget amid party warnings to uphold fiscal rules.

articles.title: Kemi Badenoch expected to announce plan to leave ECHR
articles.trailText: Move to come if Conservatives win next election and is calculated to head off growing support for Reform UK
articles.summary: Kemi Badenoch will this weekend unveil at the Manchester conference plans to quit the European Convention on Human Rights if the Conservatives win next election—a bid to stem Reform UK’s rise but one that risks alienating centrist MPs and fueling claims of a rightward lurch. In June she set up a commission to exit treaties including the ECHR and refugee convention, and she has since secured cabinet sign-off. Moderate Tories warn of damage to the Good Friday agreement and Britain’s reputation. Labour deems it a “desperate grab for relevance.” Keir Starmer is exploring tweaks to articles 3 and 8 to boost deportation powers.

articles.title: Having a digital ID will help those on low incomes | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: Sandra Coleman says many people don’t have passports or driving licences, which can make it impossible to access online government services for pensions and benefits
articles.summary: Letter by Sandra Coleman argues that reliance on passports and driving licences as photo ID for Government Gateway services—state pension, child benefit—excludes low-income individuals who often lack both documents. Though an alternative login route exists, community support workers struggle to navigate it. Coleman cites cases of parents unable to update payment details or check pension contributions despite owning smartphones. She urges implementation of an inclusive digital ID to ensure universal access to online government services.

articles.title: UK and EU poised to strike deal sparing British business from carbon border tax
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Temporary deal to shield UK exporters from levy’s impact is now viewed by both sides as likely
articles.summary: The UK and EU are set to strike a temporary deal ahead of the May/June summit shielding British exporters from the EU’s carbon border adjustment mechanism (CBAM) due Jan 2026 by aligning it with the UK’s own levy from 2027. Manufacturers of steel, glass and fertiliser would avoid extra costs and avert cheap third-country imports flooding UK markets. The pact complements emission-scheme linkage, defence-industry participation and an ambitious youth mobility scheme under a broader EU reset. Chancellor Rachel Reeves seeks to cap consumer bill hikes and red tape while aligning UK-EU emission regimes. Campaigners say it will protect jobs, investment and growth by avoiding divergence.

articles.title: Nadine Dorries is back – with her incisive thinking and deranged conspiracy theories | John Crace
articles.trailText: Dorries is a woman of no regrets for whom the past isn’t just another country, it’s a parallel universe
articles.summary: Nadine Dorries, the unapologetic ex-Tory turned Reform MP, returns in a Fourcast podcast to display “incisive thinking” and “deranged conspiracy theories.” After a chaotic conference debut where Nigel Farage had to intervene, she defends mass deportations of “illegal” migrants while confusing legal status, denies Reform’s policies are racist, accuses Keir Starmer of plotting murder, and credits Dominic Cummings with behind-the-scenes strategy. A self-styled font of “wisdom,” she lauds Boris Johnson, hints at a peerage, and dismisses inconvenient facts. In parallel, Met head Mark Rowley rejects claims of institutional racism and refuses to resign over a BBC Panorama exposé.

articles.title: Could Nigel Farage really win the next election? Here’s what the polls say
articles.trailText: Reform’s lead is persistent but pollsters themselves point out that their models come with significant uncertainty
articles.summary: Reform UK has led opinion polls since April, averaging 31% to Labour’s 21%, and latest YouGov MRP models project about 311 seats—enough to put Nigel Farage within reach of Downing Street despite falling short of an outright majority. Gains would disproportionately come at Labour’s expense due to razor-thin margins in its 2024 landslide, while multiparty dynamics lower the vote share needed per seat. Pollsters warn of significant uncertainty—82 seats hinge on margins under 5pp—and with the next election unlikely before 2028, shifts in Conservative fortunes or small poll swings could upend these projections.

articles.title: Starmer bests his conference critics but path ahead still looks perilous
articles.trailText: PM made long-awaited rallying call against Reform threat, but many in Labour still fear his shortcomings will produce a public challenge
articles.summary: At Labour’s Liverpool conference Keir Starmer delivered a tightly scripted, patriotic defence of progressive values aimed at neutralising the Reform threat, winning visible support from delegates despite stony cabinet faces. Insiders warn his leadership remains fragile: rival Andy Burnham’s warnings, simmering ministerial unease over strategic inertia and party silos, and looming electoral tests in Wales, Scotland and councils could trigger a challenge. Emerging figures like Shabana Mahmood and factional groupings signal ongoing churn ahead.

articles.title: Firms run by former diplomats and ex-Tory chief first to appear on influence register
articles.trailText: Foreign Influence Registration Scheme designed to shine light on companies paid to represent foreign states in UK
articles.summary: Three consultancies run by former British ambassadors Sir Dominick Chilcott (Groze Consulting for Bosnia and Herzegovina), Charles Crawford (CGC reSolutions for Bosnia and Herzegovina), and ex-Tory chief of staff Jonathan Lehrle (Sans Frontières Associates for the DRC) are the first to register on the UK’s Foreign Influence Registration Scheme (FIRS), launched to disclose paid foreign representation. Firms can seek opt-outs citing safety or commercial prejudice. Critics warn of loopholes and exemptions that may shield covert actors, while the government threatens up to five years’ jail for non-registration; full figures will appear in an annual Home Office report.

articles.title: Conspiracy theories and accusations fly as Labour’s Farage fever rattles Reform | John Crace
articles.trailText: Fearless Nige and his mates’ unhinged reaction to Starmer’s speech suggests he can dish it out but he can’t take it
articles.summary: At Labour’s conference keynote, Keir Starmer devoted an hour to Nigel Farage, framing Reform’s immigration policies as racist and drawing a clear line between decency and division. Rather than relish the attention, Farage appeared rattled and his party’s press officer Zia Yusuf escalated matters on Sky News, accusing Starmer of "stochastic terrorism"—an alleged plot to incite a supporter to assassinate Farage—and claiming the government deliberately cut Farage’s security to facilitate his killing. Yusuf’s unqualified, inflammatory rhetoric overshadowed the final day’s proceedings, leaving a ghost town hall for Ed Miliband and Shabana Mahmood’s wrap-up speeches.

articles.title: Labour must avoid half measures on the two-child benefit cap | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Readers react to a report that Labour is considering alternatives to completely scrapping the cap on child benefit and other news from the Labour party conference
articles.summary: Critics in Guardian letters slam Labour for considering only a partial repeal of the two-child benefit cap, branding it cruel, discriminatory and a betrayal of pledges to end child poverty, as it upholds George Osborne’s means-testing approach and hollows out Keir Starmer’s vow of “no child hungry.” They call for an immediate, unconditional lift of the cap. Additional letters debate Labour conference imagery—from Union Jacks replacing red roses to anthem proposals—and warn that without grassroots unity and clear policy shifts, a rightward drift risks ceding ground to Reform UK, especially under proposed proportional representation.

articles.title: Environmentalists rely on the Aarhus convention – Britain mustn’t ditch it | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Responding to a report about the planning bill, Keith Garner writes that the legal challenge he brought would not have been possible without Aarhus. Plus, a letter by Robbie Owen
articles.summary: Letters warn that abandoning the Aarhus convention – embedded in English law – would strip cost protection (capped at £5,000) for public judicial reviews of environmental decisions. Keith Garner cites his 2010 Elmbridge council challenge against Thames flood-plain flats as only possible under Aarhus. Parliamentary agent Robbie Owen proposes reviving a provisional order procedure for nationally significant infrastructure via a one-clause, 4–8-month parliamentary confirmation bill, offering faster, non-reviewable consent if adopted in early 2026.

articles.title: Arbitrary detention victims urge Starmer to press Modi on jailed British Sikh
articles.trailText: Activist Jagtar Singh Johal has been held in Indian prison for nearly eight years without full trial
articles.summary: British Sikh activist Jagtar Singh Johal from Dumbarton, held by India's National Investigation Agency since 2017 without conviction in nine terrorism cases, was acquitted in March 2025 of one but still faces death penalty on a torture-extracted confession. His prison conditions worsened to near-total solitary confinement and he endures eight duplicate cases violating double jeopardy. Mona and Sanaa Seif (sisters of freed detainee Alaa Abd el-Fattah), with Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, Matthew Hedges and other arbitrary-detention survivors, in letters coordinated by Redress, urge UK PM Keir Starmer to press Narendra Modi at next week's visit, warning Johal's plight threatens UK-India relations.

articles.title: Labour members feel disconnected from government, says Lucy Powell
articles.trailText: Deputy leadership candidate tells hustings party is not heeding feedback from doorstep, with impact on activists
articles.summary: At Labour conference Lucy Powell argues members feel disconnected and demotivated as grassroots feedback is ignored by an isolated leadership. She positions herself as an independent “shop steward” and full-time party officer to channel community input. Rival Bridget Phillipson, backed by Keir Starmer, cautions that Powell’s approach risks division and urges unity to drive bolder government reforms. The deputy leadership contest, triggered by Angela Rayner’s resignation, sees a member ballot from 8–23 October, with polls suggesting Powell leads among activists.

articles.title: ‘Reverse Midas touch’: Starmer plan prompts collapse in support for digital IDs
articles.trailText: Net public backing for scheme has fallen to -14% after prime minister’s announcement, according to polling
articles.summary: Public backing for Starmer’s digital ID scheme plunged from a net +35% in early summer to –14% after his announcement, with support falling from 53% to 31% and opposition rising from 19% to 45%, according to More in Common. Over 2.6m have signed against it. The collapse is tied to his record-low approval (net –66%). Critics warn the plan may be “dead in the water” without a stronger case. Proposed smartphone-based photo IDs would prove the right to work and later store health and benefits data. Reform UK opposes it; Conservatives call it a gimmick.

articles.title: Nigel Farage: what are schoolboy racism claims – and why have they resurfaced?
articles.trailText: David Lammy has clarified remarks that the Reform leader ‘flirted with Hitler Youth’. Here is the background to the row
articles.summary: Deputy PM David Lammy’s recent remark that Nigel Farage “once flirted with Hitler Youth” has reignited long-standing schoolboy racism allegations first reported by Channel 4 News and detailed in Michael Crick’s 2022 book. A 1970s Dulwich College teacher’s letter claimed Farage marched at cadet camps singing Nazi songs and voiced antisemitic slurs; former classmates cited racist chants and NF graffiti. Other alumni and staff dispute these recollections, while college authorities labelled him a cheeky prefect, not a racist. Farage insists teenage taunts were harmless banter. Lammy accepted his denial, urging focus on policy over personalities.

articles.title: At least a third of EU citizens in UK report discrimination by public bodies
articles.trailText: Long-term residents post Brexit also say they have faced difficulties exercising travel and equal treatment rights
articles.summary: An IMA survey of long-term EU/EEA/EFTA residents five years post-Brexit finds over one-third experienced discrimination by UK public bodies and 20% struggled to exercise rights to work, travel and equal access to services. Awareness of Withdrawal Agreement rights is rising, but 39% haven’t secured settled status for children—often assuming automatic citizenship—and 25% report unrecognised professional qualifications. Trust in public bodies stands at 61% (lower among over-65s). Respondents urge the IMA to ensure worry-free travel, adequate support and protection for future generations. The Home Office asserts broad compliance through the EU Settlement Scheme, noting only 9% of respondents engaged with it.

articles.title: Starmer brings the steel – and draws up battle lines with Reform UK
articles.trailText: Prime minister answers his critics in conference speech but the real challenges still lie ahead
articles.summary: Facing leadership doubts, Prime Minister Keir Starmer used the Labour conference in Liverpool to sharpen his narrative, challenging Nigel Farage’s surge with Reform UK and pitching a binary choice of “decency or division, renewal or decline.” Flanked by union flags, he reclaimed patriotic symbolism, energised his MPs and drew clear battle lines for the next election. While critics noted policy details were sparse, the speech projected steeliness under pressure and granted Starmer much-needed breathing space. Yet with a demanding autumn budget and looming May local elections, his ability to convert momentum into votes remains uncertain.

articles.title: ‘Decency or division’: Britain faces era-defining choice, Keir Starmer warns
articles.trailText: Prime minister lambasts Nigel Farage and the politics of Reform in combative Labour conference speech
articles.summary: Keir Starmer warns UK faces an era-defining fork—"decency or division"—as he pits Labour against Nigel Farage’s populist Reform UK in a combative conference address in Liverpool. Accusing Farage of lacking belief in Britain, Starmer cast Labour as the patriotic party offering renewal while denouncing the politics of grievance and rising racism. Though light on detail, he flagged tough autumn budget choices—ruling out a wealth tax, eyeing up to £30bn in fiscal adjustments, and lifting the two-child benefit cap. He also pledged to scrap the 50% university target in favor of higher technical and apprenticeship goals and launch an NHS online hospital service.

articles.title: It’s entered the Labour conference lexicon – but what is a snake-oil salesman?
articles.trailText: The party seems particularly keen to associate the term, which dates back to the 19th century, with Nigel Farage
articles.summary: At the Labour conference in Liverpool, Keir Starmer, Darren Jones and Wes Streeting labeled Reform UK leader Nigel Farage a “snake-oil salesman,” reviving a 19th-century US term for charlatans whose wares fail to deliver. The term’s resurgence underscores Labour’s strategy to depict Farage as a deceptive populist profiting from division. They linked him to Andrew Tate–style misogyny and anti-vax disinformation, and Nicola Sturgeon echoed the label at Wigtown. The original snake-oil seller, Clark Stanley, sold a bogus joint-pain ointment of mineral oil, beef fat, chili extract and turpentine, escaping major backlash with just a $20 fine.

articles.title: Starmer finally finds his voice as he speaks from the heart  | John Crace
articles.trailText: PM sounded like a decent man making the case for decency – it’s just not clear if that’s what the British public demands of its politicians these days
articles.summary: At Labour’s conference speech billed as make-or-break, PM Keir Starmer overcame a stilted start—complete with underwhelming flag-waving and repetitive personal anecdotes—to deliver an earnest, mid-speech surge that resonated. He championed decency and patriotism, pitched gold-star apprenticeships over mass university intake, and mounted a nuanced challenge to the populist right—directly criticizing Nigel Farage, Liz Truss and Boris Johnson—and pledged compassionate yet firm border controls. While delegates cheered the final half hour, questions remain whether decency alone can sway a public in a post-truth era.

articles.title: Labour won’t fend off Reform UK by just diluting Farage’s poison | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: The party must not offer a watered-down version of Reform’s policies, but instead tell the truth about immigrants, writes Guy Fassler . Plus letters from Doug Maughan , Sunil Bhopal and Dr Roger Hancock
articles.summary: Four letters argue Labour’s immigration pitch echoes Reform UK’s xenophobia, differing only in severity. Guy Fassler criticises Starmer for normalising anti-immigrant rhetoric and urges a truthful narrative: immigrants face high costs to enter the UK, subsidise universities, contribute to the NHS and labour market but lack welfare access. Doug Maughan, ex-Labour candidate, rejects Starmer’s “less racist” stance, accusing him of further shifting right. Sunil Bhopal warns framing ethnic minorities as “them” alienates 18% of voters. Dr Roger Hancock cautions that calling Reform an “enemy” risks polarising potential supporters. Contributors demand policy clarity, inclusive language and focus on real social issues rather than scapegoating immigrants.

articles.title: Nigel Farage ‘doesn’t believe in Britain’, Starmer tells Labour conference
articles.trailText: Prime minister says choice is between ‘decency or division, renewal or decline’, amid rise of Reform UK
articles.summary: At Labour's Liverpool conference, Prime Minister Keir Starmer framed Britain as at a defining fork: a patriotic Labour-led renewal versus Nigel Farage's Reform UK-driven 'division and decline.' Starmer accused Farage—'a snake oil merchant who doesn't believe in Britain'—of crossing a moral line on immigration, inciting racist violence and deportation threats, and vowed to fight anyone denying non-white Britons' belonging. He acknowledged Labour's past elitism and globalisation's failures, struck a more optimistic tone after earlier 'island of strangers' remarks, and touted government wins—from steel nationalisation and renters' protections to education reforms—while warning of tough budget choices ahead.

articles.title: Nigel Farage a ‘snake oil salesman’ comparable to Andrew Tate, says No 10 chief secretary
articles.trailText: Ministers signal Labour will take stronger approach to attacking Reform rather than just ‘respond to crazy things they’re saying’
articles.summary: Darren Jones, No 10 chief secretary, compared Nigel Farage to Andrew Tate, calling him a 'snake oil salesman' leading working-class boys down a dark path with hate, division and anti-establishment rhetoric. At a Labour Together fringe event, Jones pledged a 'muscular' campaign to proactively confront Reform UK’s anti-BBC, NHS and anti-science agenda and its proposal to revoke migrants’ indefinite leave to remain. Health secretary Wes Streeting echoed the criticism, denouncing Reform’s anti-vax adviser. Starmer labels Reform’s immigration cuts racist; Farage protests.

articles.title: NHS ‘online hospital’ plan announced to help cut waiting lists in England
articles.trailText: NHS experts welcome ambition of scheme due to launch in 2027 but some raise questions about how it will work
articles.summary: Announced by Keir Starmer at Labour’s Liverpool conference, NHS Online is a ‘virtual hospital’ due from 2027 allowing GP-referred patients in England to consult specialists via phone or video, aiming to slash waiting lists and expedite first appointments nationwide. Building on digital triage pilots – notably Southampton’s remote IBD follow-up which cut consultant visits by 73% and wait times by 58% – it will expand the NHS app (38.5m downloads). Initially covering select conditions, it remains voluntary alongside in-person visits. Experts applaud the ambition but urge clarity on staffing, digital exclusion, data integration and risks of destabilising traditional outpatient services.

articles.title: Keir Starmer to tell Labour conference growth is the ‘antidote to division’
articles.trailText: In a combative speech, the prime minister will pledge to raise living standards and ‘face down’ threats of a volatile world
articles.summary: At Labour conference in Liverpool, Starmer defends his economic strategy as 'antidote to division', pledging growth that lifts living standards from grassroots, unites communities and counters populist threats. He vows to boost growth, improve incomes and face global volatility, while reasserting authority amid internal calls for radicalism. Chancellor Reeves warns of tough budget choices, potential £30bn tax rises or cuts, gambling tax hike and strict fiscal rules; Mayor Burnham urges targeted investment. Home Secretary Mahmood signals tougher small boats measures, hinting at human rights adjustments. Starmer frames a 'defining choice' of decency vs division, evoking 1945 post-war renewal while warning of hard decisions ahead.

articles.title: Shabana Mahmood calls Nigel Farage ‘worse than racist’ over ‘dog-whistle politics’
articles.trailText: Home secretary also tells Labour conference fringe event of the abuse her family have been subjected to recently
articles.summary: Home Secretary Shabana Mahmood accused Reform leader Nigel Farage of “worse than racist” dog-whistle politics at a Liverpool fringe event, linking his plan to reassess indefinite leave to remain with a surge in racial abuse—including recent slurs against her own family in Birmingham. Warning Britain risks sliding into ethno-nationalism, she urged Labour to tackle immigration responsibly and pledged to “do whatever it takes” to curb Channel crossings. Mahmood is exploring new curbs on settlement claims from 2021-24’s “Boriswave” visas.

articles.title: Andy Burnham hits back at Labour critics over challenge to Starmer
articles.trailText: Greater Manchester mayor says he wants conference dominated by leadership speculation to be a success
articles.summary: Greater Manchester mayor Andy Burnham has hit back at Labour critics accusing him of plotting a leadership bid against Keir Starmer at the party conference. He insists he cannot run while serving as mayor, rejects disloyalty claims and defends his economic proposals—rewriting fiscal rules to boost investment, abolishing the two-child benefit cap, introducing a land value tax and reviewing council tax. Burnham also challenged Chancellor Rachel Reeves’s debt interest warnings, dismissed Alan Johnson’s critique, urged postponing digital ID cards and voiced his backing for the UK rejoining the EU.

articles.title: Labour must fight rightwing billionaires undermining net zero, says Ed Miliband
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Energy secretary will hit out at the Tory and Reform ‘culture war’ and unveil target of 400,000 new jobs in clean energy
articles.summary: Energy secretary Ed Miliband warns that a global network of rightwing billionaires, aided by the Tories and Reform UK’s imported net zero culture war, seeks to undermine the green transition. He pledges a Green New Deal with 400,000 new clean energy jobs by 2030 across engineering, construction and research, backed by a fair worker charter mandating pay, flexible contracts and union access. He’ll fund skills transfers for oil and gas workers into offshore wind, accelerate sector unionisation and challenge misleading attacks from Reform, framing net zero as vital for working people and future generations.

articles.title: Andy Burnham, the Schrödinger’s cat of the Labour party conference | John Crace
articles.trailText: Both there and not there, no minister dares mention his name but he’s etched on to everyone’s subconscious
articles.summary: At Labour’s annual conference in Liverpool, Andy Burnham was the Schrödinger’s cat—officially absent from the main stage but omnipresent in fringe events and political chatter. He denies any imminent leadership bid, despite interviews and reports fueling speculation. Burnham’s strengths—warm storytelling, policy pitches like cheaper transport fares, social housing investment and elastic fiscal rules—contrast with the cautious tone of party leadership. Working on Hillsborough law behind the scenes, he insists he’s committed to Manchester re-election but his profile and charm position him as a ready alternative should Labour stumble in next year’s regional polls.

articles.title: Mixed feelings on Labour’s plan for mandatory digital ID | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Readers on whether the proposed scheme would be useful or just a tool for state control
articles.summary: Letters on Labour’s compulsory digital ID plan split between defenders of British unwritten constitution, citing risk of state surveillance and loss of citizen autonomy, and supporters highlighting convenience for voting, everyday bureaucracy and immigration controls. Contributors recall Tony Blair’s 2006 Identity Cards Act and Theresa May’s repeal, warn about centralised biometric database security and smartphone vulnerabilities, question efficacy against illegal migration, and compare with French and Spanish physical ID systems. A former IT director urges accurate technical explanation. The debate underscores constitutional, civil liberties and practical trade-offs in Starmer’s proposal.

articles.title: Labour conference backs motion saying Israel is committing genocide in Gaza
articles.trailText: Union-led call for tougher action by government passes, as more cautious alternative proposed by leadership fails
articles.summary: At the 2025 Labour conference, unions led by Unison and Aslef passed an emergency motion accepting a UN finding that Israel is committing genocide in Gaza, urging the UK government to “employ all means reasonably available” to prevent it, suspend the arms trade and partnership agreement, and bar UK entities from aiding the genocide. The affiliate-backed motion beat a leadership-backed alternative referencing only a “risk” of genocide, reflecting deep party tensions over Palestine debates, delayed official UK genocide risk assessments and mounting calls for tougher sanctions.

articles.title: Rachel Reeves unapologetic on her fiscal rules while talking up investment
articles.trailText: Conference speech sets out likely Labour economic argument at next general election and pitch to party
articles.summary: At Labour’s Liverpool conference, chancellor Rachel Reeves drew a clear divide with the Conservatives and Reform UK, championing an “invest or decline” strategy. She highlighted early wins—£29bn for the NHS, school breakfast clubs, new transport links and 2,000 extra GPs—and proactive industry support from Sizewell C to Jaguar Land Rover, steel and shipbuilding. Reeves defended her fiscal rules and planned November tax rises as vital for stability, rejected calls (eg Andy Burnham) to loosen them, and positioned Labour as the party of working people ahead of the next election.

articles.title: Reeves warns Labour figures against ‘peddling idea’ of ditching fiscal rules
articles.trailText: Chancellor tells party conference that higher borrowing to pay for public services risks serious damage to the economy
articles.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves at Labour conference rebuked calls—particularly aimed at Andy Burnham—to abandon fiscal rules for more spending, warning such ‘reckless economic choices’ risk market turmoil akin to Liz Truss’s crisis. She stressed honesty on borrowing costs, defended her ‘securonomics’ investment strategy, signaled possible tweaks to OBR forecasting, and hinted at up to £30bn of tax rises or cuts ahead. Reeves urged unity against Reform UK’s pessimism, vowed steadfast fiscal responsibility ahead of next month’s budget, and announced new libraries, youth jobs guarantee and EU mobility scheme plans.

articles.title: Rachel Reeves confirms she no longer stands by pledge not to raise taxes
articles.trailText: Chancellor says ‘world has changed’ and UK not immune to effects of wars, US tariffs and higher borrowing costs
articles.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves has abandoned her 2024 pledge against raising taxes, citing global conflicts, US tariffs and higher borrowing costs. Speaking before the Labour conference in Liverpool, she signalled VAT will remain unchanged in the November budget to shield working families and upheld manifesto commitments. Reeves criticised premature budget speculation as irresponsible. On immigration, she backed Keir Starmer’s labelling of Reform UK’s plan to strip settled migrants’ rights as “racist”, distinguishing that policy from measures targeting those without legal residency.

articles.title: Britain may already be at war with Russia, former head of MI5 says
articles.trailText: Eliza Manningham-Buller points to extent of cyber-attacks and other hostile activity orchestrated by Moscow
articles.summary: Eliza Manningham-Buller, who led MI5 from 2002–07, warns that the scale of Russian cyber-attacks, sabotage, intelligence gathering and physical assaults on UK soil amount to a novel form of warfare, echoing Russia expert Fiona Hill’s view. She highlights convictions this year of a Bulgarian spy ring and an arson plot targeting Ukraine supplies, plus suspected Russian hacking of British businesses and unarmed drones violating NATO airspace. Reflecting on her 2005 meeting with Putin and the Litvinenko poisoning, she also criticizes recent UK and US aid cuts for creating diplomatic openings that China is poised to exploit, underscoring the value of sustained soft power.

articles.title: Stop blaming migrants and tackle UK’s real problems, 100 charities tell home secretary
articles.trailText: A letter warns Shabana Mahmood that ‘targeting refugees will do nothing to tackle’ problems with housing and the NHS
articles.summary: Before her Labour conference speech, home secretary Shabana Mahmood was urged by 105 charities—including Save the Children, Mind, Oxfam, Shelter, Greenpeace and the PCS union—to stop scapegoating migrants and focus on housing shortages, NHS underfunding, extreme inequality and the climate emergency. In a Refugee Action-coordinated letter, signatories warn that targeting refugees is a ‘dangerous smokescreen’ that deepens community divisions, citing violent anti-asylum protests and a far-right rally of up to 150,000. They call on the government to collaborate with local authorities, charities and refugees to find lasting solutions.

articles.title: High standard of English to be required for leave to remain, Mahmood to pledge
articles.trailText: Home secretary to set out proposed tougher conditions including not taking benefits and ‘spotless’ criminal record
articles.summary: Labour home secretary Shabana Mahmood will propose requiring indefinite leave to remain (ILR) applicants to demonstrate a high standard of English, a spotless criminal record, continuous national insurance contributions or voluntary work, and no reliance on benefits, with settlement delayed up to a decade for those who fall short. The package, in direct response to Reform UK’s plan to scrap ILR for non-EU migrants, includes fast‐track routes for high contributors and a public consultation later this year. Keir Starmer condemned Nigel Farage’s approach as ‘racist’, while the Refugee Council warned tougher benefit restrictions risk undermining refugee integration.

articles.title: Rachel Reeves pledges a library in every primary school in England
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Chancellor also set to unveil plans to get young people back into work in party conference speech
articles.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves will pledge a library in every one of the 1,700 English primaries currently without one, funded by £132.5 m of dormant assets to boost early literacy, especially in disadvantaged areas, in her Labour conference speech. Authors including Cressida Cowell and Axel Scheffler welcomed the plan. Reeves will also announce a youth guarantee: young universal credit claimants out of work or education for 18 months will be guaranteed paid work or face benefit sanctions, underscoring her “contribution” theme and commitment to abolish long-term youth unemployment.

articles.title: Starmer decries Reform’s ‘racist’ plans as ministers escalate attacks on Farage
articles.trailText: PM says immigration proposals could tear country apart as Labour delegates gather for first day of party conference
articles.summary: Keir Starmer condemned Reform UK’s proposal to revoke indefinite leave to remain as racist and immoral, warning it would tear the country apart. Speaking at Labour’s conference in Liverpool, he and senior ministers including Rachel Reeves and Shabana Mahmood escalated attacks on Nigel Farage’s immigration platform, pledging to toughen legal migration and crackdown on illegal crossings. Labour HQ will deploy targeted canvassing of non-voters, emphasising NHS and cost-of-living issues to reclaim disaffected voters drawn to Reform. Shabana Mahmood will unveil new integration criteria for settlement, while the party vows unity against Reform’s policies ahead of the next election.

articles.title: Andy Burnham says ‘climate of fear’ in Labour is shutting down debate
articles.trailText: Greater Manchester mayor calls for change as he continues criticism of party under Starmer at conference fringe event
articles.summary: Greater Manchester mayor Andy Burnham has accused Labour of a 'climate of fear' that stifles debate, defending his public calls for a more open discussion on policy and leadership ahead of next May’s election. He revealed MPs had pressed him to challenge for the party leadership and openly questioned Chancellor Rachel Reeves’s economic strategy. Speaking at a fringe event, he challenged suspensions over minor infractions, warned against demands for blind loyalty and criticised the government's approach. Burnham’s remarks—seen as a direct challenge to Sir Keir Starmer—have drawn ire from No 10, cabinet ministers and senior MPs, who fear they risk undermining party unity.

articles.title: Ed Miliband says it is ‘possible’ that UK government should leave X
articles.trailText: Energy minister says platform’s owner Elon Musk is a ‘dangerous man’ who is part of a ‘global network of right’
articles.summary: Labour energy minister Ed Miliband said at a fringe conference event it may be “possible” for the UK government to quit Elon Musk’s social network X, branding Musk a “dangerous” figure in a global far-right billionaire network that includes Nigel Farage. He cited Musk’s failure to curb disinformation, his appearance at a Tommy Robinson rally calling for government overthrow and incitements to violence. Miliband noted growing defections by Labour figures, criticised Reform Party’s climate denial, affirmed Keir Starmer’s leadership and ruled out his own Labour leadership bid.

articles.title: What a difference a year makes as Labour conference delegates settle for survival
articles.trailText: ‘The atmosphere is like Dignitas on the Mersey,’ said one MP, but the mood was lifted by Starmer’s tough words for Reform
articles.summary: At this year’s Liverpool Labour conference, delegates voiced low morale—survival rather than ambition—contrasting last year’s post-victory optimism. With Reform polling 10 points ahead and Starmer’s personal ratings at record lows, party goals narrowed to unity. In a revealing BBC interview he pivoted from technocratic talking points to sharply accuse Reform of racism over mass deportations, restoring some swagger. Fringe events saw censorship anxieties, while main speeches remained flat—save Steve Reed’s cheer for Angela Rayner—and Anthony Albanese urging debate diversity.

articles.title: Starmer calling Reform ‘racist’ risks backlash while staking Labour’s moral claim
articles.trailText: Labour MPs and members are relieved to hear him speak so unequivocally, but expect criticism from the right
articles.summary: In a BBC interview ahead of Labour’s conference speech, Keir Starmer branded Reform UK’s pledge to end indefinite leave to remain as “racist” and “immoral”, marking a deliberate escalation from previous “divisive” labels. Allies, relieved by his unequivocal stance, warn of a fierce backlash from rightwing media and Reform’s supporters, citing mixed-messaging risks. They argue the policy would uproot long-settled families—often in public-sector roles or without dual-citizenship options. Starmer plans a high-stakes speech balancing empathy for voter anger with a moral call to defend progressive values, while also proposing retrospective tightening of indefinite-leave rules—a move critics say could undercut his fairness argument.

articles.title: Populist threat to rule of law a danger to UK working class, says attorney general
articles.trailText: Richard Hermer aims criticism at Nigel Farage and Robert Jenrick at Labour conference event
articles.summary: At the Labour conference fringe in Liverpool, Attorney General Richard Hermer warned that rightwing populists Nigel Farage, Robert Jenrick and Reform MP Richard Tice are undermining the rule of law and eroding working-class legal protections. He cited Jenrick’s prejudicial tweet in a murder trial, Tice’s endorsement of vigilante patrols and Farage’s defence of inflammatory rhetoric as examples of attacks on courts, judges and the Human Rights Act. Speaking at a UCL policy lab event, Hermer argued that rights laws champion everyday justice, condemned rising threats to lawyers, and rejected claims he blocks human-rights reform.

articles.title: Keir Starmer’s donkey field: what are the allegations and how has he responded?
articles.trailText: PM denies putting land he bought for his parents into a trust, after report claims he may have done to avoid inheritance tax
articles.summary: Faced with claims by the Sunday Times that he may have placed the £20,000 donkey field he bought for his parents into a trust to avoid inheritance tax, Keir Starmer has categorically denied creating any trust. He says he bought the land in 1996 so his ailing mother could see her donkeys, ‘gifting’ its use without transferring legal title, later sold it in 2022 for nearly £300,000, and apologised for failing to declare it sooner. Starmer has since retained a tax KC to confirm all liabilities were correctly met and Downing Street insists his only concern was his parents’ wellbeing.

articles.title: UK government urged to restore Electoral Commission’s independence to protect democracy
articles.trailText: Oversight of watchdog could be abused by a future authoritarian government, report warns
articles.summary: Spotlight on Corruption’s Democracy in Danger report warns ministerial oversight of the Electoral Commission, imposed by Boris Johnson in 2022, breaches eight international standards and risks abuse by future authoritarian administrations. The UK now ranks 44th in electoral autonomy, below Ghana, Nepal and Croatia. Labour’s draft elections bill tightens foreign donation rules but stops short of restoring full independence. Peers could reverse Johnson’s changes in the Lords. The report calls for statutory autonomy, legal safeguards and added lay members on the Speaker’s Committee. Govt maintains the Commission remains operationally independent.

articles.title: ‘A serious disappointment’: Labour has to regain business sector’s confidence at conference
articles.trailText: After being promised last year they could ‘partner’ with party on policy, many executives are asking what happened
