articles.summary: At last year’s Liverpool business day, Keir Starmer pledged to ‘partner’ with industry and let executives shape policy, but after a year of tax hikes—most pointedly Rachel Reeves’s surprise £25bn NIC increase—slow growth, high inflation and rising unemployment, business leaders like Stuart Rose and Andrew Higginson call Labour a ‘serious disappointment.’ As the 2025 conference returns to Merseyside, bosses fear more tax rises in the November budget, grumble about ticket hikes and policy delays (eg Northern Powerhouse Rail), even as Labour touts infrastructure wins and fresh investment pledges.

articles.title: Plan to build 12 new towns in England to be unveiled at Labour conference
articles.trailText: Housing secretary is set to announce initiative modelled on Clement Attlee’s postwar ‘housing boom’
articles.summary: At Labour’s 2025 conference in Liverpool, housing secretary Steve Reed will unveil a plan to build 12 new towns across England, modelled on Attlee’s postwar housing boom. The new towns taskforce, set up last year, proposes sites such as Tempsford, Crews Hill and Leeds South Bank, each delivering at least 10,000 homes plus schools, GP surgeries, green spaces and transport. With public and private funding, the scheme aims to deliver up to 300,000 homes over decades—40% affordable, 20% social—and underpins Labour’s pledge to build 1.5 million homes before the next election.

articles.title: Scottish Labour MSP suspended over inappropriate conduct allegation
articles.trailText: Foysol Choudhury, who represents Lothian, will sit as an independent while an investigation takes place
articles.summary: Scottish Labour MSP Foysol Choudhury, Lothian representative since 2021, has been administratively suspended over an allegation of inappropriate conduct. He will sit as an independent while the party conducts a formal investigation under its rules. This follows the unrelated suspension and charges against MSP Colin Smyth. SNP MP Kirsty Blackman and Scottish Conservative deputy leader Rachael Hamilton have urged leader Anas Sarwar to disclose reasons for Choudhury’s suspension ahead of the Scottish Labour conference. Choudhury, chair of the Edinburgh and Lothians Regional Equality Council and vice-chair of the Edinburgh Mela festival, has not publicly responded.

articles.title: ‘I refuse to be defined by fascism’: daughter of murder victim speaks after death of neo-Nazi killer in prison
articles.trailText: After the man who killed her father is found dead in his cell, Maz Saleem reflects on living with loss and choosing not to hate
articles.summary: Maz Saleem, youngest of seven, forgives Pavlo Lapshyn, the neo-Nazi who murdered her father, 82-year-old community leader Mohammed Saleem, and planted bombs outside mosques in 2013. Despite initial rage, she rejects hatred’s power and calls for unity against rising far-right violence. Responding to Lapshyn’s death in Wakefield prison, she urges Britain to treat extremist attacks as terrorism—protect worship places, fund counter-extremism programs and support victims long-term. In her father’s name, she campaigns for justice, solidarity and peace.

articles.title: Education unions urge Keir Starmer to scrap ‘cruel’ two-child benefit cap
articles.trailText: A letter to the prime minister on the eve of the Labour conference warns of ‘critical need’ to abandon the policy
articles.summary: Six major education unions – the NGA, NAHT, ASCL, NEU, NASUWT and Unison – have written to Keir Starmer urging him to scrap the two-child benefit cap ahead of Labour conference, calling the 2017 policy “cruel” and warning it harms children’s learning and well-being. The Resolution Foundation estimates lifting the cap could remove 470,000 children from poverty. With growing speculation, Education Secretary Bridget Phillipson has said abolition is “on the table,” over 100 Labour MPs back change, and the government promises an ambitious child poverty strategy.

articles.title: Labour seeks ‘ambitious’ youth mobility scheme with EU
articles.trailText: Chancellor says plan would allow thousands of young Europeans to temporarily live and work in UK, and vice versa
articles.summary: Labour chancellor Rachel Reeves proposes an ambitious youth mobility scheme with the EU enabling hundreds of thousands of 18–30-year-olds to live, work, volunteer or study reciprocally in Britain and Europe. She argues it will boost growth, trade and skills, and has asked the OBR to include its effects in forecasts ahead of her November budget. Facing up to £30 bn in fiscal tightening, Reeves ruled out a wealth tax, favouring existing inheritance and capital-gains levies. She also rejected Andy Burnham’s borrowing-financed nationalisation plans as a risky re-run of Truss’s mini-budget fiasco.

articles.title: Starmer asks Conservative peer to write planning bill to block judicial reviews
articles.trailText: Exclusive: One option could be to leave treaty that allows legal claims against projects such as Heathrow expansion
articles.summary: Labour leader Keir Starmer has commissioned Conservative peer Charles Banner KC to draft a planning bill aimed at curbing environmental judicial reviews—particularly expensive legal challenges that have delayed projects like Heathrow’s third runway. Ministers are considering withdrawing from the 1998 Aarhus convention, which caps claimants’ costs and ensures public rights to sue, to fast-track nationally significant infrastructure. Chancellor Rachel Reeves sees this as vital for economic growth before the next election. Planning lawyers warn that ditching Aarhus would undermine constitutional safeguards and silence legitimate objections.

articles.title: Keir Starmer to warn Labour that battle with Reform is ‘fight for soul of the nation’
articles.trailText: Exclusive: PM says history will not forgive his government if it fails to confront and defeat the populist right
articles.summary: Speaking ahead of Labour's conference in Liverpool, PM Keir Starmer framed the contest with Reform UK as a "fight for the soul of the nation," warning against introspection and urging unity behind a vision of "patriotic national renewal." He pledged to confront populist leader Nigel Farage's party head-on, defend scientific institutions, and reclaim patriotism, while retaining fiscal discipline and considering lifting the two-child benefit cap to cut child poverty. Dismissing leadership speculation around Andy Burnham and Jeremy Corbyn's grievance politics, Starmer underlined his determination to lead Labour into the next election and introduce a mandatory digital ID by 2029.

articles.title: More than 1.6m sign petition opposing Starmer’s plan for digital ID cards
articles.trailText: Opponents of scheme for people working in UK describe it as a ‘step towards mass surveillance and digital control’
articles.summary: Over 1.6m have backed a petition rejecting PM Keir Starmer’s 2029 digital ID card mandate for UK workers, decrying it as state-controlled mass surveillance. Although petitions over 100k trigger parliamentary debate, they rarely alter policy (eg. 6m for Brexit reversal). Starmer touts the Brit card as bolstering border security, curbing illegal work and streamlining service access, while Big Brother Watch warns it risks domestic spying and data breaches. Culture secretary Nandy rejects fears of a dystopia. Conservative leader Kemi Badenoch and Reform UK’s Nigel Farage denounce it as unwarranted state control unlikely to curb illegal migration.

articles.title: ‘A hacker’s dream’: Britons on Keir Starmer’s plan for digital ID cards
articles.trailText: Views range from concerns over civil liberties and cybersecurity, to welcoming it as a helpful system to streamline services
articles.summary: Labour leader Keir Starmer is set to introduce a mandatory digital ID for UK work rights. Eight Britons offer contrasting views: Rory warns of data misuse and mass surveillance; Paul praises EU-style streamlined services; Anna calls it a hacker’s dream; Thomas fears forced smartphone reliance; Alexander doubts Whitehall’s IT expertise and warns of US tech intrusion; Dani condemns it as a redundant migrant-focused gimmick; while Neil, long-term France resident, applauds its everyday utility. Concerns range from civil liberties and cybersecurity to digital sovereignty, bureaucratic complexity and mental-health impacts.

articles.title: ‘There are ripples of hope’: allies of Keir Starmer say he can prove doubters wrong
articles.trailText: At Labour conference the PM needs to draw a line under the chaos and prove he is best placed to challenge Reform UK
articles.summary: In the critical Labour conference in Liverpool, PM Keir Starmer must quell internal dissent and counter Nigel Farage’s Reform UK surge after a rocky start to autumn marked by overshadowed policy launches and resignations. Facing poll deficits and challenges from within—Andy Burnham’s hinted leadership bid and a contentious deputy leadership race—he’ll pitch “patriotic renewal,” refreshed levelling-up funds, and a unifying vision to contrast Reform’s grievance politics. Allies insist his most political speech can restore hope before a budget that threatens tough economic choices.

articles.title: Labour restores whip to two more child benefit cap rebels
articles.trailText: John McDonnell and Apsana Begum were among last still suspended for July 2024 rebellion
articles.summary: Labour reinstated the party whip to MPs John McDonnell (Hayes and Harlington) and Apsana Begum (Poplar and Limehouse) 14 months after their July 2023 suspension for rebelling over the two-child benefit cap. Chief whip Jonathan Reynolds approved the move, prompting Begum to pledge continued opposition to the cap amid rising child poverty (44.6% in her constituency). They join four colleagues whose whips returned in February; three other rebels remain suspended or have quit, including Zarah Sultana.

articles.title: Why does the UK need digital IDs and what data will they include?
articles.trailText: Starmer’s proposal has been criticised by rivals and civil liberties groups and campaigners worry about people without smartphones
articles.summary: Labour leader Keir Starmer will consult on compulsory UK digital IDs by mid-2029, aiming to streamline access to government services, verify work rights and curb smuggling and fraud. Backed by the Tony Blair Institute, the system—modelled on Estonia and India—stores holders’ name, DOB, nationality/residency, photo (and possibly address) in a smartphone gov.uk wallet and government databases. Polls show 38% support, with opposition from major parties and civil-liberties groups citing privacy, hacking risks, potential errors and digital exclusion for 4.5m without smartphones; a physical card is under review.

articles.title: Digital ID plan for UK risks creating ‘an enormous hacking target’, expert warns
articles.trailText: Cyber security expert offers warning as tech companies prepare to bid for potentially multi-billion pound contracts
articles.summary: Keir Starmer’s UK-wide mandatory digital ID—dubbed ‘Britcard’ and due by July 2029—would store citizens’ photos, personal data and residency status in an encrypted smartphone wallet but rely on a central database, warns cybersecurity expert Alan Woodward, calling it “an enormous hacking target” and citing recent nursery, Jaguar Land Rover and Estonia ID breaches. With £1.2–2 billion estimated costs and contracts held by Deloitte, BAE, Palantir and others, critics decry poor transparency, digital exclusion, surveillance risks and political opposition from Lib Dems, SNP, Sinn Féin, DUP and Conservatives.

articles.title: Nigel Farage’s deportation plan would break up the NHS | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: The Reform UK leader’s threat to abolish indefinite leave to remain would be devastating for the health service, writes Danny McCloskey . Plus letters from Ian K Watson , Jan Syska and Derek Robinson
articles.summary: Reform UK leader Nigel Farage’s proposal to abolish indefinite leave to remain would destabilise the NHS by stripping settlement rights from foreign-born doctors and staff—over a third of doctors and one in five NHS workers—triggering exodus, longer waiting lists, ward closures, burnout and eventual privatisation. Danny McCloskey warns this undermines universal care and international solidarity. Correspondents Ian K Watson highlight legal and trade fallout from quitting the ECHR and voiding the EU TCA, Jan Syska and Derek Robinson blame Farage for Brexit-linked migration crises and call on UK parties to challenge his agenda.

articles.title: Starmer’s ID plan has caused upset, but in the EU the debate has long been settled
articles.trailText: ID cards have become an essential part of life for many across the bloc, with digital versions already launched in many member states
articles.summary: Keir Starmer’s proposal to introduce national ID cards in the UK contrasts sharply with the EU’s established physical and digital systems. In 25 of 27 EU states, credit-card–sized, machine-readable ID cards—compulsory in 15 countries, voluntary in 11—double as travel documents in Schengen. Under eIDAS 2.0, every EU resident must receive a digital ID wallet by 2026. Denmark’s MitID app is essential for banking, healthcare and e-government; Estonia’s 20-year-old e-ID enables voting and e-signatures; Ukraine’s Diia offers 14 documents and 21 services; Poland’s mObywatel has 10 M users and features from digital driving licences to AI assistants.

articles.title: Menzies Campbell, former Liberal Democrat leader, dies at 84
articles.trailText: Campbell was North East Fife MP for nearly three decades before becoming a peer, and once held UK 100m record
articles.summary: Menzies Campbell, Lib Dem leader (2006–07) and North East Fife MP for 27 years, has died at 84. He held the UK 100m record (10.2s, 1967–74) and competed in the 1964 Tokyo Olympics (200m quarter-finalist, 4×100m relay finalist). Succeeding Charles Kennedy, he resigned amid speculation before a potential 2007 election. Respected for principled opposition to the Iraq War as foreign affairs spokesperson, he earned praise from Ed Davey, Tony Blair, Gordon Brown and Kemi Badenoch. Made a life peer in 2015, he remained active at Lib Dem events. His wife Elspeth died in 2023.

articles.title: Lord Campbell of Pittenweem obituary
articles.trailText: Liberal Democrat leader and sage politician who was also an Olympic athlete and British record holder
articles.summary: Menzies ‘Ming’ Campbell, Liberal Democrat MP (1987–2015) and party leader from 2006 to 2007, has died aged 84. A former Olympic sprinter and British record holder, Campbell served as defence and foreign affairs spokesman and led the Commons opposition to the Iraq war. Knighted in 2004, he resigned as leader partly amid ageist whispering campaigns and discomfort with Commons theatrics. After retiring he entered the Lords as Lord Campbell of Pittenweem and served as chancellor of St Andrews University. He married Elspeth Urquhart in 1970; she died in 2023.

articles.title: Morgan McSweeney will not face new donations investigation, says watchdog
articles.trailText: Electoral Commission decision will come as relief to PM after Tory claims that his chief of staff’s position was in peril
articles.summary: Morgan McSweeney, Keir Starmer’s chief of staff, will not face a fresh Electoral Commission probe into undeclared donations to his former thinktank Labour Together after the regulator found “no evidence of any other potential offences.” The ruling relieves pressure on the PM following Tory claims of a cover-up. Conservatives, led by Kevin Hollinrake, say McSweeney dodged a criminal offence and want a parliamentary standards inquiry. Labour Together was fined £14,250 in 2021 for late reporting of £740,000 and says it has since ensured full compliance.

articles.title: Politicians must confront lies used by populists, Starmer tells London summit
articles.trailText: In speech to Global Progress Action summit, PM criticises rhetoric describing London as ‘decaying and lawless’
articles.summary: At the Global Progress Action summit in London, PM Keir Starmer urged centre-left leaders to confront the “lies” and “industrialised infrastructure of grievance” fuelled by populists, thinly veiled at Donald Trump’s false portrayal of London as decaying and lawless. Speaking alongside Mark Carney and Anthony Albanese, he accepted the reality of Trump’s tariffs, condemned a recent far-right rally as poison, and called for a ‘patriotic renewal.’ Starmer also outlined plans for mandatory digital ID cards linked to migration control and work eligibility, and emphasized the need to deliver real wage growth for social democrats to regain trust.

articles.title: Share your thoughts on plans for a UK digital ID scheme
articles.trailText: We’d like to hear views from people in the UK about how they view government plans for a digital ID scheme
articles.summary: Labour leader Keir Starmer will today unveil plans for a mandatory-but-not-to-be-carried UK digital ID scheme, used for right-to-work checks and available to citizens and legal residents by the end of this parliament. The government says it will strengthen border security, crack down on illegal employment and speed up access to services without needing paper proof. The Guardian invites readers to share their views on benefits, privacy risks and practical challenges.

articles.title: Farage endangering women by failing to condemn paracetamol claims, says Bridget Phillipson
articles.trailText: Labour deputy leader candidate criticises ‘scaremongering’ on autism and says party must be firmer in tackling Reform
articles.summary: Labour education secretary and deputy leadership hopeful Bridget Phillipson accuses Nigel Farage of endangering women’s health by refusing to reject Donald Trump’s baseless claim that paracetamol during pregnancy causes autism. She warns Reform’s promotion of medical conspiracies—including anti-vaccine rhetoric and fringe doctors linking Covid jabs to cancer—threatens public health. Phillipson pledges a tougher moral line against Reform’s divisive policies—from rolling visas that split families to SEND reforms—and condemns far-right protests exploiting women’s safety fears. Backed by GMB and Unison but trailing Lucy Powell, she vows to use the deputy leader role to challenge intolerance and strengthen Labour’s frontline.

articles.title: Keir Starmer says digital ID cards an ‘enormous opportunity’ for the UK
articles.trailText: PM to set out plans for compulsory ‘Brit card’ but faces opposition from civil liberty groups over privacy concerns
articles.summary: Prime Minister Keir Starmer has pitched a compulsory ‘Brit Card’, a secure digital ID to curb illegal migration, streamline border controls and speed access to services. Legislation would build on gov.uk One Login via a gov.uk Wallet app. Culture secretary Lisa Nandy insists it won’t become a surveillance dystopia. Civil-liberty groups including Big Brother Watch’s Silkie Carlo warn of mass surveillance, cyber-attack risks and civil-rights loss. Reform UK’s Nigel Farage brands it a cynical ploy; Tory leader Kemi Badenoch calls it a gimmick. It follows a Labour Together plan to avoid another Windrush-style scandal.

articles.title: Labour MPs call for action to tackle deprivation in coastal ‘sea wall’ seats
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Group warn coastal communities need greater investment to reduce inequality and fight off threat from Reform
articles.summary: A group of 66 Labour coastal MPs has urged urgent investment to tackle entrenched deprivation in so-called sea wall seats, warning Reform Party gains could threaten marginal constituencies. At the Liverpool conference they will demand a London Challenge-style initiative focused on post-16 training, apprenticeships, non-graduate jobs, plus a dedicated minister for coastal communities, improved transport and health equity measures. Citing London Challenge’s success under Blair, they highlight youth NEET rates, brain drain and seasonal tourism economies, and point to a new levelling up fund as a first step.

articles.title: Starmer to unveil digital ID cards in plan set to ignite civil liberties row
articles.trailText: ‘Brit card’ already facing opposition from privacy campaigners as government looks for ways to tackle illegal immigration
articles.summary: PM Keir Starmer will unveil legislation for a universal ‘Brit Card’ digital ID requiring all working adults to verify right-to-work via a gov.uk Wallet app, aiming to curb illegal immigration, rogue landlords and exploitative employers. Backed by Home Sec Shabana Mahmood and Tony Blair Institute, built on existing One Login infrastructure, but attacked by privacy groups, Lib Dems, Open Rights Group and ex-minister David Davis over data security, surveillance and cost-of-living concerns. Labour seeks ‘patriotic renewal’ on border control while rejecting far-right discourse. Promoted as free, smartphone-stored ID to prevent another Windrush-style scandal.

articles.title: Digital ID cards: a versatile and useful tool or a worrying cybersecurity risk?
articles.trailText: As Keir Starmer aims to revive ID card system first proposed by Tony Blair, we look at the arguments for and against
articles.summary: As Keir Starmer revives Tony Blair’s ID card plan to tackle illegal migration, improve service access and curb fraud, proponents argue digital IDs offer convenience, fairness, streamlined state interactions and close trafficking loopholes. Critics – civil liberties groups and security experts – warn mandatory schemes risk mass data collection, profiling, hacking vulnerabilities, digital exclusion among 1.7m over-74s and costly overruns. Costs range from £140m–£2bn; decentralisation details remain unclear. Labour’s Tony Blair Institute champions state-run platform built via smaller UK contracts, eschewing big tech, while opponents fear a central database could empower mass surveillance.

articles.title: Labour’s internal warfare breaks open as Starmer and ministers criticise Andy Burnham
articles.trailText: Starmer is understood to be furious at Greater Manchester mayor’s admission that he would seek to challenge for the leadership
articles.summary: Labour’s internal conflict erupted as Keir Starmer and senior ministers publicly rebuked Greater Manchester mayor Andy Burnham after he dismissed bond-market constraints and signalled a potential leadership challenge. Burnham’s remarks coincided with a spike in UK borrowing costs and drew comparisons to Liz Truss’s ill-fated fiscal gamble. Bridget Phillipson and Rachel Reeves allies warned casual language on markets risked another Truss-style crisis, while Starmer reasserted strict fiscal rules. Burnham has meanwhile advocated scrapping the two-child benefit cap, higher council-tax on expensive properties, 50% top-rate income tax, council housing investment and nationalisation of utilities, prompting frustration at Downing Street.

articles.title: Andy Burnham alarms investors with call to end UK dependence on foreign lenders
articles.trailText: Approach would risk fresh bond market crisis, say investors, amid speculation Greater Manchester mayor is seeking Westminster return
articles.summary: Greater Manchester mayor Andy Burnham warns Labour should end the UK’s dependence on foreign bond lenders, proposing a council housebuilding drive, utility nationalisation, higher taxes on top earners, a levy on pricey London homes and £40bn extra borrowing. City investors fear his rhetoric could trigger a fresh bond market crisis as 10-year gilt yields climbed to 4.726% and 30-year to 5.54%. His remarks, amid speculation he may challenge Keir Starmer with Corbyn alignment, have spooked markets over political risk.

articles.title: Starmer’s head of communications Steph Driver quits in latest No 10 exit
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Departure of key figure comes little over a week after that of director of political strategy
articles.summary: Steph Driver, Keir Starmer’s long-time communications chief, has resigned from Downing Street just over a week after director of political strategy Paul Ovenden departed. Driver served five years with Starmer, rising from opposition communications head to No 10 director. Her exit follows James Lyons’s departure and a reshuffle that promoted former Blair aide Tim Allan to executive director of government communications. Despite Starmer’s attempts to retain her and praise for her role in Labour’s election victory, Driver chose to step down amid broader concerns over No 10 communications churn and strategic missteps.

articles.title: Boring Boris briefly becomes king of the world again – at least in his own head | John Crace
articles.trailText: Former prime minister was grateful for a 45-minute slot on the Harry Cole Saves the West YouTube channel this week
articles.summary: Former PM Boris Johnson, once “king of the world” in 2019, now struggles for attention on Harry Cole’s YouTube show; grateful for a 45-minute slot, he resurrects stale Brexit and immigration rhetoric, urges tougher sanctions on Russian oligarchs and shooting down drones, and laments betrayal by an “ungrateful world.” Skipping from Ukraine to net zero, he speaks with fading self-importance, oblivious to the public’s shift since his downfall. Once a charismatic populist, Johnson is now a disengaged figure, stuck in a political time warp with no clear path back.

articles.title: What is the Labour Together row and are there risks for Keir Starmer?
articles.trailText: The Tories are calling for the standards commissioner and the police to investigate the Labour-aligned thinktank
articles.summary: The Conservatives have urged Commons standards officials and police to probe Labour Together’s failure to declare nearly £740,000 in donations, fined £14,250 in 2021, arguing the “administrative error” defence was a cover-up. Emails from a Labour lawyer in 2021 and from the Electoral Commission in 2017 show Morgan McSweeney, now Starmer’s chief of staff, understood the group’s obligation to register gifts. Tories also allege Starmer failed to list campaign support from Labour Together—McSweeney’s secondment and polling data—as a benefit in kind. Labour says his campaign paid McSweeney and polling was commissioned separately. A new inquiry risks reputational damage, McSweeney’s exit and wider fallout for senior Labour figures.

articles.title: Andy Burnham calls two-child benefit limit the ‘worst of Westminster’
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Greater Manchester mayor says policy introduced in 2017 is arbitrary and cannot be justified
articles.summary: Greater Manchester mayor Andy Burnham has reignited demands to scrap the Conservative-introduced two-child benefit limit, calling it “arbitrary”, unjustifiable and “the worst of Westminster.” Speaking alongside poverty campaigner Terri White, he argued the cap—introduced in 2017—silently punishes low-income families and pushes 109 children into poverty every day. His intervention provoked anger from Labour MPs amid speculation of a return to Westminster and leadership ambitions. Ministers are due to publish a review of the policy this autumn, while charities warn lifting the cap would cost £3.5 bn but lift 470,000 children out of poverty.

articles.title: Tory candidates must pledge support for leaving ECHR or stand down, says Jenrick
articles.trailText: Shadow justice secretary demands prospective MPs sign contract saying they stand for ‘Conservative values’ UK politics – latest updates
articles.summary: Shadow justice secretary Robert Jenrick has urged prospective Conservative candidates to sign a ‘contract’ committing to withdraw the UK from the European Convention on Human Rights or not stand as MPs. His stance, more hardline than leader Kemi Badenoch—who argues leaving the ECHR isn’t a panacea—aims to enforce ideological purity amid one-nation Tories’ alarm. Jenrick also calls for repealing laws like the Human Rights Act and Equalities Act, linking sovereignty restoration to anti-immigration goals. The Tory conference will unveil official ECHR policy next month, while Labour pursues its own reforms.

articles.title: Burnham says MPs are privately urging him to challenge Starmer for Labour leadership
articles.trailText: Greater Manchester mayor accuses Downing Street of creating a ‘climate of fear’ and says wholesale change is required
articles.summary: Greater Manchester mayor Andy Burnham says Labour MPs have privately urged him to challenge Keir Starmer for party leadership and ultimately the prime ministership, insisting any contest must focus on policy over personalities. He accused Downing Street of creating a ‘climate of fear’ among MPs and called for wholesale change, proposing higher council tax on south-east homes, a 50p top rate of income tax, public control of utilities, proportional representation and scrapping the two-child benefit cap. Burnham stopped short of announcing a bid, noting practical hurdles—resigning as mayor and winning a Commons seat—while reiterating his ambition.

articles.title: Starmer gambles on ‘levelling up’-style initiative to tackle Reform threat
articles.trailText: Deprived communities to be given tens of millions to patch up derelict shops, pubs and libraries and ‘restore pride’
articles.summary: Labour will allocate tens of millions of pounds to each of 330 deprived UK communities—particularly coastal towns, ex-coalfields and market towns—to restore derelict shops, pubs, libraries, parks and youth clubs under a new “levelling up”-style regeneration fund. Councils get spending control, powers to seize vacant properties and block bookmakers or vape shops. Keir Starmer hopes it will counter Reform UK’s poll surge, address grassroots anger and demonstrate tangible improvements ahead of Labour’s conference and next election.

articles.title: Boris Johnson says Farage’s stance on Russia is ‘extremely dangerous’
articles.trailText: Former PM also brands Reform UK a threat to national security and raises concern about its approach to the economy
articles.summary: In an interview with the Sun’s Harry Cole, former PM Boris Johnson warns Nigel Farage’s view that NATO provoked Putin and his broader Russia stance is ‘extremely dangerous’, brands Reform UK a national security threat and criticizes its economic and welfare proposals, including lifting the two-child benefit cap. He backs Kemi Badenoch to lead the Tories, vows Conservative solutions over any Tory–Reform deal, claims he could have beaten Keir Starmer, and mocks Reform’s poll surge and its future viability.

articles.title: ‘Sorry for the confusion’: Jeremy Corbyn says membership is open for new party
articles.trailText: Former Labour leader announces November conference after week of turmoil, without mention of Zarah Sultana
articles.summary: Jeremy Corbyn apologised to supporters for a week of turmoil in his new leftwing party, announcing membership is now open and a founding conference set for Liverpool in late November. In a video that made no direct reference to co-founder Zarah Sultana, he accepted confusion over a membership portal she launched then disavowed, amid defamation threats and an ICO report. Your Party told 750,000 interested sign-ups that 13,000 attendees would be chosen by lottery to debate founding documents, with final decisions by one-member-one-vote. Corbyn said independent MPs will hand control to the grassroots after the conference. Venue details remain unconfirmed.

articles.title: Labour says Starmer’s 2020 leadership campaign paid McSweeney salary
articles.trailText: Party says aide’s campaign work did not need to be declared as a Labour Together donation amid new Tory attacks
articles.summary: Labour has confirmed that Morgan McSweeney’s salary during Keir Starmer’s 2020 leadership bid was paid directly by the campaign, not by the affiliate group Labour Together, rebutting Tory claims of undeclared support. Conservatives, led by party chair Kevin Hollinrake, have urged the Electoral Commission to probe whether staffing costs should have been registered as donations. Labour insists neither Starmer nor his campaign accepted financial or in-kind contributions from Labour Together. The commission is reviewing fresh evidence amid a prior £14,250 fine for late declarations.

articles.title: Keir Starmer’s relationship with his chief of staff faces biggest test yet
articles.trailText: Morgan McSweeney under spotlight over late declarations of donations to thinktank when he was its director
articles.summary: Keir Starmer’s partnership with chief of staff Morgan McSweeney, dubbed a ‘marriage of convenience’, is under unprecedented strain after McSweeney’s Labour Together thinktank failed to declare over £700,000 in donations on time. Starmer, who rewarded McSweeney for engineering his leadership win and election majority, publicly defended him in Cabinet, but growing discontent over missteps—from the welfare bill defeat to the mishandled Peter Mandelson ambassadorship—has emboldened critics. Emails show Labour’s legal team warned of reporting lapses. If further donation breaches emerge, the scandal could implicate Starmer, fuel internal revolt and heighten leadership challenge threats.

articles.title: How to take the fight to Reform UK and the far right | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Barry Greatorex, Jennifer Rees, Dr Sebastian Kraemer, Elizabeth Baker and Marilyn Adams respond to an article by Jonathan Freedland
articles.summary: Letter writers back Freedland’s warning on Reform UK and Farage’s threat, citing polls showing just 31% back Brexit versus 56% favour rejoining the EU, nearly 60% want to stay under the European Convention on Human Rights and only 31% view migrants as undermining British culture, with a 49% progressive majority vs 45% Reform/Conservatives. Barry Greatorex urges voting system reform to stop far-right rule; Jennifer Rees proposes the slogan “Vote Farage, get Trump”; Sebastian Kraemer calls for hard-hitting grassroots drama; Elizabeth Baker rejects Farage’s narrative; and Marilyn Adams seeks clear action steps beyond protests.

articles.title: Sadiq Khan hits back at ‘racist, sexist, misogynistic and Islamophobic’ Trump
articles.trailText: Khan’s comments come after US president used speech at UN to call London mayor ‘terrible’
articles.summary: After Trump’s UN speech attacking him as a "terrible" mayor and alleging London was veering toward sharia law, Sadiq Khan accused the US president of racism, sexism, misogyny and Islamophobia. His remarks drew praise from Labour’s health secretary, Wes Streeting, while work and pensions secretary Pat McFadden defended London without challenging Trump. Khan cited record US visitor numbers and London’s global leadership in culture and investment, urging UK leaders to leverage the special US-UK relationship by calling out Trump’s false claims. MPs from Greens and Labour, including calls to summon the US ambassador, backed Khan’s call for a firmer rebuke.

articles.title: Nigel Farage swans around peddling hate on Nick Ferrari’s phone-in | John Crace
articles.trailText: From immigrants eating the king’s waterfowl to sharia law in London, it’s all there in our Nige’s relativist world
articles.summary: Nigel Farage used a 30-minute slot on Nick Ferrari’s LBC show to stoke xenophobic and conspiratorial rhetoric, warning immigrants of sharia law threats in royal parks and falsely claiming 1.3m ILR holders drain £230bn benefits. He marginalized a long-term UK resident by suggesting her deportation, echoed Trump’s anti-elite relativism by dismissing science and mainstream medicine on paracetamol, floated absurdist desert enclaves for Palestinians, trafficked misinformation on Sadiq Khan, Gaza, and European decline—an object lesson in 21st-century populist hate and strategic ambiguity.

articles.title: Farage refuses to criticise Trump over paracetamol despite health experts dismissing autism claims
articles.trailText: Reform UK leader says he has ‘no idea’ if US president is right to tell women to avoid drug during pregnancy
articles.summary: Nigel Farage refused to condemn Donald Trump’s unfounded claim that paracetamol (Tylenol) in pregnancy causes autism, telling LBC “science is never settled” and he “has no idea” if Trump is right, rejecting experts’ consensus. WHO and scientists label the link inconsistent; UK health secretary Wes Streeting advised trusting doctors over Trump. Farage, who featured controversial physician Aseem Malhotra at Reform UK’s conference, also echoed Trump on sharia law in London, defended benefits cuts for non-citizens except Ukrainians/Hongkongers, and repeated false swan-eating allegations.

articles.title: Peter Mandelson’s advisory firm revokes his voting rights and ends dividend payments
articles.trailText: Global Counsel co-founder was sacked as US ambassador amid email revelations about extent of relationship with Jeffrey Epstein
articles.summary: Global Counsel has stripped co-founder Peter Mandelson of voting rights and halted dividend payments on his 21% stake following his ousting as UK ambassador after emails revealed a close relationship with Jeffrey Epstein. The firm, co-founded with Benjamin Wegg-Prosser in 2010, will sell his shares over the next two months. Mandelson, who resigned as director in May and agreed in January to divest gradually, saw scrutiny intensify after messages showed him calling Epstein his “best pal” and urging challenges to Epstein’s conviction. Global Counsel, which advises clients including JP Morgan, Barclays, OpenAI and TikTok, declined to comment.

articles.title: Tories demand inquiry into claims Labour’s McSweeney misled elections watchdog
articles.trailText: Starmer’s chief of staff used ‘false excuse’ for failing to declare donations to his former thinktank, Conservatives claim
articles.summary: Conservatives have demanded an inquiry into Labour chief of staff Morgan McSweeney over allegations he misled the Electoral Commission about undeclared £739,492 donations to his former thinktank, Labour Together, fined £14,250 in 2021. A leaked legal email from Labour lawyer Gerald Shamash suggests advising McSweeney to claim administrative error to minimise publicity. McSweeney, who helped deliver Labour’s 2024 landslide and later joined Keir Starmer’s team, faces renewed scrutiny amid internal Labour disquiet. Labour and Downing Street insist McSweeney cooperated fully, with Starmer expressing confidence, while Tory chair Kevin Hollinrake argues public interest warrants full investigation.

articles.title: No more Mr Nice Guy: Ed Davey rebrands Lib Dems as the real opposition to Reform
articles.trailText: Leader’s conference speech at Bournemouth shows a bullish party ready to be key player in any centre-left coalition
articles.summary: At the Lib Dem conference in Bournemouth, leader Ed Davey shed his conciliatory tone to brand the party “the real opposition to Reform,” touting 72 confident MPs, plans to reclaim Tory and red wall seats, and a role in any centre-left coalition. He targeted Reform’s Farage-style populism and Trump’s America, reclaimed Labour’s policies on carers and school meals, championed Gaza genocide recognition and a single-market re-entry. Despite polished theatrics, the speech hinted at reinvention needs beyond performance politics.

articles.title: Mahmood vows to change modern slavery laws after bid to deport Eritrean man thwarted
articles.trailText: Appeal court rejects home secretary’s attempt to appeal against blocking of return of man to France under ‘one in, one out’ deal
articles.summary: Home Secretary Shabana Mahmood lost an appeal at the Court of Appeal against a High Court ruling that blocked the deportation of an unnamed Eritrean asylum seeker under the UK’s one-in, one-out repatriation deal with France. Judges Arnold, Lewis and Laing found no legal error in granting him 14 days to gather evidence for a modern slavery trafficking claim. Mahmood, accusing migrants of “vexatious” last-minute tactics, amended policy on 17 September and has commissioned wider modern slavery law reforms. Government lawyers cited “considerable urgency” to deter dangerous crossings before winter; only three removals have taken place so far.

articles.title: Donald Trump’s sharia law attack on Sadiq Khan outrages Labour MPs
articles.trailText: Keir Starmer urged to take action over US president’s inflammatory speech to the UN
articles.summary: At the UN, Donald Trump falsely accused London’s mayor Sadiq Khan of wanting to impose sharia law, calling him “terrible” and inflaming Labour MPs who demand Keir Starmer reprimand the US administration. Rosena Allin-Khan urged summoning US ambassador Warren Stephens over “rampant Islamophobia,” while Wes Streeting, Rupa Huq and Dawn Butler defended Khan’s record on diversity, safety and transport. Khan’s office declined to dignify the remarks, noting a 50% jump in US citizenship applications (2,194) in April–June. Starmer, wary of US tariffs, faces growing pressure after Trump’s second state visit.

articles.title: Wes Streeting rejects Trump claim linking paracetamol and autism
articles.trailText: Health secretary joins medical experts in urging pregnant women to ignore US president’s remarks
articles.summary: UK health secretary Wes Streeting has publicly rejected Donald Trump’s unsupported claim that prenatal paracetamol causes autism, citing a major 2024 Swedish study of 2.4 million children that found no link. He urged pregnant women to trust NHS doctors and scientists rather than political rhetoric. The DHSC mobilised parenting influencers and NHS spokespeople to counter misinformation. Top experts—including Prof Sir Andrew Pollard, Dr Alison Cave, Prof Claire Anderson, Dr Steven Kapp and Prof Laurie Tomlinson—and the National Autistic Society warned such baseless claims risk stigmatising autistic people.

articles.title: Civil servants may feel ‘under attack’ after new rules briefed to media, UK ministers told
articles.trailText: Guidance that meetings should be held outside working hours was published in Telegraph with quote about ‘nonsense’ events
articles.summary: Civil service guidance now mandates senior sign-off for all cross-government staff network events, requires meetings outside working hours unless tied to organisational benefits, and stresses impartiality under the civil service code. Unions and experts welcomed clarity but warn that media leaks—labelling events “nonsense”—risk undermining trust and equality, diversity and inclusion commitments. Networks face suspension for non-compliance. Cabinet Office ministers defend measures as proportionate, citing occasional “inappropriate” gatherings, while academics note most meetings already occur off-hours and stress networks’ value for minority groups within the service.

articles.title: Your Party is offering a gift to the hard right | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Paul Cavaciuti, Lorraine Du Feu and Paul Walmsley on bickering and the politics of the fledgling new leftwing party
articles.summary: Three letters critique the nascent Your Party’s infighting: Paul Cavaciuti warns that endless process debates, leadership vacuum and lack of policy waste a chance to offer a genuine left-wing alternative and suggests a clear figure like Zarah Sultana; Lorraine Du Feu urges defectors to back the established Green Party’s socialist-environmentalist platform; Paul Walmsley argues further fragmentation of left forces risks handing victory to Reform UK and calls for unity to block the far right.

articles.title: Lib Dems the last block against ‘forces of darkness’ led by Farage, says Ed Davey
articles.trailText: Lib Dem leader’s conference speech takes aim at Reform by predicting it would bring Trump-style policies to UK
articles.summary: At their 2025 conference, Lib Dem leader Ed Davey branded his party the final bulwark against Nigel Farage’s ‘forces of darkness’, likening Reform UK’s agenda to Trump-style policies: dismantling the NHS, loosening gun laws to teach children mass-shooting drills, enabling racism, rolling back human rights protections, and outsourcing asylum decisions. He challenged centre-right voters disillusioned with Labour and the Conservatives to join the Lib Dems, warning that without them Farage’s Britain would see chaos, climate rollback, poison on social media, and Taliban-backed asylum expulsions. No new policies were announced, but the speech cranked up anti-Reform rhetoric amid upcoming elections.

articles.title: Lib Dems aiming to go big as they spot electoral opportunity
articles.trailText: Ed Davey and his party are preparing to do battle with Reform as they gather for their annual conference
articles.summary: At their annual Bournemouth conference, Ed Davey’s Liberal Democrats, buoyed by a post–2024 surge to 72 MPs, are targeting a head-to-head battle with Reform amid a collapse in Tory support and faltering Labour polls. After winning more council seats than both rivals in May, they plan to defend newly won seats via local embedding and adopt a “go big” strategy combining grassroots and “air war” tactics. Polls still have them under 15% nationally, but they’ve doubled support among under-25s and lead in southern England. Unified behind Davey, they seek broad, mainstream policies—on cost of living, economy—to seize a historic electoral opportunity.

articles.title: What does ‘Boriswave’ mean and what is its political significance?
articles.trailText: Use by Nigel Farage is latest example of terms coined by the ‘extremely online right’ entering political mainstream
articles.summary: At Reform UK’s launch Nigel Farage used the term “Boriswave” – a label for the post-Brexit influx of non-EU migrants coined by the online far right – to justify stripping existing indefinite leave to remain. Originally forged and spread on X and 4chan, then laundered into mainstream outlets (Daily Telegraph, Daily Mail) and even parliament, “Boriswave” exemplifies the so-called “posting-to-policy pipeline,” where extremist digital rhetoric seeps rapidly into political discourse, reshaping migration debates under a far-right framing.

articles.title: Keir Starmer to launch progressive fightback against ‘decline and division’ fuelled by far right
articles.trailText: Prime minister expected to warn UK is ‘at a crossroads’ as he sets out plan to counter Nigel Farage and Reform
articles.summary: Prime Minister Keir Starmer will use an upcoming speech at the Labour conference to launch a progressive fightback against far-right-fuelled division, warning the UK is “at a crossroads.” Under pressure from within his party, he will confront Nigel Farage and Reform UK, build an international centre-left coalition to oppose right-wing populism, and offer solutions on immigration and social cohesion. Starmer will contrast Labour’s green energy investments, workers’ rights advances and tax protections with Reform’s hardline deportation and human-rights rollback proposals to reclaim the moral high ground.

articles.title: Ed Davey calls for UK to import US cancer researchers hit by Trump cuts
articles.trailText: Lib Dem leader to use conference speech to urge extra funding for mRNA research and accuse Nigel Farage of cheering US funding reductions
articles.summary: At the Liberal Democrat conference in Bournemouth, Ed Davey urged the UK to recruit US scientists whose mRNA cancer research was slashed under the Trump administration, lambasting Nigel Farage and Reform UK for applauding the cuts. He vowed to boost mRNA funding, rebuild a National Cancer Research Institute closed under the Conservatives, and position Britain as a global hub for personalised immunotherapy. The address also framed the Lib Dems' battle against hard-right populism and calls for stricter rules on foreign lobbying ahead of local elections.

articles.title: Corbyn and Sultana prepare new party memberships launch – without unified line
articles.trailText: Exclusive: party insiders hope low-stakes launch will help movement move on from chaotic start, despite ongoing tensions
articles.summary: Jeremy Corbyn and MP Zarah Sultana are launching a second membership drive for their Independent Alliance this week without a joint statement, months after Sultana unilaterally opened a £55 portal that 20,000 paid into and sparked condemnation as a 'false membership system'. Sultana dropped legal threats and accused a 'sexist boys’ club' around Corbyn of sidelining her; Corbyn insists she remained involved. Relations remain cordial but trust is damaged. MPs say the quieter rollout and upcoming founding conference—with one-member-one-vote constitution—should help the movement move past public spats and internal discord.

articles.title: Nigel Farage roundly condemned over plan to abolish indefinite leave to remain
articles.trailText: Cross-party criticism after Reform UK leader threatens hundreds of thousands of legal immigrants with deportation
articles.summary: Nigel Farage’s Reform UK has pledged to abolish indefinite leave to remain (ILR), blocking 800,000 migrants who gained post-Brexit rights (“Boriswave”) from permanent settlement between 2026 and 2030. He proposes five-year visa renewals with raised salary, English tests and stricter dependant rules, risking family splits and revoking Ukrainians’ or Hongkongers’ statuses. Cross-party critics – Labour, Lib Dems, SNP, unions and Downing Street – denounce the policy as unworkable, divisive and based on flawed £230bn savings, warning of NHS, care sector and community fallout.

articles.title: Bridget Phillipson pledges to deliver workers’ rights bill in full if deputy leader
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Unions endorse education secretary as she vows to ensure measures are not watered down – ‘no ifs or buts’
articles.summary: Bridget Phillipson promises to enact the full employment rights bill – banning exploitative zero-hours contracts, ending fire-and-rehire, securing day-one unfair dismissal protection and stronger harassment safeguards – if elected Labour deputy leader. Backed by Musicians’ Union, Community and NUM, she pledges “no ifs or buts” on workers’ rights, positioning herself as the unions’ cabinet champion against business pushback. Facing rival Lucy Powell, who has CWU and mayor Andy Burnham’s support, Phillipson vows daily union collaboration to deliver reform.

articles.title: Hate, hate again, hate better – for Farage, the country needs educating about foreigners | John Crace
articles.trailText: Was he sure everyone hated legal immigrants as much as he did? Nige knew better because he was Nige
articles.summary: Nigel Farage, at a Reform UK press conference, announced a policy to revoke indefinite leave to remain for all legal immigrants, branding them lazy welfare dependents whose removal would save £230bn. Only high-earning, fluent English speakers could stay for up to five years without family rights. Reform’s Zia Yusuf promised limited skilled visas tied to British wage increases, but critics derided the plan as racist, economically flawed and impractical. Farage declared the public needed to 'hate better' and threatened mass deportations enforced by law changes.

articles.title: Stop shilly-shallying and scrap the two-child benefit cap | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Readers respond to articles about rising child poverty in Britain, and the education secretary’s criticism that the two-child benefit cap has ‘punished and pushed children into hardship’
articles.summary: Paediatricians Guddi Singh and Geoff Debelle condemn the UK’s two-child benefit cap as a deliberate choice driving hundreds of thousands of children into hunger and hardship—babies failing to thrive, schoolchildren too hungry to learn and stressed teenagers. Citing the children’s commissioner, Child Poverty Action Group and BMJ, they urge lifting the cap as the single most effective poverty measure, funded by a modest wealth tax. Letters from Labour supporter Joan Friend and critic David Murray highlight the policy’s spitefulness and political hypocrisy.

articles.title: Labour should have a single-minded focus on social housing | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: A housebuilding drive for social rent will sell the government better than any vague slogan, writes Caroline Mozley , while Ken Guy longs for party differences to be aired in open debate
articles.summary: Two letters urge Labour to prioritize a social housing boom akin to post-war efforts: focus solely on mass-producing quality, factory-built rental homes to showcase tangible progress, rather than juggling private-sector tweaks or vague slogans on healthcare and education. Caroline Mozley argues this single-minded drive will define the party’s identity. Ken Guy adds that Labour should revive open, spirited debates among MPs—like Jenkins vs. Benn—to engage voters authentically.

articles.title: Farage vows to scrap indefinite leave to remain, placing thousands at risk of deportation
articles.trailText: Reform UK plans to force non-citizens to apply for visas, with high salary thresholds and no access to NHS services
articles.summary: Nigel Farage’s Reform UK has pledged to abolish indefinite leave to remain (ILR), targeting around 800,000 post-Brexit “Boriswave” immigrants—described as young, low-skilled and a burden on the state. Under the proposal anyone with ILR would lose status and be forced to reapply for work visas with high salary thresholds (reportedly ~£60,000), no NHS or benefits access, stricter English tests, limited family reunion, a 7-year residency wait and renunciation of other citizenships. Farage cites a disputed £234bn saving. Downing Street, Labour and London mayor Sadiq Khan condemn the uncosted, divisive plan; EU settled status would initially be spared.

articles.title: Insolvent UK recruiter acquired by previous owner who took millions out
articles.trailText: Premier Group Recruitment went into administration with debts of £2.9m – including £647,000 owed in tax
articles.summary: Premier Group Recruitment, insolvent with £2.9m debts including £647k to HMRC, was acquired for £10k and monthly £25k instalments (total £610k) by PGGBR Ltd, created by former 99% shareholder Andrew Woosnam, who holds a £1.2m director’s loan and extracted £1.95m in dividends over 2022–23. Administrators rejected a higher bid of £321k plus royalties, judging Woosnam’s phoenix bid best for creditors given his personal guarantees. HMRC estimates ‘phoenixism’ cost 22% of the £3.8bn tax losses in 2022–23. Recovery of the director’s loan and HMRC debt remains uncertain.

articles.title: Ministers could give mayors control of schools and hospitals in devolution shake-up
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Steve Reed, backed by Labour Together, wants to devolve control over more local services
articles.summary: Local Government Secretary Steve Reed is preparing amendments to the devolution bill to grant English mayors sweeping new powers over schools, hospitals, social care and probation, including the appointment of health, education and justice commissioners. Endorsed by the Labour Together report Reed co-founded, the plans would shift budgetary control from NHS integrated care boards and underfunded local authorities to metro and combined authorities. Cabinet Office minister Josh Simons is convening a cross-department panel for rollout. Proponents argue this will boost local accountability, integrated community services and cost savings, while critics warn of empowering political rivals and complicating governance.

articles.title: Labour thinktank hopes Starmer will devolve more power to his potential rivals
articles.trailText: Regional commissioners could save government money while boosting local control of public services, report argues
articles.summary: Labour Together’s report, authored by JP Spencer, urges Keir Starmer to accelerate devolution by empowering regional mayors—especially Andy Burnham—to appoint commissioners overseeing health, education, policing and justice, mirroring police and crime commissioners. It proposes radical measures including abolishing central departments and introducing a Barnett-style funding formula for local budgets. Although Starmer and Chancellor Rachel Reeves have already rejected parts of the plan, local government secretary Steve Reed supports deeper devolution as a cost-saving, community-empowering strategy that could undercut Reform UK’s appeal and boost democratic accountability.

articles.title: Zarah Sultana drops legal threat over feud with Jeremy Corbyn
articles.trailText: MP ‘determined to reconcile’ with former Labour leader after fledgling party’s membership sign-up row
articles.summary: Coventry South MP Zarah Sultana has called off defamation proceedings against ex-Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn after a dispute over her paid membership sign-up system for Your Party. Sultana, who accused Corbyn and fellow founders of sidelining her in a “sexist boys’ club” when he disowned an “unauthorised” recruitment email, said she will not pursue legal action “for the sake of the party” and is engaged in reconciliation talks. The new socialist movement—launched by Sultana after her July Labour exit post-suspension over the two-child benefit cap vote—has yet to hold its first conference or adopt a formal name but claims over 750,000 supporters.

articles.title: Lib Dems should ditch Ed Davey’s stunts and talk policy, survey finds
articles.trailText: Thinktank poll reveals voters unclear what party stands for despite photo opportunities winning more media coverage
articles.summary: A More in Common poll shown at the Lib Dem annual conference finds over 60% of voters—and 47% of party supporters—view Ed Davey’s image-friendly stunts as undermining seriousness. While the party has costed policies on asylum backlogs, an energy-bill windfall tax on banks, NHS, care and water pollution, only 15% back the Lib Dems and just a third would trust them in coalition, though 30% remain open and they could win over 100 seats. Youth support has surged thanks to a strong Gaza stance; Davey boycotted the US state dinner, and deputy leader Daisy Cooper warned public flag-waving sends the wrong message.

articles.title: How will recognition of Palestinian statehood be greeted in the UK?
articles.trailText: As well as being deeply symbolic, the move is also a major foreign policy shift for the Labour government
articles.summary: The UK’s formal recognition of Palestinian statehood marks both a symbolic shift internationally and a significant domestic political move by Keir Starmer’s Labour government. Pressured by over 100 Labour MPs—backed by figures including Yvette Cooper and Angela Rayner—and losses to pro-Palestine independents in last year’s election, the decision fulfills a manifesto pledge and eases internal dissent. While relief is widespread, some right-wing Labour MPs fear straining US ties, and left-wing factions demand further action on sanctions, arms sales and trade. Public opinion remains supportive, potentially bolstering Starmer ahead of the party conference.

articles.title: Tulip Siddiq fears plans to use ‘fake’ documents to secure conviction in corruption trial
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Ex-minister being tried in absentia in Bangladesh claims ID card and passport tendered as evidence not hers
articles.summary: Tulip Siddiq, the Labour MP tried in absentia in Dhaka on allegations of influencing a land deal, fears prosecutors will use forged Bangladeshi ID and passport images published in UK and Bangladesh papers to secure her conviction. She denies ever holding a valid national ID card or renewing her passport since childhood, labels the documents fake and politically motivated. Cleared in January by Keir Starmer’s adviser but forced to resign ministerial roles over reputational risks, Siddiq—alongside 20 relatives—has had no legal representation or contact from Bangladeshi authorities. She warns these forgeries may presage further fabricated evidence to sway British and Bangladeshi media.

articles.title: Lucy Powell: Labour should raise gambling taxes to axe two-child benefit cap
articles.trailText: Deputy leadership candidate says party needs to be ‘clear that our objective is to lift children out of poverty’
articles.summary: Labour deputy leadership hopeful Lucy Powell proposes raising gambling levies to fund abolishing the two-child benefit cap, aiming to lift 500,000 children out of poverty by generating £3.2bn as recommended by Gordon Brown and the IPPR. Powell, MP for Manchester Central and rival to education secretary Bridget Phillipson, argues the move would demonstrate Labour’s commitment to fighting childhood poverty and differentiate her platform. The two-child limit, introduced by the Conservatives in 2015, restricts tax credits and universal credit. Powell stresses clearer messaging on social justice amid concerns over past mistakes and slow progress.

articles.title: UK and St George’s flags should never be used to ‘intimidate and terrify’, says senior Lib Dem
articles.trailText: ‘How dare the nationalists steal our flags?’ asks Tim Farron at party conference in Bournemouth
articles.summary: At the Lib Dem conference in Bournemouth on Sept 20, senior figure Tim Farron condemns hard-right activists who wield the Union Jack and St George’s Cross to intimidate and enforce a narrow patriotism, arguing that hijacking national flags for exclusion does not reflect true love of country. Speaking after a mass far-right rally in London—where Elon Musk addressed crowds urging “violence”—and echoed by party leader Ed Davey, Farron reclaims flags as symbols for all British people, contrasting “proud patriots” committed to service and community with “nationalists” who hate neighbours and fantasise about a golden-age Britain.

articles.title: Rachel Reeves due to appear at gambling lobbyist’s event amid tax review
articles.trailText: Chancellor’s invitation criticised as ‘strange timing’ with Treasury looking at whether to raise duties on £12bn sector
articles.summary: Rachel Reeves will headline a private Brunswick reception on 28 September at the Labour conference, hosted by Betting & Gaming Council chair Michael Dugher—her childhood friend and former Westminster office-sharer—while the Treasury reviews duties on the £12bn gambling sector ahead of her autumn budget. Critics—MPs Daisy Cooper, Iain Duncan Smith and ethics campaigners—denounce the timing, citing her past BGC hospitality (£330 tickets) and £20,000 donations, and urge higher online-gambling taxes. Brunswick says Dugher’s advisory role is separate.

articles.title: Zarah Sultana consults defamation lawyers after spat with Jeremy Corbyn over party funds
articles.trailText: MP says she faced ‘baseless attacks’ over paid membership portal, which Corbyn told supporters not to use
articles.summary: Coventry South MP Zarah Sultana has instructed defamation lawyers over what she calls ‘baseless, politically motivated’ attacks after clashing with Jeremy Corbyn about the launch of Your Party’s paid membership portal. Sultana denies any misuse of member data or funds, insisting all contributions were ringfenced and protected. Corbyn publicly warned supporters against an ‘unauthorised email’ sign-up and defended aide Karie Murphy, whom Sultana accused of running a ‘sexist boys’ club’ and sidelining her from official accounts. The party self-reported to the Information Commissioner’s Office over the disputed email, while Sultana claims more than 750,000 supporters have joined.

articles.title: ‘Good humanitarian reason’: Ed Davey calls for emergency programme to clear asylum backlog
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Lib Dem leader says push to process cases would also ultimately save money and remove far-right target
articles.summary: Lib Dem leader Ed Davey urges a Covid-style emergency to clear 70,000+ asylum cases in six months using Nightingale centres and triple staffing, saying it saves money on hotel stays, treats refugees humanely and denies the far-right a grievance. He accuses the previous Conservative government of deliberately building the backlog as a deterrent and calls on Kemi Badenoch to apologise. At Bournemouth, Lib Dems will defend 72 MPs and target Tory-held East Surrey and Exmouth & Exeter East with health, care and cost-of-living pitches to disillusioned voters.

articles.title: Labour rules against dozens of motions about Palestine being debated at party conference
articles.trailText: Calls for sanctions on Israel and ban on trade that aids international law violations among snubbed motions
articles.summary: Labour’s conference arrangements committee has rejected about 30 Palestine motions submitted by local parties for next month’s conference, ruling they duplicate the August National Policy Framework. The move comes as the prime minister readies recognition of Palestine as a state. Submitters may appeal by Sunday with hearings on Monday. The decision sparked accusations from the Palestine Solidarity Campaign and MPs like John McDonnell that officials are silencing calls for arms embargoes, sanctions and a trade ban over alleged international law breaches, including events since the NPF report. Labour says party rules were followed and broader debates will take place.

articles.title: ‘Go-to trope’: how the far right is exploiting violence against women and girls
articles.trailText: From Tommy Robinson to Reform UK, nationalist figures are weaponising women’s safety to push anti-migrant fears
articles.summary: UK far-right figures from Tommy Robinson to Reform UK have revived the ‘protect women and children’ trope to link sexual violence to illegal immigration, reframing hostility as defence, stereotyping migrants as predators and mobilising support. Academics label this ‘femo-nationalism’, co-opting feminist concerns for xenophobic ends. Politicians like Farage and Philp invoke disputed Ministry of Justice figures; researchers warn age skew distorts migrant conviction rates. Grassroots ‘pink patrols’ in east London embody public fear despite little evidence of migrant-linked assaults.

articles.title: Scottish minister Jamie Hepburn quits after Douglas Ross assault accusation
articles.trailText: Former Scottish Tory leader alleges Hepburn grabbed him amid row over SNP’s apparent failure to tackle gull attacks
articles.summary: Jamie Hepburn, Scotland’s minister for parliamentary business, resigned after former Scottish Tory leader Douglas Ross accused him of grabbing his shoulder and using abusive language outside Parliament during a dispute over the government’s response to aggressive gull attacks. Hepburn denied assault, apologized for his remarks and said his conduct breached his personal code. Ross secured backing from an unnamed MSP and demanded an independent ministerial code probe by First Minister John Swinney, who had defended Hepburn initially. Rare among SNP dismissals, Hepburn’s departure was accepted with regret as he bowed to principle.

articles.title: ‘Good at self-sabotage’: people react to Corbyn and Sultana row in new leftwing party
articles.trailText: Public spat over membership portal is a huge turn-off for those sympathetic to ideals of nascent party
articles.summary: Jeremy Corbyn and Zarah Sultana’s fledgling left-wing party has opened with a public dispute over an unauthorized membership portal, prompting criticism of factionalism and poor organisation. Six respondents – from former Labour stalwarts to politically homeless Greens – express disappointment, self-sabotage and doubts about the party’s viability. Some vow to wait for stability, others demand clearer leadership or fear Corbyn’s electoral liability. Amid concerns over internal ego battles and lack of trust, several supporters now look to the Greens as a more credible vehicle for economic change and anti-far-right resistance.

articles.title: Reform UK suspends councillor linked to account calling for Starmer’s death
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Party investigates Northumberland councillor John Allen over alleged YouTube posts
articles.summary: Reform UK suspended Northumberland councillor John Allen pending an inquiry after antifascist group Hope Not Hate linked him to YouTube account @johnallen7807, which posted calls to “shoot Starmer myself” and “see Starmer swinging from a lamp post.” Allen, also on Northumbria’s police and crime panel, neither confirmed nor denied authorship. Leader Nigel Farage previously urged police to arrest social-media users calling for his shooting. The case amplifies concern over violent rhetoric in UK politics, from a recent far-right rally arrest to Elon Musk’s “violence is coming” remarks.

articles.title: Green party membership surges after public split between Corbyn and Sultana
articles.trailText: Almost 1,400 people sign up in 24 hours to increase party membership by 10% since Zack Polanski’s leadership win this month
articles.summary: Following a public fallout between Jeremy Corbyn and Zarah Sultana over an unauthorised membership drive and ICO referral, the Green party added nearly 1,400 members in 24 hours—pushing its ranks above 75,000, a 10% rise since Zack Polanski’s early-month leadership win. Polanski, open to talks with the ex-Labour duo yet emphasising the Greens as the go-to left-wing home, vowed to prioritise bold growth. Corbyn lambasted Sultana’s “false membership system,” while she accused Greens insiders of a “sexist boys’ club”; party sources now seek de-escalation.

articles.title: Share your views on the fallout between Corbyn and Sultana over their new party’s membership portal
articles.trailText: We would like to hear from people about their reaction to the latest fallout between Jeremy Corbyn and Zahra Sultana
articles.summary: Internal conflict has erupted within the new leftwing party co-founded by Jeremy Corbyn and Zarah Sultana after an unauthorized membership portal began collecting personal data and funds. Corbyn denounced the system as “false,” urged supporters to ignore donation requests and referred the issue to the Information Commissioner’s Office. Sultana countered that she was frozen out “by a sexist boys’ club,” insisting her sole aim was to protect grassroots involvement. Corbyn denied sidelining her. The article closes by inviting readers to share whether this fallout has changed their view of the party and voiced any concerns.

articles.title: Reform UK receives £100,000 donation from design firm that faced winding-up petition
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Interior Architecture Landscape, which faced closure by HMRC early this year, made donation in June
articles.summary: Reform UK, led by Nigel Farage, received a £100k June donation in three tranches from Interior Architecture Landscape, a London-based luxury design firm that faced an HMRC winding-up petition over a £200k+ tax liability and late accounts. Owned by director John Richard Simpson via a BVI-linked structure, the firm says the dispute is settled and is now fully compliant. Reform UK confirms it vetted the donor as a permissible UK-registered company. The donation complements major funding from Nick Candy, Zia Yusuf and other high-net-worth backers.

articles.title: Corbyn clashes with Sultana over membership portal as split emerges in new party
articles.trailText: Ex-Labour leader says ‘legal advice being taken’ over issue, while Sultana claims ‘sexist boys’ club’ is running party
articles.summary: Ex-Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn and co-leader Zarah Sultana have split over an unauthorised membership portal in their new left-wing party, prompting Corbyn to refer the matter to the ICO and urge supporters to cancel payments. Corbyn brands the site a “false membership system,” while Sultana accuses a “sexist boys’ club” of sidelining her and centralising control over funds and data. Allies on both sides allege rival factions are vying for power. The clash exposes deeper rifts over party structure, grassroots vs top-down governance, data ownership and democratic process ahead of its founding conference.

articles.title: The Sunbed King stifles a yawn at Chequers while Keir twitches at the press | John Crace
articles.trailText: Trump was in his own Truman show, everyone else satellites to his ego – even the PM, who was just another beta male
articles.summary: In John Crace’s caustic take on Donald Trump’s UK state visit, the ex-president soaks up Disney-style pageantry at Windsor and Chequers while Prime Minister Keir Starmer nervously plays supporting act. At a critical joint press conference, Starmer offers effusive praise as Trump yawns, spouts bombastic, unsubstantiated claims—from peacemaking to tough immigration crackdowns—and dodges tough questions on Gaza, global conflicts and a Mandelson scandal. Starmer only narrowly avoids humiliation, breathing a sigh of relief as he survives Trump’s ego-driven spectacle.

articles.title: John Windle obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives: General manager of Sheffield University students’ union who helped it to become one of the best in the country
articles.summary: Died aged 75 of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, John Windle was a lifelong socialist who supported Tony Benn’s 1984 Chesterfield win and led Sheffield University Students’ Union as general manager from 1982, making it the UK’s top-rated union through low-cost services, sabbatical training and support for 150+ clubs. After a 2003 heart attack he founded a quality-assurance scheme for 60+ student unions endorsed by the Department for Education. A keen cricketer, he leaves wife Sue, three children and grandchildren.

articles.title: Labour must win voters’ hearts – or Reform UK will | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Cyril Haessig , Adrian Dumphy and Dr Margaret Martlew respond to an article by Kirsty Major on how the party is failing to connect with people even in safe seats
articles.summary: Readers respond to Kirsty Major’s analysis of Labour’s struggle to connect with voters in safe seats, warning that emotionally-charged, simple messaging from Reform UK capitalizes on disillusionment from benefit cuts, stagnant wages and job insecurity. Letters from Surrey, south Wales and Sheffield underscore fears of Reform gains in traditional Labour areas, criticize the government’s policy-heavy approach and urge the party to craft an inspiring, values-driven narrative offering hope, dignity and clear vision.

articles.title: Apparent Your party implosion leaves big political vacancy on the left
articles.trailText: If the latest Sultana-Corbyn row proves terminal, 700,000 people who registered interest will have no political home
articles.summary: Both sitting as independent MPs, Jeremy Corbyn and Coventry MP Zarah Sultana’s feud over control of their proposed left-wing “Your party” — triggered by Corbyn’s legal warning over an “unauthorised” email and Sultana’s rival membership portal accusing his allies of sexism and broken gender-balance promises — has all but collapsed the movement. Their personality-driven split, highlighting the challenges of launching a new party under the UK’s first-past-the-post system and exposing divides between traditional Corbynists and Gaza-focused independents, underscores the fragmentation of Britain’s left and leaves 700,000 registered supporters politically homeless. What remains is a semi-allied collection of left-wing micro-groups often at odds.

articles.title: Taxpayers lose £400m as result of investment fund set up by Rishi Sunak
articles.trailText: Report shows 334 companies backed by Future Fund, set up in May 2020 by then chancellor, have since gone under
articles.summary: The Future Fund, launched by then-chancellor Rishi Sunak in May 2020 to support emerging firms during the pandemic, backed 1,190 companies with £1.14bn of public convertible loans. A Department for Business and Trade report shows 334 of those startups have since failed, costing taxpayers £400m, and the portfolio’s value slid to £609m (or £736m post-returns) by March 2025. It also funded unconventional ventures—from festival tickets group Pollen to sex party organiser Killing Kittens—and flagged £79.5m across 47 companies for suspected fraud. Critics had warned the scheme would draw “second-tier” firms and lacked a firm value-for-money guarantee.

articles.title: UK anti-slavery commissioner condemns Shabana Mahmood’s asylum comments
articles.trailText: Home secretary’s remarks about ‘vexatious’ claims will have real-life impact on trafficking victims, says Eleanor Lyons
articles.summary: UK anti-slavery commissioner Eleanor Lyons has condemned home secretary Shabana Mahmood’s remarks accusing asylum seekers of making “vexatious, last-minute” modern slavery claims to evade removal to France under the Channel “one in, one out” small boats deal. Mahmood is appealing a high court injunction that delayed the deportation of a 25-year-old Eritrean man, seeking to shorten the 14-day window to submit trafficking evidence. Lyons warned such rhetoric risks real-world harm to victims, cited lack of evidence for system abuse, and criticized government failures to identify and protect genuine modern slavery survivors.

articles.title: Privatisation of UK industries is driving cost of living crisis, says Greens leader
articles.trailText: Zack Polanski calls mass privatisation a ‘failed experiment’ as report finds it has cost UK households £250 a year more
articles.summary: Green Party leader Zack Polanski warns that decades of privatisation have imposed a £250-a-year “privatisation premium” on UK households, costing consumers £200 billion in dividends since the 1980s. He brands the sell-off of rail, mail, energy and water a ‘failed experiment’ and accuses both Conservatives and Labour of presiding over rising bills, crumbling services and widening inequality. Backed by a Common Wealth report and TUC boss Paul Nowak, Polanski urges full public ownership of essential services—including water firms like Thames Water—and faster renationalisation to tackle the cost-of-living crisis and climate emergency.
